revision.text:
[[Image:Dorset Geology.png|thumb|350px|Geological map of Dorset]] '''Dorset''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|ɔr|s|ɨ|t}} (or [[Archaism|archaically]], '''Dorsetshire''') is a [[Counties of England|county]] in [[South West England]] on the [[English Channel]] coast. Covering an area of {{convert|2653|km2|sqmi|0}}; it borders [[Devon]] to the west, [[Somerset]] to the north-west, [[Wiltshire]] to the north-east, and [[Hampshire]] to the east. The great variation in its landscape owes much to the underlying geology which includes an almost unbroken sequence of rocks from 200 Ma to 40 Ma and superficial deposits from 2 Ma to the present.<ref name=CHA5-6>Chaffey (pp.5-6)</ref> In general the oldest rocks ([[Early Jurassic]]) appear in the far west of the county, with the most recent ([[Eocene]]) in the far east. Jurassic rocks also underlie the Blackmore Vale and comprise much of the coastal cliff in the west and south of the county; and although younger Cretaceous rocks crown some of the highpoints in the west, they are mainly to be found in the centre and east of the county.<ref name=CHA6>Chaffey (p.6)</ref>
Dorset's coastline is one of the most visited and studied coastlines in the world because it shows, along the course of {{convert|95|mi|km|0}} (including some of east [[Devon]]), rocks from the beginning of [[Triassic]], through the [[Jurassic]] and up to the end of the [[Cretaceous]], documenting the entire [[Mesozoic]] era with well-preserved [[fossil]]s.<ref>House (1993) pp.1-4</ref> Throughout Dorset there are a number of [[limestone]] ridges.<ref>Chaffey pp.5-7</ref> The largest and most notable is the band of [[Cretaceous]] [[chalk]] that runs from the south-west to the north-east of the county and forms part of the [[Chalk Group]] that underlies much of the south of England, including [[Salisbury Plain]], the [[Isle of Wight]] and the [[South Downs]]. Between the bands of limestone and chalk are wide [[clay]] [[River valley|vale]]s with [[flood plain]]s.
South-east Dorset, around [[Poole]], [[Bournemouth]] and the [[New Forest]], lies on younger and less resistant beds: Eocene clays (mainly [[London Clay]]), [[sand]]s and [[gravel]]s. These rocks produce thin soils that historically have supported a [[heathland]] habitat. The chalk and limestone hills of the [[Isle of Purbeck|Purbeck]]s lie atop Britain's largest onshore [[oil field]]. The field, operated from [[Wytch Farm]], produces a high-quality oil and has the world's oldest continuously pumping well at [[Kimmeridge]], which has been in use since the early 1960s.<ref>Cullingford (p.122)</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bp.com/liveassets/bp_internet/globalbp/STAGING/global_assets/downloads/U/uk_asset_wytch_farm.pdf|title=Wytch Farm|work=Asset Portfolio|publisher=BP|accessdate=8 March 2012|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65ctcW4NE|archivedate=21 February 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref> The source of this oil is the organic-rich shales found in the lower lias. Landslides along the coast have been known to ignite these shales causing cliff fires, the most recent of which occurred in 2000.<ref>Ensom (1998) pp.22-23</ref><ref name= NatEng>{{cite web|url= http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/conservation/geodiversity/englands/counties/area_ID9.aspx|title=Geodiversity: Dorset|page=|work= |publisher= Natural England|accessdate=24 January 2012|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/66ihIvWI0|archivedate=6 April 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Permian and Triassic==
===380–204 Ma (late Devonian – late Triassic)=== 380 million years ago ([[Year#Symbols y and yr|Ma]]) the landmass that was later to form Southern Britain was some 19 degrees south of the equator and lay on the northern shore of an ocean basin that separated the continents of [[Laurasia]] and [[Gondwanaland]]. When these continents collided to form the single super-continent of [[Pangaea]], the sediments on the ocean floor were pushed up and over while the molten rock below the surface was forced out.<ref>Ensom (p.13)</ref> Today, these [[igneous intrusion]]s and the red [[sandstones]], visible in the neighbouring county of Devon, slope away from west to east and are deeply buried beneath younger deposits in Dorset.<ref>Ensom (p.14)</ref> Around 204 Ma Dorset, now 30 degrees north, was under water and the first [[ammonite]]s (''Psiloceras planorbis'') appear among the shales and limestones that make up the lower Lias.<ref>Ensom (p.19)</ref>
===204–191 Ma (late Triassic – early Jurassic)=== [[File:Blue lias cliffs at Lyme Regis.jpg|thumb|The blue lias cliffs at Lyme Regis]]
Formed somewhere between 191 Ma and 204 Ma, in what was then a shallow marine environment, the lower [[Lias Group|Lias]] is composed of Blue Lias, Black Ven Marls and Green Ammonite Beds. Mostly covered by lush vegetation, it forms the floor of [[Marshwood Vale]] in the west of Dorset and can be seen in stream beds, where the land has been excavated, and along the coast to the west of [[Seatown]]. The sides of the vale are mainly made from the clays and sands of the upper and lower Lias while younger strata from the [[Cretaceous Period]] (145-66 Ma), crown the higher points.<ref>Ensom (p.21)</ref> The Blue Lias is the lowest of the Liassic stratum and where it is visible on the coast near Lyme Regis is layered with hard limestone and oil-rich shale.<ref>Ensom (p.22)</ref> The iron pyrites in the clay can heat up when exposed to the air and occasionally ignite the shales.<ref name=E23>Ensom (p.23)</ref>
Around [[Lyme Regis|Lyme]], during the 18th and 19th centuries, the collecting and sale of fossils became a popular occupation. Landslides and the excavation of the clays, used in cement production, exposed not only an abundance of ammonites of varying size, but much larger specimens such as Ichthyosaurs and Plesiosaurs.<ref name=E23>Ensom (p.23)</ref> Although these rocks were formed underwater, the discovery of fossilised wood, land-dwelling animals and a Pterosaur suggest that dry land was close by.<ref>Ensom (p.24)</ref>
==Jurassic==
===191–190 Ma (early Jurassic)=== Laid down between 191 Ma and 190 Ma years ago in a shallower marine environment that was subjected to much more turbulent weather conditions, the sediments of the middle Lias are not as muddy as those in the lower Lias, and are much nearer to silt and sand.<ref name=E25>Ensom (p.25)</ref> These sands are thought to have come from the islands that now form part of Cornwall and South Wales.<ref name=E25/> Again, inland exposure is poor, although the middle Lias is visible along the spring line of the hills that surround the Marshwood Vale. The cliffs either side of [[Eype]] and the coastal stretch between [[Thorncombe]] and Watton Cliff provide the best view.<ref name=E25/> The base of the middle Lias is composed of three thick layers of calcareous sandstone beds separated by marls. These resistant bands form massive buttresses along the sea-cliffs and, where eroded, boulder aprons on the foreshore.
Above these three layers is the Eype clay, which was probably deposited in deeper, calmer waters.<ref>Ensom (p.26)</ref> Ammonites found in this layer have apparently been attacked by larger crustaceans. The fossilised remains of large numbers of brittle stars, found towards the end of this deposition, indicate that they were rapidly covered. Theories put forward suggest a great storm or tidal wave was the cause and indeed many of the remains appear to have been swept along the sediment, some losing limbs on the way. This particular section of the lias is appropriately known as the "starfish bed".<ref>Ensom (P.26-27)</ref> The succeeding layers of Downcliffe and Thorncombe sands also appear to have been deposited in a periodically stormy environment where silts and sands dominate. Pebbles and cobbles are found here, encrusted with fossilised animals, which suggests that some of the sediments were already [[Lithification#Lithification|lithified]]; there is also some evidence of localised fault activity.<ref>Ensom (p.28)</ref> The last layer in the middle Lias is the Marlstone Rock Bed.
===190–180 Ma (early Jurassic)=== [[File:East Cliffs, West Bay, Dorset - geograph.org.uk - 758051.jpg|thumb|The distinctive yellow cliffs near West Bay, formed of Bridport sand]]
The lowest part of the upper lias, formed around 190 Ma, is known as the junction bed and despite representing 3,000,000 years, is only 0.6 to 1.5 metres thick, where it can be seen at [[Eype Mouth]].<ref name=E29>Ensom (p.29)</ref> In Yorkshire the equivalent strata is around 100 metres thick, suggesting that Dorset remained underwater much longer and was robbed of supplies of sand and clay. This bed is composed of fine grain limestones from white to pale pink in colour.<ref name=E29>Ensom (P.29)</ref> The clearest evidence of fault activity exists in a section of cliff between West Bay and Eype Mouth, where the junction bed thickens in a section of steps, and fractures in the rock contain sediment from the ocean bed which, most likely, was sucked in as the cracks opened.<ref name=E29/>
The remaining part of the upper Lias is the bright yellow Bridport sandstone that gives the cliffs between West Bay and Burton Bradstock their distinctive colour.<ref name=E31>Ensom (p.31)</ref> The sands form a band that runs inland to [[Yeovil]]. In the east of the county, these sands are some 900 metres below the surface and form the Wytch Farm oilfield’s middle reservoir.<ref name=E31/>
===180–170 Ma (early – middle Jurassic)=== The succeeding [[Inferior Oolite]] was deposited in a shallow, tropical marine environment, 35 degrees north of the equator. It is only 2 metres thick in the south but increases to 20 metres in the north, near Sherborne.<ref name=E32>Ensom (p.32)</ref> It contains many fossils, including bryozoans, brachiopods, ammonites, belemnites, gastropods, bivalves and echinoids, and like the previous middle and upper Lias shows signs of fault-controlled deposition.<ref name=E32/> It appears in some places that the sea floor was breached and sediments and fossils were trapped like those in the junction bed between West Bay and Eype. Most of Dorset was starved of sediment and condensed limestones collected.<ref name=E32/> These limestone beds are often iron rich, lending them a rusty colour. One particular bed, exposed at Burton Cliff, contains large numbers of orange, discus-shaped concretions, which on closer inspection reveal themselves to be pieces of shell from a species of mussel, coated with a thin layer of iron-rich sediment.<ref name=E33>Ensom (p.33)</ref>
In the upper section of the Inferior Oolite there are two beds packed with numerous types of sponge, which can be seen around Shipton Gorge and Burton Bradstock.<ref name=E34>Ensom (p.34)</ref> Despite being formed in a marine environment, the oolite, like the lower Lias, contains some fossilised remains of land-dwelling creatures, including two species of ''[[Megalosaurus]]'' that were found near Sherborne.<ref name=E34/>
===170–160 Ma (middle – late Jurassic)=== Fullers Earth clays were deposited across much of southern Dorset when the continental shelf subsided, forcing the region deeper underwater. The lower clays are visible at [[Burton Bradstock]] and contain large numbers of ''Bositra buchi''. It has been suggested that these bivalves were able to swim freely and thus able to avoid the soupy mud on the sea floor.<ref name=E35/36>Ensom (pp.35-36)</ref> A limestone known as Fullers Earth Rock is found in the north-west of the county, between the clays south and east of Sherborne. It is rich in ammonites and bivalves.<ref name=E36>Ensom (p.36)</ref> Previously referred to as the Upper Fullers Earth Clay, the succeeding Frome Clay can be seen to the west of West Bay where it forms the major part of the West Cliff. It contains many [[Brachiopods]], particularly in the Weymouth Anticline where the oyster beds are 5 metres thick.<ref name=E36/> At the junction between the Frome Clay and the overlying Forest Marble is the Boueti Bed, so called because of the large numbers of the brachiopod, ''Goniorhynchia boueti'' found there. It is best viewed on the Herbury peninsula south of [[Langton Herring]].<ref name=E36/> The limestone known as Forest Marble is not a true metamorphic marble but it takes a high polish, and has been used as a building material and marble substitute for many years.<ref>Ensom (pp.37-38)</ref> Outcrops of Forest Marble are concentrated around the Weymouth Anticline, the coastal escarpment between Burton Bradstock and [[Abbotsbury]], and inland as far as [[Bothenhampton]], where they disappear below younger Cretaceous deposits. Surfacing once more at [[Rampisham]], they turn east and then north into [[Somerset]].<ref name=E38>Ensom (p.38)</ref> The limestone does not form one continuous bed as previously thought, but rather forms pockets in a formation which is predominately clay. It is likely that severe tropical storms swept up large quantities of shells and other invertebrates and deposited them in this way.<ref name=E38/> The formation of the Forest Marble suggests a shallowing of the sea and the remains of pieces of tree, and bits of land-dwelling animals, are found among the turtles, frogs and salamanders within.<ref name=E38/>
===160–145 Ma (late Jurassic)=== Between 160 Ma and 145 Ma, the future Dorset, at 36 degrees north, still had a tropical climate and the limestones, clays, silts and sands from this period were laid down in a marine environment that ranged from deep water to tidal shallows.<ref name=E39>Ensom (p.39)</ref> Above the Forest Marble lies the [[Cornbrash]] sequence which is dominated by rubbly limestone. Unsuitable for building stone, these limestones have been used lime production and road construction. In the north of the county an already lithified Cornbrash floor was being eroded, and the resulting pebbles gathered serpulid worms, bryozoans and bivalves as they rolled around beneath the shallow sea.<ref name=E39/> The shallow water in which these limestones were deposited was followed by marginally deeper water in which the [[Kellaways Formation|Kellaway Beds]] were laid down. The Kellaway Beds are only visible in the banks of streams and rivers, and the brick pits at [[Chickerell]] and Rampisham where the succeeding [[Oxford Clay Formation|Oxford Clays]] were quarried.<ref>Ensom (pp.39-40)</ref> The Oxford Clays were deposited in much deeper water and cover the valley floors between Weymouth and the Blackmore Vale.They can also be seen in the cliffs at Tidmoor Point, [[Jordan Hill, Dorset|Jordan Hill]] and the previously mentioned brick pits at Chickerell.<ref name=E40>Ensom (p.40)</ref> Poor exposure, coupled with a decline in the brick industry has made detailed mapping of the clays difficult which now relies heavily on trenches dug for services. These excavations have unearthed some impressive examples of [[Septarian Nodule]]s.<ref name=E40/>
The exposure of Nothe Grit, to the south of Weymouth, suggests a return to shallower water conditions and a more turbulent environment. In the following 4.5 million years a cycle of lagoonal, tidal and deep water environments caused by a world-wide fluctuations in sea levels, deposited beds of sand, clay and limestone across the entire county.<ref>Ensom (pp.40-41)</ref> The Corallian strata can be seen on the Weymouth anticline, between Abbotsbury and [[Osmington]]. It then disappears to emerge as a low escarpment between [[Mappowder]] and [[Cucklington]] on the [[Somerset]] border. Near the top of this formation is the Ringstead Waxy Clay in which large delta shaped oysters are found and at the top of the Corallian is the Ringstead Coral Bed.<ref name=E42>Ensom (p.42)</ref>
Benecliff grit, a soft sandstone containing large doggers, is well exposed at the headland, Bran Point. Once a reservoir, oil sometimes seeps from the cliff here, and an oily residue is present in the sands nearby.<ref name=E42/>
===145–140 Ma (Late Jurassic)=== [[File:Beach and cliffs, Egmont Bight - geograph.org.uk - 900296.jpg|thumb|Kimmeridge Clay in the cliffs at Egmont Bight]] The varied rock types of the Corallian are superseded by the Kimmeridge clay, a bed of dark clays and shales up to 500 metres thick. These deposits occurred in a deep marine environment, 38 degrees north, 140 Ma to 145 Ma.<ref name=E43>Ensom (p.43)</ref> Deposited in an oxygen deficient environment, the Kimmeridge beds make up the major part of the Purbeck Monocline and the periphery of the Weymouth Anticline. They form a low lying band running north to south through the [[Blackmore Vale]], and underpin the strip of land between the isle of Portland and the mainland.<ref name=E43/><ref>Chaffey (p.12)</ref> The unusual iron rich sediment near Abbotsbury was, in a departure from the norm, deposited in shallow iron rich water and the pale bands throughout the formation were caused by [[Coccolith]]s following periodic blooms of algae.
Many of the fossilised remains are squashed flat, indicating that the Kimmeridge beds were heavily compacted, perhaps to an eighth of their original thickness. This was not sufficient to produce oil reservoirs like those beneath the [[North Sea]], yet the oil rich shales have, in the past, been economically important as a local fuel.<ref>Ensom (pp.45-46)</ref>
===140-137 Ma (Late Jurassic)===
It is unclear whether the formations created between the Upper Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous, were deposited across the whole of Dorset like the preceding beds, and subsequently eroded, or only formed in the areas in which they are now found.<ref name=E47>Ensom (p.47)</ref>
The Portland sands were created in a deep marine environment whereas the [[Portland stone]] was a near shore deposit.<ref name=E47/> The lower Portland Sand formation, usually greyish blue in colour, is a [[Dolomitic]] sand limestone best viewed on the West Weares, Gad Cliff and Hounstout. The overlying Portland stone is a distinctive white Oolite containing thick shelled fossils and marine algae.<ref name=E48>Ensom (p.48)</ref> The marine algae which formed large reefs, is responsible for the occasional stacked and arched bands in the formation and is best viewed in the Roach, an extremely fossiliferous limestone confined to the north of [[Isle of Portland|Portland]].<ref>Ensom (pp.48-49)</ref>
To the north of the Oolite is a fine grained limestone, which was deposited in calm, shallow water. It contains flint-like rocks known as [[Chert]] and if it wasn't for the presence of very large ammonites, might be mistaken for an early chalk.<ref>Ensom (p.50)</ref> Previously thought to be around the middle of the Purbeck Strata, modern research suggests that the end of the Portland limestone marks the boundary between the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods.<ref name=E51>Ensom (p.51)</ref>
===137–130 Ma (Late Jurassic – early Cretaceous)=== [[File:Fossil Forest, West Lulworth, Dorset - geograph.org.uk - 603310.jpg|thumb|Part of the fossil forest, West Lulworth]] The Purbeck limestone group is a succession of limestones, shales and clays named after the [[Isle of Purbeck]], laid down mainly in very shallow lagoons and freshwater lakes, with only occasional marine influence at the lower levels where [[salt]], [[gypsum]] and other [[evaporite]]s are found.<ref name=E51>Ensom (p.51)</ref> The muddled sediments around Lulworth are thought to be caused by a thick layer of these evaporites dissolving. There is also evidence of uplift and erosion of earlier formations. The climate around this time had changed from a tropical to a sub-tropical one, with pronounced wet and dry seasons as indicated by the growth rings in the fosslised trees also found in the lower levels of the Purbeck strata.<ref>Ensom (pp.51-52)</ref> These trees grew around the low coastal areas and were, from time to time, subjected to drowning from the sea. The fallen trees and their stumps became covered by [[stromatolites]] which trapped sediments. The limestones at this level, which vary greatly in colour, are composed of densely packed shells of the freshwater snail ''[[Viviparus]]''.<ref>Arkell, W. J. (1947), ''Geology of the country round Weymouth, Swanage, Corfe Castle and Lulworth''. London: HMSO for British Geological Survey.</ref><ref>Clements, R. G. (1993), "Type-section of the Purbeck Limestone Group, Durlston Bay, Swanage, Dorset", ''Proceedings of the Dorset Natural History and Archaeological Society'', '''114''', 181–206.</ref> Their ability to take a very high polish has led them to become known as [[Purbeck Marble]]. Like the older Forest Marble it is a sedimentary marble rather than a true metamorphic one.<ref>Ensom (p.52)</ref>
The Purbeck Limestone Group has yielded a diverse selection of fossilised remains, including rare reptiles, amphibians and mammals, for which the formation has become internationally important.<ref>Ensom (pp.52 & 56)</ref>
==Cretaceous==
===130–113 Ma (early Cretaceous)=== The [[Wealden Supergroup|Wealden Beds]] are confined to the south and increase in thickness from 107 metres to 716 metres, between [[Upwey, Dorset|Upwey]] and [[Swanage]].<ref name=E57/> By 130 million years ago, the waters covering Dorset's landmass had subsided leaving the area almost completely terrestrial save for the large rivers that dominated it.<ref name=E57>Ensom (p.57)</ref> These rivers drained the upland areas to the north and west, and were responsible for depositing much of the succeeding sediment across southern Dorset.<ref name=E57/> Comprising clays, silts, sands and grits, they cover the floors of the valleys between Lulworth and Swanage. The sands and grits are also exposed in the cliffs there, and form ridges along the valleys.<ref name=E57/> Traces of granite from Cornubia, the landmass that later became Cornwall, were also washed down.<ref name=E59>Ensom (p.59)</ref> The Wealden Beds contain a great deal of plant matter and [[charcoal]] indicating periodic fires in the region. At [[Mupe Bay]], some of the sands have been bound together by oil and formed into sandstone boulders, suggesting that oil production had already begun when these sands were deposited.<ref name=E59/>
===113–97 Ma (early – late Cretaceous)=== The marginal marine incursions that occurred in the previous period increased in severity until Dorset was completely underwater. The geology from this period indicates a gradual flooding of the county from the south-east to the north-west.<ref name=E60>Ensom (p.60)</ref> The earliest deposit, the [[Lower Greensand Group|Lower Greensand]], covers the preceding Wealden Beds in the south, and the Oxford and Kimmeridge clays in the north.<ref name=E60/> It is so called because of its green colour which is caused by the presence of the mineral [[Glauconite]].<ref name=E62>Ensom (p.62)</ref>
In the west, overlying the eroded Lias, is a thin layer of [[Gault clay]] which decreases in depth from 27 metres to 7 metres the further west it stretches, and can be located by the spring lines around the chalk ridges and escarpments.<ref>Ensom (pp.60&61)</ref> The water that sits between these two beds is responsible for the many landslips which have occurred throughout the county's history.<ref name=E62/> Around [[Compton Valence]], it lies on the Fuller's Earth whereas between [[Ringstead, Dorset|Ringstead]] and [[White Nothe]], it covers the Kimmeridge clay and the Portland and Purbeck stratas.<ref>Ensom (pp.60-61)</ref> Because geologists are certain all the formations from the Lias to the Kimmeridge clay were deposited over the whole of the county, the Gault clay reveals the scale of uplift and erosion which must have taken place before Dorset was flooded.<ref name=E61>Ensom (p.61)</ref> The overlying Gault is revealed in the spring lines around the chalk ridges and escarpments.<ref name=E61/> This water is also responsible for the many landslips throughout Dorset's history from the prehistoric to modern times.<ref name=E62>Ensom (p.62)</ref>
Above the Gault is the [[Upper Greensand]], which varies from the golden sands that crown the West Dorset heights, such as [[Pilsdon Pen]] and [[Golden Cap]], to the rubbly sandstones found in the centre of the county.<ref name=E62/> The fossiliferous, green sandstone found around [[Shaftesbury]] contains many ammonites which, when compared to other deposits, indicate condensed deposition during different periods at different locations and detailed analysis reveals that basement structures were still active at this time.<ref name=E62/>
===97–65 Ma (late Cretaceous – Paleocene)=== The sea levels remained more or less unchanged until the end of the Cretaceous period and despite Dorset having moved even further north to 40 degrees, the climate had reverted to a tropical one. During this period, the sea deposited an enormous amount of chalk across the county, perhaps as much as 300 metres more than there is currently.<ref name=E63>Ensom (p.63)</ref> The first chalk deposits contained sands and grits thought to have originated in Cornubia. This gritty chalk was deposited across central Dorset and can clearly be seen in the sides of [[Eggardon Hill]]. As the water deepened, [[plankton]], coccoliths and [[foraminifera]] became the main source for the calcereous soup which would later form the Dorset chalk.<ref name=E63/> The chalk forms a narrow strip inland between [[Studland]] and [[Worbarrow Bay]] when it reaches the coast once more. A much wider strip continues westward along the coast until it meets the wide swathe of chalk that cuts north-west across the county and forms the south-east point of the [[Hampshire Basin]].<ref name=E64>Ensom (p.64)</ref> Generally the Dorset chalk is too soft to be used as a building stone except along the [[Wessex Ridgeway|Ridgeway]] where faulting and folding produced a particularly hard variety popularly used by the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] in their [[mosaic]]s. The chalk often contains larger fossils including ammonites, belemnites and brachiopods. Flint occurs throughout in both nodule and tabular layers.<ref name=E64/>
The [[iridium]] rich layer of sediment, found around the world at the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event|K-T]] boundary, is missing in Dorset. This may be due to the uplift and erosion that removed the upper layers of the chalk.<ref name=E66>Ensom (p.66)</ref> The sediments resting on the Dorset chalk are, for the same reason, distinctly different from those in other parts of the world, and the remains of the plants and animals within, much more recent.<ref name=E68>Ensom (p.68)</ref>
==Paleogene and Neogene==
===65–40 Ma (Paleocene – Eocene)=== [[File:Geograph-2158028-by-Nigel-Mykura.jpg|thumb|The edge of Culpepper's Dish, a large [[Sinkhole|doline]] on Briantspuddle Heath]] The expansion of the North Atlantic, which first occurred during the [[Triassic]] period, now reached a point where it was affecting the Dorset landscape. Areas that were previously underwater were exposed to erosion as the chalk was folded and forced upwards.<ref name=E69>Ensom (p.69)</ref> The early deposits from this period, found across South-East England, do not occur in Dorset. The small amounts found in Devon however, coupled with the many [[sinkhole|solution holes]] found across the Dorset chalk, suggests that erosion may have removed them.<ref name=E69-70>Ensom (pp.69-70)</ref> Some of the larger solution holes, known as dolines, are found on the heaths between [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]] and [[Bere Regis]]. Near [[Briantspuddle]] is Culpepper's Dish, 86 metres wide and over 21 metres deep.<ref name=E70>Ensom (p.70)</ref>
The first deposits found from this period in Dorset are the Reading Formation clays. A sub-division of the [[Lambeth Group]], they are visible above the chalk at Studland. Mottled, brightly coloured and generally lacking fossils, the clays are thought to be deposited beneath [[lagoons]].<ref name=E70/> In the east of the county, however, fossilised remains of gastropods and sharks' teeth have been found alongside flint pebbles, clearly identifying these clays as marine deposits.<ref name=E71>Ensom (p.71)</ref>
The [[Bracklesham Beds|Bracklesham group]], found across much of the Dorset portion of the Hampshire Basin, were mainly deposited by rivers and form the foundations of the Dorset heathland. The frequent and heavy rains which occurred during this period transported large amounts of material from northern uplands across the [[Isle of Purbeck|Purbeck]] and [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]] areas.<ref name=E71/> A thick layer of Chert gravel from the Purbeck Strata can be found on Blackdown Hill near [[Portesham]], but it is not known whether it was carried there or whether it is the remains of an earlier deposit.<ref>Ensom (pp.71-72)</ref> Blocks of Quartzite can be found across the downlands of Southern Dorset and these sarsons have been used in the some of the local prehistoric monuments.<ref name=E71>Ensom (p.71)</ref>
To the north and east of the county, much finer sands and gravels are found, including ball clay which was widely mined on the heaths around Wareham.<ref name=E72>Ensom (p.72)</ref> The fine particles which make up the clay are believed to have originated in the west where rocks were being broken down by the alternating dry, humid conditions and torrential rain, which in turn formed rivers and carried the material to its current position.<ref name=E72/> Overlying the clay is the Agglestone grit, an iron cemented sandstone which forms the [[Agglestone Rock|Agglestone]] near Studland, and has been used in the buildings in and around the heathland where it is found.<ref name=E73>Ensom (p.73)</ref> [[File:Stair Hole - geograph.org.uk - 24710.jpg|thumb|The crumpled rock strata at Stair Hole caused by a collision between the African and Eurasian plates]]
Fossilised palms taken from the cliffs at Bournemouth confirm that Dorset had a tropical climate at the time.<ref name=E73/> [[Creech Barrow Hill]] is crowned with a unique early Eocene limestone that has yielded some important fossils. Outcrops of rock from the Barton Group occur along the coast between Bournemouth and [[Hengistbury Head]].<ref name=E74>Ensom (p.74)</ref>
===45–1.5 Ma (Eocene – Pleistocene)=== During this period, Dorset drifted a further 9 degrees north, the climate cooled rapidly and by 37 Ma was [[Temperateness|temperate]].<ref name=E75>Ensom (p.75)</ref> Mainly terrestrial with fresh and brackish water environments, the county would, despite its low-lying nature, remain largely without marine influences except for some minor incursions at the end of the ice ages. The late [[Palaeogene]] deposits that filled the Hampshire Basin as the sea levels fell are not found in Dorset, nor are the [[Neogene]], which are absent from virtually all of the [[British Isles]].<ref name=E75/>
The collision of the [[African plate|African]] and [[Eurasian plate]]s that occurred around this time caused a violent uplift in the south of the county, the results of which can be seen clearly at [[Stair Hole]], where the strata run almost vertically.<ref>Ensom (pp.75-76)</ref> Further, but less dramatic folding and uplift, along the county's subsurface faults, coupled with continuing erosion of Jurassic and Cretaceous sediments, created Dorset's modern landscape and drainage patterns.<ref name=E76>Ensom (p.76)</ref>
==Quaternary==
===1.5 Ma–Present (Pleistocene – Holocene)=== [[File:Cliffs at the north end of White Hole - geograph.org.uk - 1099825.jpg|thumb|left|Raised beach deposits at [[Portland Raised Beach|White Hole]], Portland]] During the last 1,500,000 years, Britain was subjected to a number of extreme fluctuations in temperature which included three ice ages. Dorset was not affected by glaciation but did experience very low temperatures with permafrost on the high ground.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://publications.environment-agency.gov.uk/PDF/SCHO0207BLYB-E-E.pdf|title=The Chalk of Dorset|page=15|work=Baseline chemistry of selected reference aquifers in England and Wales.|publisher= British Geological Survey/Environment Agency|year=2002|accessdate=24 January 2012|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/691Ty3W1c|archivedate=9 July 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>Ensom (pp.77 - 78)</ref> Sudden changes in sea-level, and successive warming and cooling, took their toll on the landscape.<ref name=E77>Ensom (p.77)</ref> The two [[Portland Raised Beach|raised beaches]] at Portland created 210,000 and 125,000 years ago are a dramatic testament to the fluctuations in sea levels. The cause of these two fluctuations was twofold: the growth of the ice, which absorbed large quantities of water, and the weight of the ice in the north that caused the landmass to tilt.<ref name=E78>Ensom (p.78)</ref>
During the summer months, partial melting of the ice created large rivers that washed enormous amounts of sand and gravel across the county, forming huge terraces in both the upland areas and valleys.<ref name=E78>Ensom (p.78)</ref> These rivers cut down into the landscape as they made their way to the lower sea levels. This action caused many large-scale landslips, most notably around Shaftesbury and Abbotsbury.<ref name=E78/>
Landslips caused by marine erosion still occur today, with some of the largest taking place along the West Dorset Coast. Fossilised remains, including the teeth and tusks of [[Elephantidae|elephants]] and [[mammoth]]s dating back 500,000 years, are often exposed.<ref name=E79>Ensom (p.79)</ref> Flint and Chert tools from early human visitors have been retrieved from the river terraces around the Dorset and Devon border, although these may have been transported here with the other river deposits.<ref name=E79/> [[Chesil Bank]] a {{convert|29|km|mi|0}} long [[barrier beach]] stretching from [[West Bay]] to Portland, was created 10,000 years ago, when sea levels rose at the end of the last ice age.
==Structure== [[File:Rock Strata, Durdle Door - geograph.org.uk - 274762.jpg|thumb|Vertical rock strata on the west side of [[St Oswald's Bay]], at the western end of the Purbeck Monocline]]
===Structural development=== The [[Variscan orogeny]] is the oldest event for which there is evidence in Dorset, forming a major series of [[thrust fault]]s in [[Carboniferous]] and older rocks. These thrusts trend west–east, dip moderately towards the south and have controlled later basin development and subsequent phases of [[inversion (geology)|inversion]]. During the Permo-Triassic the area was affected by a phase of rifting that reactivated the older thrusts in extension.<ref name="Chadwick">{{cite journal|last=Chadwick|first=R.A.|year=1986|title=Extension tectonics in the Wessex Basin, southern England|journal=Journal of the Geological Society|publisher=[[Geological Society]]|volume=143|pages=465–488|url=http://jgs.lyellcollection.org/content/143/3/465.abstract|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> These extensional faults were themselves reactivated during further rifting in Jurassic to early Cretaceous times. The area experienced the effects of the early stages of Alpine collision during the Late Cretaceous to [[Palaeogene]], with reverse reactivation of many of the extensional faults, creating the most visible of the structures in the Dorset area, such as the Purbeck Monocline.
===Litton Cheney Fault=== The Litton Cheney Fault is a west–east-trending, south-dipping normal fault. The fault was active during deposition of the Lias Group and again during the Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous. There is evidence of minor reversal on the fault during the Late Cretaceous to Palaeogene inversion.<ref name="Butler">{{cite book|last=Butler|first=M.|coauthors=|title=The development, evolution and petroleum geology of the Wessex Basin|publisher=[[Geological Society]]|location=London|year=1998|series=Special Publications|volume=133|chapter=The geological history of the southern Wessex Basin — a review of new information from oil exploration|isbn=9781897799994|url=http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/133/1/241.abstract|accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref>
===Abbotsbury–Ridgeway Fault=== This major west–east-trending, south-dipping normal fault was mainly active during the Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous, as shown by the local preservation of the Wealden in its hanging wall. It was reactivated as a reverse fault during the Late Cretaceous to Palaeogene, and now juxtaposes Portland and Purbeck beds in the hanging wall against Chalk in the footwall. The fault is not directly linked to faults beneath the Triassic salt layer.<ref name="Harvey"/> [[File:Weymouth Anticline.png|thumb|Cross-section over the Weymouth Anticline|260px]]
===Weymouth Anticline=== The Weymouth Anticline has a west–east trending axis and plunges to the east. Strata beneath the Upper Triassic halite are unfolded indicating that the salt is acting as a [[decollement]]. The anticline is a result of inversion along the Abbotsbury–Ridgeway Fault, although it has been suggested that it developed by the tightening of an earlier rollover anticline, formed during an earlier extensional phase, due to the [[Salt_tectonics#Salt_detached_fault_systems|soft-linked nature]] of the faulting.<ref name="Harvey">{{cite book|last=Harvey|first=M.J.|coauthors=Stewart S.A.|title=The development, evolution and petroleum geology of the Wessex Basin|publisher=[[Geological Society]]|location=London|year=1998|series=Special Publications|volume=133|chapter=Influence of salt on the structural evolution of the Channel Basin|isbn=9781897799994|url=http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/133/1/67.abstract|accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref>
===Purbeck Monocline=== {{main|Purbeck Monocline}} This monoclinal structure forms part of a semi-continuous structure extending eastwards through the Isle of Wight as the Portland-Wight Monocline (or Disturbance). This was formed by reverse reactivation of the Purbeck–Isle of Wight fault zone.<ref name="Beeley">{{cite book|last=Beeley|first=H.S.|coauthors=Norton M.G.|title=The development, evolution and petroleum geology of the Wessex Basin|publisher=[[Geological Society]]|location=London|year=1998|series=Special Publications|volume=133|pages=283–298|chapter=The structural development of the Central English Channel High — constraints from section restoration|isbn=9781897799994|url=http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/133/1/283.abstract|accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref>

M. |titlelink1=|others= |title=The Dorset Coast|origyear=|publisher=Adam and Charles Black|location=London|year= 1964|language= |isbn=|page= |pages= |at=}} *{{cite book |first1=Ensom |last1=Paul |titlelink1=|others= |title=Discover Dorset: Geology|origyear=|publisher=Dovecote Press|location=Wimborne|year= 1998|language= |isbn=1 874336 52 0|page= |pages= |at=}} *{{cite book |first1=Michael R.|last1=House |titlelink1=|others= |title=Geology of the Dorset Coast|year=1993|publisher=The Geologists' Association|location=Gower Street, London.|language= |isbn=0-900717-58-0|page= |pages= |at=}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{About|1=the English music producer|2=the Australian politician|3=John Leckie (Australian politician)|the English music producer|Jock Leckie}}
'''John William Leckie''' (born 23 October 1949 in [[Paddington]], [[London]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creditgate.com/companysearch/john+leckie+music+limited.aspx |title=John Leckie Music Limited |publisher=Creditgate |date= |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Professor Footprint |url=http://www.dellam.com/cgi-bin/main.pl?web=yes&foundnumber=03978670 |title=Dellam Corporate Information Limited, England |location=51.350638;-0.19093 |publisher=Dellam.com |date= |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref>) is an English [[music producer]], and [[recording engineer]].
==Early career== Leckie began work at [[Abbey Road Studios]] on 15 February 1970 as a Tape-Operator, later graduating to Balance Engineer.<ref name="eandt.theiet.org">{{cite web|url=http://eandt.theiet.org/magazine/2011/11/interview-john-leckie.cfm |title=Interview - John Leckie, record producer - E & T Magazine |publisher=Eandt.theiet.org |date= |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref> During this early career he worked with artists such as [[John Lennon]] (''[[John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band]]''), [[George Harrison]], (''[[All Things Must Pass]]''), [[Syd Barrett]] (''[[Barrett (album)|Barrett]]'') and [[Pink Floyd]] (''[[Meddle]]'' and ''[[Wish You Were Here (Pink Floyd album)|Wish You Were Here]]'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musictank.co.uk/resources/speaker-biographies/john-leckie-producer |title=John Leckie - Producer — MusicTank |publisher=Musictank.co.uk |date=15 February 1970 |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref> With [[Paul McCartney]]'s [[Wings (band)|Wings]] Leckie worked on ''[[Red Rose Speedway]]'' and the single "[[Hi, Hi, Hi]]". He mixed [[Be-Bop Deluxe]]'s début album ''[[Axe Victim]]''. His first job as producer was the same band's third album ''[[Sunburst Finish (album)|Sunburst Finish]]'', which collaboration continued through ''Modern Music'', ''Live! In The Air Age'' and ''[[Drastic Plastic]]''.
Leckie left Abbey Road in 1978 and produced albums for [[Simple Minds]] (''[[Life in a Day (album)|Life in a Day]]'', ''[[Real to Real Cacophony]]'' and ''[[Empires and Dance]]'') and [[Magazine (band)|Magazine]] (''[[Real Life (Magazine album)|Real Life]]''). For [[Be-Bop Deluxe]] founder [[Bill Nelson (musician)|Bill Nelson]], he produced the [[Bill Nelson's Red Noise|Red Noise]] album ''Sound on Sound'' and Nelson's subsequent solo album ''Quit Dreaming And Get On The Beam'' (the latter unreleased until 1981). Leckie recorded the début single, ''[[Public Image (song)|Public Image]]'' for [[Public Image Ltd]]. Leckie's work with [[XTC]] included ''3D-EP'', as well as the band's later albums: ''[[White Music]]'',<ref name="SOS" /> ''[[Go 2]]'', ''[[25 O'Clock]]'' and ''[[Psonic Psunspot]]'' which XTC issued under the pseudonym [[The Dukes of Stratosphear]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ape.uk.net/podcast/2009/03/andy-partridge-chats-with-john-leckie-part-one/ |title=Andy Partridge's Ape House Label » Andy Partridge Chats With John Leckie – Part One |publisher=Ape.uk.net |date=31 March 2009 |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref>
==1980s work== Album productions in the 1980s included work with [[The Fall (band)|The Fall]], [[Brix Smith]]'s post-Fall project [[The Adult Net]], [[The Lucy Show (band)|The Lucy Show]], The Doctor's Children, [[Gene Loves Jezebel]], [[Bill Nelson (musician)|Bill Nelson]], [[The Posies]], [[The Dukes of Stratosphear]], and [[Let's Active]]. For some of his work with The Dukes, The Adult Net and The Doctor's Children, all bands that had strong 1960s psychedelic overtones, Leckie adopted the pseudonym 'Swami Anand Nagara'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://huffduffer.com/twelvety/16273 |title=Andy Partridge Chats With John Leckie - Part Two on Huffduffer |publisher=Huffduffer.com |date= |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref>
In 1984 he produced [[Felt]]'s album [[The Strange Idols Pattern and Other Short Stories]].
In 1989 Leckie produced [[The Stone Roses]]' debut album ''[[The Stone Roses (album)|The Stone Roses]]''.<ref name="Devlin">Devlin, Louise (2009) "[http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/45846-john-leckie-producing-the-goods John Leckie: Producing the Goods]", ''[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]]'', 19 May 2009, retrieved 7 November 2010</ref> The album was voted the best record of all time on a music poll taken by [[BBC Radio 6 Music]] and features as Number 1 on [[the Observer Music Monthly]]’s June 2004 “100 Greatest British Albums”.
==1990s== Leckie was named ''Best Producer'' by [[Music Week]] (1995) and at the [[Q Awards]] (1996) and [[Brit Awards]] (1997).<ref name="SOS">"[http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/1997_articles/may97/johnleckie.html True brit: John Leckie]", ''[[Sound on Sound]]'', May 1997, retrieved 7 November 2010</ref>
Notable production credits from this era include [[The Trashcan Sinatras]]' 1990 debut album ''[[Cake (album)|Cake]]'', [[Robyn Hitchcock and the Egyptians]]' 1991 album ''Respect'', the Stone Roses' album ''Second Coming'', [[The Lilac Time]]'s ''And Love For All'', [[Ride (band)|Ride's]] 1993 (''[[Carnival of Light (album)|Carnival of Light]]''), [[Elastica]]'s 1994 eponymous debut album, [[Cast (band)|Cast's]] albums ''[[All Change (album)|All Change]]'' (1995) and ''[[Mother Nature Calls]]'' (1997), [[Kula Shaker]]'s debut ''[[K (album)|K]]'' (1996), and [[The Verve]]'s ''[[A Storm in Heaven]]''.<ref name="eandt.theiet.org"/> In 1995, Leckie worked on [[Radiohead]]'s album, ''[[The Bends]]''. This would be the band's last album not to be recorded in full by [[Nigel Godrich]], an assistant engineer present during Leckie's work on [[The Bends]].
Leckie's work during the 1990s widened considerably to include the work of [[Dr John]] (''Anutha Zone'').<ref>http://www.mikecollins.plus.com/PUBLICATIONS/PDFS/John%20Leckie%20Interview.pdf</ref>
==Recent career== In 1999 he produced the début album ''[[Showbiz (album)|Showbiz]]'' for Taste Media’s then new signings [[Muse (band)|Muse]]. This went platinum on the heels of the band's breakthrough 2001 second album ''[[Origin of Symmetry]]'', also produced by Leckie, which reached No. 3 in the UK album Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/music/features/45846-john_leckie_producing_goods |title=John Leckie: Producing the Goods |publisher=The Skinny |date=19 May 2009 |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref> In 2000 he began production on ''"Wildflowers"'' the debut album from [[Northern Ireland]] band ''[[Relish (Northern Irish band)|Relish]]''. It attained platinum status in Ireland on release in 2001.<ref>http://www.relishmusic.com/#!Wildflowers/zoom/cvmc/i0q7i</ref> In 2002, Leckie produced a single for [[Suede (band)|Suede]] (''Positivity'' from the album ''New Morning'').
In 2009 he travelled to Mexico to work again with [[Rodrigo y Gabriela]] on tracks for the album ''[[11:11 (Rodrigo y Gabriela album)|11:11]]''. Leckie then returned to [[Abbey Road]] to record and produce the jazz sounds of [[Portico Quartet]] and was also called in to remaster the Anniversary Edition Box Set of [[The Stone Roses]] eponymous first LP complete with his videos of the sessions and some long lost demos. Leckie also appeared in TV's Classic Album Series playing and commenting on tapes from [[Plastic Ono Band]] sessions he had worked on some 40 years previously at [[Abbey Road Studios]].{{cn|date=February 2014}} In 2010, Leckie produced [[The Coral]]'s album, ''[[Butterfly House (album)|Butterfly House]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/indy-choice-best-of-the-new-music-2022787.html?action=gallery&ino=4 |title=The Coral, Butterfly House (Deltasonic) 'I can't quite put my finger on th |publisher=The Independent |date=9 July 2010 |accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref> which went on to win Album of the Year at Music Producer's Guild Awards.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name= Ronnie O'Brien | image = Ronnie Obrien.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | fullname = Ronnie O'Brien | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1979|1|5}} | birth_place = [[Bray]], [[County Wicklow|Co. Wicklow]], Republic of Ireland | height = {{height|ft=5|in=10}} | currentclub = | clubnumber = | position = [[Midfielder]] | youthyears1= | youthclubs1= | years1 = 1997–1999 | years2 = 1999–2002 | years3 = 1999 | years4 = 2000–2001 | years5 = 2001–2002 | years6 = 2002 | years7 = 2002–2006 | years8 = 2007 | years9 =2008 | clubs1 = [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] | clubs2 = [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] | clubs3 = → [[AC Lugano]] (loan) | clubs4 = → [[F.C. Crotone|Crotone]] (loan) | clubs5 = → [[Calcio Lecco 1912|Lecco]] (loan) | clubs6 = → [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] (loan) | clubs7 = [[FC Dallas]] | clubs8 = [[Toronto FC]] | clubs9 =[[San Jose Earthquakes]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | caps3 = 8 | goals3 = 0 | caps4 = 4 | goals4 = 0 | caps5 = 8 | goals5 = 0 | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 0 | caps7 = 108 | goals7 = 12 | caps8 = 13 | goals8 = 0 | caps9 = 28 | goals9 = 4 | totalcaps = 175 | totalgoals = 16 | nationalyears1= | nationalteam1= | nationalcaps1= | nationalgoals1 = | pcupdate = 17 August 2010 | ntupdate = 7 April 2006 }}
'''Ronnie O'Brien''' (born 5 January 1979 in [[Bray]], Republic of Ireland) is a retired Irish [[Association football|footballer]] who last played for the [[San Jose Earthquakes]].
==Playing career== O'Brien's footballing career began very promisingly, when at the age of 18 he signed a contract with [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] of the [[FA Premier League]]. Although he played little at Middlesbrough, he had great success with [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Irish national team]] youth sides, winning the [[UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|European U-16 championship]] alongside players like [[Damien Duff]] and [[Robbie Keane]]. After two years with [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], O'Brien was released on a free transfer. Incredibly, Italian giants [[Juventus]] offered 20-year-old O'Brien a five-year contract; however, he had trouble getting playing time on such a talented side and was loaned out to [[A.C. Lugano|Lugano]] of Switzerland, [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] of [[Scotland]], and lower league Italian sides [[F.C. Crotone|Crotone]] and [[Calcio Lecco 1912|Lecco]]. After several years of disappointment and three Inter-Toto Cup appearances, O'Brien was released from his contract with Juventus in 2002.
===MLS=== In search of consistent playing time, O'Brien, made the unconventional decision to move to America to join the Dallas Burn. O'Brien made an immediate impact, scoring on his debut for the club in a [[US Open Cup]] match. He finished the 2002 season with two goals and two assists in 11 games but had proven himself one of the more dynamic players on the team. O'Brien entered the 2003 season with great expectations, but these were cut short early in the season. In the Burn's third game of the season, a tackle from [[D.C. United]]'s [[Dema Kovalenko]] broke O'Brien's tibia, effectively ending his season. O'Brien returned to the team in 2004 and was one of the team's offensive leaders – he started 29 games, registering two goals and 10 assists, was named to the [[MLS Best XI]], and helped revitalise a Burn team that had recorded one of the league's worst records ever in the previous season.
In 2005, O'Brien repeated his Best XI form, finishing the year with six goals and 12 assists. During the 2006 season, O'Brien clashed with FC Dallas' head coach [[Colin Clarke (footballer born 1962)|Colin Clarke]] all season. His form was poor and he finished with only one goal in 27 games. At the conclusion of the season, O'Brien was traded to the expansion club [[Toronto FC]] with a gentlemen's agreement that Toronto FC would not draft any other FC Dallas players.
Due to a knee injury during a training session, which was later aggravated during a friendly match, O'Brien was limited to 13 games in the 2007 season.
In 2008, O'Brien was traded to the San Jose Earthquakes. In return, Toronto FC received San Jose's first round pick in the 2009 draft plus an undisclosed amount of money.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thestar.com/Sports/Soccer/article/307761 |title=TFC trades O'Brien to Earthquakes: Report |first=Morgan |last=Campbell |date=28 February 2008}}</ref> He made 28 appearances, scoring 4 goals (his 16th in the MLS). His 6 assists brought his MLS career assist total to 45 (from 142 total appearances).
Following O'Brien's strong performance and evident leadership in 2008, the San Jose Earthquakes stunned their fans by failing to pick up his contract option for the 2009 season. Instead, Earthquakes' GM John Doyle was hoping that he would accept a substantial pay cut. In January 2009, O'Brien made it known that he would not be returning to the [[San Jose Earthquakes]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centerlinesoccer.com/obrienim-definitely-not-coming-back/ |title=O'Brien: "I'm definitely not coming back" |first=Jeff |last=Carlisle |date=22 January 2009}}</ref> Without O'Brien's leadership and strong play, the Earthquakes struggled early in 2009. Despite a favourable schedule in which San Jose played five of their seven games at home, the Quakes managed just one win, leading many San Jose fans to call for O'Brien's return.
O'Brien keeps an off-season residence in Dallas and is an avid [[Dallas Mavericks]] fan. His profile page on the MLS site stated that he had retired.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/player/ronnie-obrien |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110427212529/http://www.mlssoccer.com/player/ronnie-obrien |archivedate=27 April 2011 |title=Ronnie O'Brien}}</ref>
He is now a coach of FC Dallas' youth teams.<ref>{{cite AV media |url=http://vimeo.com/10414889 |year=2010 |author=FC Dallas |title=Spring Break Youth Soccer Camp |type=Video}}</ref>
==International career== Despite having played multiple times for the Irish underage sides, O'Brien only received one callup to the senior side. [[Steve Staunton]] contacted Toronto FC about his availability for a short tour of the US in June 2007. However, O'Brien turned down the chance to play for his country again, as he had just returned from injury, while adding he was happy playing club football.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=433303&root=mls&&cc=5739 |title=O'Brien has no regrets about declining Irish invite |first=Doug |last=McIntyre |date=24 May 2007}}</ref>
==''Time'' magazine stunt==
In August 1999, e-mails circulated urging Irish people to vote for Ronnie O'Brien in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']]'s [[Person of the Century]] Internet poll, causing O'Brien to lead the poll, above those such as [[Albert Einstein]] and [[Martin Luther King]]. After the poll crashed due to attracting too much traffic, ''Time'' removed O'Brien from the running, restating the rule that "whimsical candidates will not be counted."<ref name="archives.tcm.ie">{{cite web |url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2003/04/06/story218107692.asp |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090301024355/http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2003/04/06/story218107692.asp |archivedate=1 March 2009 |title=Polling power of viral e-mails |date=6 April 2003 |first=Mark |last=Wrafter }}</ref>
==Honors==
===Individual=== MLS All-Star- 2004,05,06,07 *'''[[MLS Best XI]]:''' 2004 and 2005

revision.comment: +Category:Mortgage industry companies of the United States
revision.text:
The '''Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation''', also known as '''Farmer Mac''' ({{nyse|AGM}}), is a stockholder-owned, publicly traded company that was chartered by the United States federal government in 1988 to serve as a [[secondary market]] in agricultural loans such as [[mortgage loan|mortgages]] for agricultural real estate and rural housing. The company purchases loans from agricultural lenders, and sells instruments backed by those loans. The company also works with the [[United States Department of Agriculture]]. It is based in [[Washington, D.C.]]
It was created by the [[Agricultural Credit Act of 1987]] (P.L. 100-233) as a federally chartered, private corporation responsible for guaranteeing the timely repayment of principal and interest to investors in a new agricultural secondary market. The secondary market allows a lending institution to sell a qualified farm real estate loan to an agricultural mortgage marketing facility, or pooler, which packages these loans, and sells to investors securities that are backed by, or represent interests in, the pooled loans. Farmer Mac guarantees the timely repayment of principal and interest on these securities and, under authorities granted in 1995, can also serve as a loan pooler.
== See also ==
* [[Fannie Mae]] * [[Farm Credit System]] * [[Freddie Mac]] * [[Ginnie Mae]] * [[Sallie Mae]]
== External links ==
* [http://www.farmermac.com/ Farmer Mac home page]

6,143 tons full
363 tons dead |Ship length= {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]], 2 turbines, 35,000 hp (26 MW), 1 auxiliary motor 325 hp (242 kW), 1 shaft |Ship speed= {{convert|15|kn|km/h}} surfaced
{{convert|32|kn|km/h}} submerged |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth={{convert|290|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=12 Officers; 98 Enlisted |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} {{otherships|USS Groton}} '''USS ''Groton'' (SSN-694)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Groton, Connecticut]]. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 31 January 1971 and her keel was laid down on 3 August 1973. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 9 October 1976 sponsored by Mrs. Elliot L. Richardson, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 8 July 1978, with Commander R. William Vogel, III in command and Master Chief Petty Officer Joseph Pow as Chief of the Boat. ''Groton'' departed on its first overseas deployment in March 1980 to the Indian Ocean. The submarine made its way back to the homeport of Groton, CT by way of the Panama Canal. ''Groton'' completed the Around-the-World Cruise in October 1980. ''Groton'' was decommissioned and stricken from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] on 7 November 1997. Ex-''Groton'' is scheduled to enter the Nuclear Powered [[Ship and Submarine Recycling Program]] in [[Bremerton, Washington]]. == References == This article includes information collected from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] as well as various press releases and news stories. {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Groton (SSN-694)}} [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Connecticut-related ships]] [[Category:1976 ships]]

6,159 tons full
370 tons dead |Ship length= {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.7|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]], 2 turbines, 35,000 hp (26 MW), 1 auxiliary motor 325 hp (242 kW), 1 shaft |Ship speed= {{convert|15|kn|km/h}} surfaced
{{convert|32|kn|km/h}} submerged |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth=Greater than {{convert|400|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=12 Officers; 98 Enlisted |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, Mk 48-AdCap torpedoes, SubRoc anti-submarine rockets and Tomahawk cruise missiles. |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Birmingham'' (SSN-695)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 24 January 1972 and her keel was laid down on 26 April 1975. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 29 October 1977 sponsored by Mrs. Maryon Allen, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 16 December 1978, with Commander Paul L. Callahan in command. ''Birmingham'' was decommissioned and stricken from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] on 22 December 1997. Ex-''Birmingham'' is scheduled to enter the Nuclear Powered [[Ship and Submarine Recycling Program]] in [[Bremerton, Washington]]. == In fiction == Footage taken during the commissioning trials for the USS ''Birmingham'' was used in the film ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)|The Hunt for Red October]]''. The hull number (SSN-695) is easily readable on the submarine in the film. This denotes that the footage was taken during commissioning trials as the numbers are removed before active service. ==External links== {{Commons category|USS Birmingham (SSN-695)}} * [http://www.ssn695.org/ Official Web Site of the USS ''Birmingham'' SSN 695] * [http://forums.ssn695.org/ Discussion Site run by Crew Members of the USS "Birmingham" SSN 695] {{NVR}} {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birmingham (SSN-695)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Alabama-related ships]] [[Category:1977 ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]] {{US-submarine-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{otherships|USS Bremerton}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Bremerton SSN-698.jpg|300px|USS Bremerton (SSN-698)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag={{USN flag}} |Ship name=USS ''Bremerton'' |Ship namesake= [[Bremerton, Washington]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 24 January 1972 |Ship builder=[[General Dynamics Corporation]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=8 May 1976 |Ship launched=22 July 1978 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=28 March 1981 |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Pearl Harbor]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship status=[[The Oldest and Finest Submarine in the Fleet]] |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:USS Bremerton SSN-698 Crest.png|180px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= [[Los Angeles class submarine]] |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement= 5,789 tons light
6,159 tons full
370 tons dead |Ship length= {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.7|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × 21 in (533 mm) torpedo tubes |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Bremerton'' (SSN-698)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the second ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Bremerton, Washington]]. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 24 January 1972 and her keel was laid down on 8 May 1976. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 22 July 1978 sponsored by Mrs. [[Henry M. Jackson]], and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 28 March 1981 with Captain Thomas H. Anderson in command. On 11 March 1999, ''Bremerton'' used one torpedo to sink the derelict forebody of the merchant ship ''[[New Carissa]]'' off the [[Oregon]] coast. The [[USS David R. Ray (DD-971)|USS ''David R. Ray'']] also participated in the sinking.[http://www.seattlepi.com/archives/1999/9903120070.asp NEW CARISSA IS FINALLY BURIED AT SEA] After a successful Western Pacific deployment, in September 2003 ''Bremerton'' changed its homeport to [[Pearl Harbor, Hawaii]]. ''Bremerton'' spent two months in [[drydock]] at Pearl Harbor ending 21 January 2010.[http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20100127/GETPUBLISHED/1270388 Pearl Harbor Shipyard Undocks USS Bremerton] When {{USS|Los Angeles|SSN-688}} was decommissioned on 23 January 2010, ''Bremerton'' became the oldest commissioned submarine in the US fleet. On that day, [[Richard O'Kane]]'s [[cribbage]] board was transferred from ''Los Angeles'' to ''Bremerton'', a tradition that dates back to [[World War II]].{{cite news|publisher=Press-Telegram|title=USS Los Angeles Decommissioning|author=Steven Georges|date=23 January 2010|url=http://presstelegram.mycapture.com/mycapture/enlarge.asp?image=27658244&event=930342&CategoryID=28570}} The USS ''Bremerton'' is deployed with COMSUBPAC [http://www.csp.navy.mil/subssquadrons/bremerton/bremerton_homepage.shtml USS BREMERTON (SSN 698) COMSUBPAC] == References == {{Refimprove|date=April 2009}} {{reflist|30em}} [http://www.csp.navy.mil/subssquadrons/bremerton/bremerton_homepage.shtml USS BREMERTON (SSN 698) COMSUBPAC] This article includes information collected from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] as well as various press releases and news stories. {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bremerton (SSN-698)}} [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Washington (state)-related ships]] [[Category:1978 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] {{US-submarine-stub}}

{|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Jacksonville (SSN-699) alongside USS Hampton (SSN-767).jpg|300px|USS Jacksonville (SSN-699)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag|2008}} |Ship name=USS ''Jacksonville'' |Ship namesake= City of [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |Ship ordered=24 January 1972 |Ship builder=[[General Dynamics Electric Boat]] |Ship laid down=21 February 1976 |Ship launched=18 November 1978 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=16 May 1981 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship badge= [[File:USS Jacksonville SSN-699 Crest.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship displacement=5,720 tons light, 6,149 tons full, 429 tons dead |Ship length=110.3 meters (362 feet) |Ship beam=10 meters (33 feet) |Ship draught= |Ship draft=9.7 meters (32 feet) |Ship propulsion=One [[S6G reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= }} |} '''USS ''Jacksonville'' (SSN-699)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class]] [[attack submarine]], is the only ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. The ship is nicknamed "The Bold One". The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 24 January 1972 and her keel was laid down on 21 February 1976. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 18 November 1978 using the pontoon system designed for the launching of the Ohio Class Trident Submarines. The Jacksonville was sponsored by Mrs. Charles E. Bennett, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 16 May 1981, with Captain Robert B. Wilkinson in command.
''Jacksonville''’s operations have included a variety of fleet exercises and deployments including two around-the-world cruises in 1982 and 1985, deployments to the western [[Atlantic Ocean]] in 1983, 1986, 1993 and 1994, and deployments to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] in 1987 and 1993. In 1988, Jacksonville participated in a shock trials test program for Los Angeles class submarines, which was followed by a three-year major modernization overhaul in Norfolk Naval Shipyard.
''Jacksonville'' has been involved in several collisions with other vessels during her over 30 years of operation:
:(1) While outbound with the inbound Turkish merchant vessel ''General Z. Dogan'' in the vicinity of Norfolk, Virginia on 22 March 1982,<ref>http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/j/ssn-699/1982.pdf</ref>
:(2) with a barge positioned across [[Chesapeake Bay]]'s Thimble Shoal Channel, requiring the replacement of the submarine's sonar dome, on 21 September 1984,<ref>http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/j/ssn-699/1983-84.pdf</ref>
:(3) with the container ship ''Saudi Makkah'' near the mouth of the Chesapeake Bay, requiring repairs to the submarine's fairwater planes and rudder, on 17 May 1996,<ref>http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/j/ssn-699/1996.pdf</ref><ref>http://articles.dailypress.com/1996-05-18/news/9605180038_1_coast-guard-saudi-arabia-saudi-makkah</ref> and
:(4) with an unnamed fishing vessel while on regular patrol in the Persian Gulf on 10 January 2013. The ship's main periscope was sheared off in the collision.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hawaii-Based US Navy Sub Damaged in Persian Gulf |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2013/01/10/us/ap-us-submarine-periscope-damaged.html |newspaper=New York Times |location=Honolulu |date=10 January 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref>
On 20 December 2004 a small fire broke out aboard ''Jacksonville'' while she was undergoing a [[refueling overhaul]] at the [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]]. The fire was immediately extinguished and the reactor was never in danger, though a shipyard firefighter and a sailor were treated at the scene for [[smoke inhalation]].
== References == This article includes information collected from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] as well as various press releases and news stories. *[http://www.sublant.navy.mil/factsheets/jacksonville.pdf Sublant Fact sheet on the U.S.S. Jacksonville.]

{{otherships|USS Olympia}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image= [[Image:USS Olympia SSN-717.jpg|300px|USS Olympia (SSN-717)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag= {{USN flag|2009}} |Ship name=USS ''Olympia'' |Ship namesake= The City of [[Olympia, Washington]] |Ship awarded=15 September 1977 |Ship builder=[[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]], [[Newport News, Virginia]] |Ship laid down= 31 March 1981 |Ship launched= 30 April 1983 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 17 November 1984 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship homeport=[[Pearl Harbor]] |Ship motto=''Este Paratus''
("We Are Ready") |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship badge= [[Image:717insig.png|150px]] |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement={{convert|5763|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} surfaced
{{convert|6130|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} submerged
{{convert|6136730|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} dead |Ship length= {{convert|362|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|33|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= {{convert|32|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor]] |Ship range= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship armament=4 × {{convert|21|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Olympia'' (SSN-717)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the second ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Olympia, Washington]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 15 September 1977 and her keel was laid down on 31 March 1981. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 30 April 1983 sponsored by Mrs. Dorothy Williams, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 17 November 1984, with Captain William Hughes in command. In 1998, ''Olympia'' became the first Pacific-based submarine to pass through the Suez Canal in over 35 years. She is currently captained by Cdr. M.J.Boone. == References == *{{NVR}}, as well as various press releases and news stories. ==External links== {{Commons category|USS Olympia (SSN-717)}} * [http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN717.htm Naval Vessel Register entry for USS ''Olympia''] {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olympia (SSN-717)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Olympia, Washington]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Washington (state)-related ships]] [[Category:1983 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]]

{{otherships|USS Honolulu}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Honolulu (SSN-718) underway.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=USS ''Honolulu'', probably during [[sea trial]]s off the [[United States East Coast]] in 1984. }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag={{USN flag|2007}} |Ship name=USS ''Honolulu'' |Ship namesake= [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 15 September 1977 |Ship builder= [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding]], [[Newport News, Virginia]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 10 November 1981 |Ship launched= 24 September 1983 |Ship sponsor= Mrs. Joan B. Clark |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 6 July 1985 |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned=2 November 2007<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN718.htm |title=HONOLULU (SSN 718)}}</ref> |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= ''Maka `Ala Mau'' ([[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] for "Always On Alert") |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= [[Ship-Submarine recycling program|Disposed of by submarine recycling]] |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= [[File:USS Honolulu SSN-718 Crest.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= [[Los Angeles class submarine]] |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement= 5,700 tons light, 6,068 tons full, 368 tons dead |Ship length= {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × 21 in (533 mm) torpedo tubes |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Honolulu'' (SSN-718)''', was a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Honolulu, Hawaii]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 15 September 1977 and her keel was laid down on 10 November 1981. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 24 September 1983 sponsored by Mrs. Joan B. Clark, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 6 July 1985, with Commander Robert M. Mitchell in command.
[[Image:Polar bears near north pole.jpg|300px|left|thumb|Three [[polar bear]]s approach ''Honolulu''{{'}}s [[starboard]] [[Bow (ship)|bow]] while she is on the surface 280 nautical miles (519 kilometers) from the [[North Pole]].]]''Honolulu'' featured unique split stern planes that operated from independent hydraulic systems. With this redundant configuration, the inboard and outboard planes could be operated independently, preventing a failure of one or the other from causing an uncontrolled dive.
''Honolulu''’s patrols are commemorated by ten [[surfboard]]s signed by the crews aboard her at the time. The latest three are kept on board the submarine; the other seven are stored at [[Pearl Harbor]].
''Honolulu'' held a farewell ceremony in Pearl Harbor on 15 April 2006, that included remarks by Senator [[Daniel K. Inouye]], Lieutenant Governor [[James Aiona]], U.S. Pacific Fleet commander Admiral [[Gary Roughead]] and former ''Honolulu'' commanding officer Vice Admiral [[Jonathan Greenert]]. ''Honolulu'' put to sea in early May 2006 for her final patrol. Her last patrol ended at [[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] in October 2006 where she was placed on stand down, on her way to decommissioning.
==Final Deposition== ''Honolulu'' was [[Ship decommissioning|decommissioned]] and stricken from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] on 2 November 2007. Ex-''Honolulu'' entered the [[Nuclear Powered Ship and Submarine Recycling Program]] in [[Bremerton, Washington]].
The forward section of ex-''Honolulu'' was transferred to [[USS San Francisco (SSN-711)|USS ''San Francisco'' (SSN-711)]], repairing extensive damage caused by a severe grounding ''San Francisco'' experienced in 2005. The "challenging, one-of-a-kind project" was completed on 20 October 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=40390 |title=USS San Francisco Undocks With New Bow |date=20 October 2008}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}} {{DANFSNVR}}
