| Type = studio | Single 1 = Rocks on the Road | Single 1 date = 1991 | Single 2 = This Is Not Love | Single 2 date = 1991 | Single 3 = Still Loving You Tonight | Single 3 date = 1991 | Single 4 = Doctor to My Disease | Single 4 date = 1991 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r10372|tab=review|last=Eder|first=Bruce|label=''Catfish Rising''}} }} '''''Catfish Rising''''' is the 18th studio album by the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Rock music|rock]] group [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]], released in 1991. It is the first Tull album to feature keyboardist [[Andrew Giddings]]. ==Track listing== ===Vinyl edition=== {{tracklist | all_writing = [[Ian Anderson (musician)|Ian Anderson]] | headline = Side one | title1 = This Is Not Love | length1 = 3:56 | title2 = Occasional Demons | length2 =3:48 | title3 = Rocks on the Road | length3 = 5:30 | title4 = Thinking Round Corners | length4 = 3:31 | title5 = Still Loving You Tonight | length5 = 4:30 }} {{tracklist | headline = Side two | title1 = Doctor to My Disease | length1 = 4:34 | title2 = Like a Tall Thin Girl | length2 = 3:36 | title3 = Sparrow on the Schoolyard Wall | length3 = 5:21 | title4 = Roll Yer Own | length4 = 4:25 | title5 = Gold-Tipped Boots, Black Jacket and Tie | length5 = 3:38 }} {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = Bonus disc, side one | title1 = When Jesus Came to Play | length1 = 5:04 | title2 = Sleeping with the Dog | length2 = 4:25 }} {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = Bonus disc, side two | title1 = White Innocence | length1 = 7:43 }} ===CD edition=== {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | title1 = This Is Not Love | length1 = 3:57 | title2 = Occasional Demons | length2 = 3:49 | title3 = Roll Yer Own | length3 = 4:26 | title4 = Rocks on the Road | length4 = 5:32 | title5 = Sparrow on the Schoolyard Wall | length5 = 5:22 | title6 = Thinking Round Corners | length6 = 3:32 | title7 = Still Loving You Tonight | length7 = 4:32 | title8 = Doctor to My Disease | length8 = 4:35 | title9 = Like a Tall Thin Girl | length9 = 3:38 | title10 = White Innocence | length10 = 7:44 | title11 = Sleeping with the Dog | length11 = 4:26 | title12 = Gold-Tipped Boots, Black Jacket and Tie | length12 = 3:41 | title13 = When Jesus Came to Play | length13 = 5:05 }} {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = 2006 remaster bonus tracks | title14 = Night in the Wilderness | length14 = 4:06 | title15 = Jump Start | length15 = 7:49 | note15 = live; recorded at the Tower Theatre, Philadelphia, 25 November 1997 }} * "Night in the Wilderness" appeared as the B-side to many ''Catfish Rising'' -era singles. * The live version of "Jump Start" appeared as the B-side to several single releases of "This Is Not Love". ==Personnel== *[[Ian Anderson (musician)|Ian Anderson]] – vocals, acoustic and electric guitars, acoustic and electric mandolins, flute, percussion, keyboards, drums *[[Martin Barre]] – electric guitar *[[Dave Pegg]] – electric and acoustic bass guitars *[[Doane Perry]] – drums Also featuring: *[[Andrew Giddings|Andy Giddings]] – keyboards on tracks one, four and eight *[[Foss Patterson]] – keyboards on track 10 *[[John Bundrick]] – keyboards on track 11 *[[Matt Pegg]] – bass on tracks one, four and seven ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Jethro Tull}} [[Category:Jethro Tull albums]] [[Category:1991 albums]] [[Category:Chrysalis Records albums]]

<!-- This article is a part of [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft]]. Please see [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft/page content]] for recommended layout. --> {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name=R22 |image=Robinson 1172.jpg |caption=<!--image caption; if it isn't descriptive it should be left blank--> }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type=Light utility and [[trainer (aircraft)|trainer]] [[helicopter]] |manufacturer=[[Robinson Helicopter Company]] |designer=[[Frank D. Robinson]] |first flight=1975 |introduced=1979 |retired= |status= |primary user= |more users= |produced= |number built=over 4,484 (2012) |unit cost=$270,000 |variants with their own articles= |developed into = [[Robinson R44]] }} |}
The '''Robinson R22''' is a two-bladed, single-engine light utility [[helicopter]] manufactured by [[Robinson Helicopter]]. The two-seat R22 was designed in 1973 by [[Frank D. Robinson|Frank Robinson]] and has been in production since 1979.
The R22 has a suggested retail price of $270,000,<ref>{{cite web|title=R22 Pricelist|url=http://www.robinsonheli.com/price_lists_eocs/r22_pricelist.pdf|publisher=Robinson Helicopter Company|accessdate=4 April 2013}}</ref> and is valued from $40,000 on the second hand market.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robinson R22 Helicopters for Sale|url=http://www.globalaircraftmarket.com/en/helicopter/_/Robinson?family=R22|accessdate=4 April 2013}}</ref>
==Development== The majority of flight testing was performed at [[Zamperini Field]] in [[Torrance, California]]. Flight testing and certification was performed in the late 1970’s by test pilot [[Joseph John "Tym" Tymczyszyn]] and the R22 received FAA certification in March 1979. <ref>{{cite web|title= Aerospace Walk of Honor: "Tymczyszyn Bio"] |url= http://www.cityoflancasterca.org/Index.aspx?page=196#tym|accessdate=1 April 2014}}</ref> Due to relatively low acquisition and operating costs, the R22 has been popular as a primary rotorcraft trainer around the world and as a livestock management tool on large [[ranch]]es in [[North America]] and [[cattle station]]s in [[Australia]]. The R22 has a very low inertia rotor system and the control inputs are operated directly by push rods with no hydraulic assistance. Thus, the flight controls are very sensitive and require a light touch to avoid over correcting. A student that masters an R22 generally does not have a problem transitioning to a heavier helicopter. Due to the issues relating to a low inertia rotor-system and a teetering main rotor, operation by any pilot in the United States of the Robinson R22 or [[Robinson R44]] requires a special endorsement by a certified flight instructor.<ref>[http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=667dbf9e08b795564f0fc685a46bf054&rgn=div5&view=text&node=14:2.0.1.1.2&idno=14#14:2.0.1.1.2.0.1.1.7 SFAR No. 73 to Part 61 in the Federal Aviation Regulations]</ref> Tip weights were added to increase rotor inertia,<ref>http://www.unicopter.com/0385.html</ref> but the small rotor limits weight.<ref>Borrows, David A. [http://flighttraining.aopa.org/magazine/1998/March/199803_Features_Rotor_RPM_.html Rotor RPM] ''Flight Training'', March 1998. Accessed: February 2011.</ref>
==Design== [[Image:robinson.r22.g-cbxn.arp.jpg|thumb|right|Robinson R22 hovering]]
The R-22 is a light, two-place, single reciprocating-engined helicopter with a semi-rigid two-bladed main rotor and a two-bladed tail rotor. The main rotor has a teetering hinge and two coning hinges, the tail rotor has only a teetering hinge.
The normal production variant has skid landing gear. The Mariner version provided floats; wheeled gear is not available.
The basic structure is welded [[41xx steel|chromoly steel]] tubing. The forward fuselage is made of fiberglass and aluminum with a Plexiglas canopy. The tailcone, vertical and horizontal stabilizers are aluminum. It has an enclosed cabin with side-by-side seating for a pilot and passenger. The doors may be removed for flight, and are often done so for photographic flights, interior cooling in high temperatures, or a 10.4 lb weight saving.
The first version was produced as the R22, followed by the R22 HP, R22 Alpha, R22 Beta and R22 Beta II. Superficially, the aircraft appear similar. The R22 HP was fitted with a 160 [[horsepower#Brake horsepower|bhp]] Lycoming 0-320-B2C engine, an increase of {{convert|10|bhp|abbr=on}} over the original R22. The landing skid assembly on the R22 Alpha was modified by extending the rear struts, giving it a slightly nose-down attitude on the ground and better matching its attitude in a low altitude hover with two people on board. The R22 Beta added an engine speed governor (optional), rotor brake and auxiliary fuel tank (optional). The battery was moved from below the instrument cluster to the engine compartment for better balance. It has been offered as an instrument trainer version, with optional fixed floats as the R22 Mariner, and other special configurations for police work, electronic news gathering, and so on. The R22 Beta II added a Lycoming 0-360 engine, remade of lightweight materials and derated for sealevel operation. It allows greater altitudes for hovering in and out of ground effect (HIGE/HOGE). The R22 Beta II also made the engine speed governor standard and included a "carb heat assist" which correlates adding carb heat with decrease in collective control. Only the basic skid style is currently being sold. The R44 is available as the Clipper with floats, and as police and electronic news configurations.
===Controls=== [[Image:Robinson R22 Cockpit-001.jpg|thumb|The R22's cockpit, showing its unique "T-Bar" control.]]
Instead of floor-mounted cyclic sticks between the pilot's knees, the R22 uses a unique teetering "T-Bar" control connected to a stick that emerges from the console between the seats. This makes it easier for occupants to enter and exit the cabin and reduces chances for injury in the event of a hard landing. The teeter bar has a hand grip on both sides that hangs down between the pilots' legs. Thus, if teetered to the right, the right side pilot would be flying and the left grip would be about 12 inches above the left pilot's lap. R22 flight instructors quickly learn how to fly with their hand in the air. The left part of the bar, left collective control, and left tail rotor pedals can be removed if the left seat occupant is not certificated to fly the R22 or the space is needed for technical or observer duties. A floor-mounted foot activated push-to-talk switch facilitates intercom communications for the left seat occupant, although some later models may be equipped with a voice activated intercom system.
The [[helicopter rotor]] system consists of a two-bladed main rotor and two-bladed anti-torque rotor on the tail, each equipped with a teetering hinge. The main rotor is equipped with two coning hinges. Collective and cyclic pitch inputs to the main rotor are transmitted through pushrods and a conventional [[Swashplate (helicopter)|swashplate]] mechanism. Control inputs to the pre-coned tail rotor are transmitted through a single pushrod inside the aluminum tail cone.
To ease the pilot's workload, a mechanical throttle correlator adjusts the throttle as the [[collective pitch]] control is raised or lowered. The pilot only needs to make small adjustments by twisting the throttle grip on the collective throughout the flight regime. Later models are also equipped with an electronic [[governor (device)|governor]] which works to maintain RPM within normal operating limits (between 97 and 104% RPM); the governor is only active when the engine is running above 80% RPM, and is most effective in normal flight conditions. The governor can be switched on or off with a toggle switch located at the end of the pilot's collective pitch control; when the governor is not engaged, a yellow caution light glows on the instrument panel.<ref name="RTR 061">{{cite book | last =Robinson Helicopter Company | first = | coauthors = | title =R22 Pilot’s Operating Handbook and FAA Approved Rotorcraft Flight Manual | publisher = | date = 1996-10-22 | pages = 2–2, 7–17 }}</ref>
===Powerplant=== [[Image:Robinson R22 engine detail.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lycoming O-320]] mounted in a Robinson R-22 Beta]] [[File:Robinson R22 Helicopter hovering.jpg|thumb|The R22 is a simple and tight design]]
The R22 uses a horizontally mounted [[Lycoming O-320]] (O-360-J2A on the Beta II), [[four-cylinder]], [[air-cooled]], [[normally aspirated]], [[carburetor]]-equipped [[piston engine]]. It is fueled with 100LL grade aviation gasoline. Cooling is provided through a direct drive [[Centrifugal fan|squirrel-cage]] cooling fan. At sea level it is capable of producing more power than the transmission and rotor system can safely handle, and to ensure maximum engine and transmission life the O-360 must be [[derating|derated]], or operated at less than maximum power. As the air becomes thinner with increasing altitude, maximum available horse power decreases, reaching a point where the throttle can be completely open and rotor RPM is controlled by [[Collective pitch#Collective|collective]] position. By derating the engine at sea level, the R22 achieves acceptable high-altitude performance without use of [[supercharger|supercharging]] or [[turbocharger|turbocharging]], thus saving the weight, complexity, unreliability, and shortened engine life of a [[forced induction]] system.
A [[carburetor]] is used to provide the air-fuel mixture. Carbureted engines are susceptible to carburetor icing, a condition most likely to occur in conditions of low {{convert|11|C|F}} difference between the outside air temperature and [[dew point]] (the "dew point spread"), as well as visible signs of moisture in the atmosphere. Icing can lead to loss of engine power, and if not corrected total shutdown of the engine. A carburetor heat control is used to supply heated air to the carburetor from the exhaust muffler [[heat exchanger]]; this can prevent or cure icing, but also causes a reduction in engine power output because hot air is less dense, enriching the fuel-air mixture. The carburetor heat control is a simple plunger-type control mounted on the center console near the cyclic; pulling the control up slides a gate near the carburetor that admits warm air from a shroud surrounding the muffler. The R22 employs a carburetor air temperature gauge, marked to indicate temperatures conducive to icing. The Beta II version of the R22 also includes a "carburetor heat assist", which automatically applies carburetor heat when the [[Collective pitch#Collective|collective]] is lowered below a certain point. When icing conditions are present carburetor heat is required to prevent icing around the butterfly valve from the pressure drop at that point. As the carburetor air temperature (CAT) indicator does not read correctly below {{convert|18|in|cm}} of intake manifold air pressure, icing conditions require applying full carburetor heat below {{convert|18|in|cm}} of manifold pressure. A placard indicating this requirement is located on the CAT indicator and in the Pilot's Operating Handbook (POH).
Power is transmitted from the engine to the rotor system through [[Belt (mechanical)|drive belts]]. Originally, the R22 used four separate [[V-belt#Vee belts|v-belts]]. This system proved problematic, as belt length variations due to manufacturing tolerances caused some belts to overstress and break. As a temporary measure, in 1982, R22 operators received a kit from Robinson that was installed in the cockpit and clutch [[worm drive|worm-gear]] motor, isolating the tensioning circuits and locking the clutch/drive system at take-off tension. The problem was ultimately solved by replacing the four individual v-belts with two dual-v belts, running on matching multi-groove sheaves. The upper driven sheave is mounted on the tail rotor drive shaft next to a flexible coupling and is raised and lowered relative to the engine-mounted driving sheave by means of a small electric gear motor. During shutdown, the gear motor is used to lower the top sheave to loosen the drive belts. For startup, the engine is started with the belts loose, allowing the engine to run without spinning the rotor system. Immediately after engine start, the clutch switch located in the cockpit is closed by the pilot, powering the gear motor to slowly move the top sheave up to flight position, which tightens the belts. The gear motor is thereafter controlled by a pressure-sensing switch, automatically maintaining proper belt tension during flight as the belts warm up and stretch. The tail rotor drive shaft is also driven by the main transmission; the semi-conical gear box delivers power to the main rotor shaft through a pair of splash-lubricated [[spiral bevel gear]]s.
A [[sprag clutch]] is built into the center of the top sheave to allow the rotor system to continue to rotate in the event of engine failure, allowing the R22 to enter [[autorotation (helicopter)|autorotation]] and land in a controlled manner. Because the main rotor has very little mass and inertia, autorotation in an R22 requires careful and proper execution to assure a successful outcome. Much time is spent in training practicing various types of autorotation. Target speed in an autorotation is {{convert|65|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} and the glide ratio is approximately 4:1 in maximum-glide configuration.
== Transport == [[Image:R22-Trailered.jpg|thumb|right|Robinson R22 helicopter on 8 x 30-foot (2.4 x 9.1 m) trailer with a gross weight of {{Convert|3500|lb|kg}}.]] The two-bladed rotor and the small size of the R22 make it possible to transport the helicopter without blade folding or dismantling tasks. Transporting the R22 requires securing the tail boom and rotor blades to the truck or trailer bed,{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} which must be torsionally rigid to prevent motion and stresses being applied to the helicopter during transportation. It is possible to take off from and land directly onto a trailer.
==Variants== ;R22 :Initial production version powered by a Lycoming O-320-A2B or A2C piston engine. ;R22 HP :Higher-powered version, powered by a 160-bhp Lycoming 0-320-B2C piston engine. ;R22 Alpha :Improved version certified in 1983 powered by a Lycoming 0-320-B2C piston engine. ;{{visible anchor|R22 Beta}} :Fitted with a more powerful engine, powered by a Lycoming 0-320-B2C piston engine. ;R22 Beta II :Fitted with a more powerful engine, powered by a Lycoming O-360-J2A piston engine. ;R22 Beta II Police :Police patrol version, equipped with searchlight and loudspeaker. ;R22 Mariner :Designed for off-shore work, fitted with floats and wheels, Lycoming 0-320-B2C piston engine. Limited to daylight operations when fitted with floats. ;R22 Mariner II :Designed for off-shore work, fitted with floats and wheels, Lycoming O-360-J2A piston engine. Limited to daylight operations when fitted with floats. ;R22 Police :Police version. ;R22 IFR :Designed for IFR training with a larger 10-hole panel to accommodate additional instruments. Not IFR certified, so training must be done with a safety pilot in VFR conditions. ;[[#Unmanned derivatives|Maverick UAV]] :Unmanned military version marketed by Boeing ;[[#Unmanned derivatives|Renegade UAV]] :Unmanned R&D version built for DARPA
== Unmanned derivatives == The R22 is the basis for [[Boeing]]'s Maverick military [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] helicopter, and its Renegade version. In 1999, Frontier Systems developed a remotely piloted R22, the Maverick. This aircraft, along with the company, was later acquired by [[Boeing Phantom Works]]. In 2003 the [[United States Navy]] purchased four aircraft, equipped with Wescam EO/IR (Electro-Optical/Infrared) systems.<ref name=ds>[http://www.designation-systems.net/dusrm/app4/maverick.html Boeing Maverick at Designation Systems]</ref>
Boeing then modified one of the Mavericks further, calling it the Renegade, under contract with [[DARPA]] as a research testbed to develop software for its [[Boeing A160 Hummingbird|A160 Hummingbird]].<ref name=ds/> The software system, known as the Software Enabled Control (SEC) program, was developed by Boeing and teams from the [[University of California Berkeley]], [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and was first flown on May 26, 2005. During the flight, the SEC assumed control of the aircraft to "execute autonomous maneuvering algorithms".<ref name=boeing1>[http://www.boeing.com/phantom/news/2005/q2/nr_050621a.html Boeing Team Demonstrates Advanced Autonomous Flight Control for UAVs "Boeing Team Demonstrates Advanced Autonomous Flight Control for UAVs" Boeing news release, June 21, 2005]</ref> The software allows the aircraft to autonomously select "optimal routes through a field of pop-up and already-known threats; flying low-level, terrain-hugging profiles to avoid detection; and determining safe landing zones by using vision-based algorithms to process landing site imagery and terrain height information."<ref name=boeing2>[http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Boeing_Completes_Successful_Autonomous_Flight_Control_Technology_Program.html "Boeing Completes Successful Autonomous Flight Control Technology Program", ''Space Daily'', March 20, 2006]</ref>
==Operators== <!-- no need to list --> The R-22 is operated by many private individuals, companies and flying clubs. In Australia, where there are 489 R22s registered as of mid-2011, a survey found that 62% of the fleet's flying time was in [[Muster (livestock)|mustering]] operations, while 13% of hours were spent in training pilots. Many broadcasters used the R-22 until the mid-1990s when the financial landscape of radio broadcasting in the U.S. changed due to deregulation of the industry.<ref>{{cite journal |date=July–August 2011 |title=Stockhorse of the sky: the Robinson R22 |journal= Flight Safety Australia |issue= 81 |pages=14–15 |publisher=[[Civil Aviation Safety Authority]] |editor1-first=Margo |editor1-last=Marchbank |issn=1325-5002 |accessdate=7 August 2011 }}</ref>
===Military=== ;{{DOM}} * [[Dominican Republic Army]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.aeroflight.co.uk/waf/americas/dominican_rep/DomRep-arav-R22.htm|title=Dominican Rep. Army Aviation |publisher= |date=|accessdate=10 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.airliners.net/photo/0589681/|title= Robinson R-22 Beta II|publisher= |date=|accessdate=10 January 2013}}</ref> ;{{PHL}} * [[Philippine Navy]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philippinesdefence.com/philippine-navy/ |title= Philippine Navy |publisher= |date=|accessdate=10 January 2013}}</ref>
==Accidents and incidents== Since the R22 received FAA certification in March 1979, Robinson has delivered 4620 R22 helicopters. The R22 had 182 fatal accidents between March 1979 and June 2010 from a total of 1230 incidents. In late 1981, the R22 had its type certificate temporarily revoked by the Federal Aviation Administration due to delamination of a main rotor blade. The cause of the delamination was determined to be contamination of one of the bonded parts during a priming operation performed at an outside vendor. In response, Robinson Helicopter Company instituted stringent quality procedures and requirements, and replaced all main rotor blades on the fleet of 33 helicopters in service at the time.<ref>Krauss, Barbara. (1986, July/August). ''Robinson Helicopter: Number two and trying harder. Vertiflite, Volume 32'', p 24</ref>
In the early 1980s, the R22 experienced a number of student-pilot related accidents due the R22’s use as a primary flight trainer. Believing the number of accidents was the result of insufficient training and lax standards, Robinson established the Robinson Pilot Safety Course in 1982 to educate Certified Flight Instructors transitioning from larger helicopters to the new, smaller R22.<ref>Ells, Steven W. (2007, June 1) ''The highest standards: Robinson Helicopter aims for excellence. AOPA Pilot''.</ref> After the introduction of the Robinson Pilot Safety Course, the rate of fatal R22 accidents declined from 3.7 per 100,000 flight hours in 1983 to 0.97 per 100,000 flight hours for the 12 months preceding July 1995.<ref>Campbell, J.R. "Zoom". (1995, October) Witch hunt extraordinaire. ''US Aviator'' 8-16.</ref> Robinson’s statistics show the rate of fatal R22 accidents per 100,000 flight hours fell from 6.0 in 1982 to 0.7 in 1997.<ref>Robinson Helicopter Company. (2012, Spring). ''Robinson safety class turns thirty. Robinson News, Volume 18, Issue 1'', p. 3.</ref> To date more than 17,000 students have gone through the course.<ref>Moorman, Robert. (2013, May/June). ''The house that Frank built. Vertiflite, Volume 59'', p. 25</ref>

To add a new line, end the old one with a right parenthesis ")", and start a new fully formatted line beginning with * --> |crew=1 |capacity= |length main= 28 ft 8 in |length alt= 8.74 m |span main= 25 ft 2 in |span alt= 7.67 m |height main= 8 ft 11 in |height alt= 2.72 m |area main= 497 ft² |area alt= 46.2 m² |airfoil= |empty weight main= 796 lb |empty weight alt= 389 kg |loaded weight main= 920 lb |loaded weight alt= 417 kg |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main= 1,370 lb |max takeoff weight alt= 635 kg |more general= '''Main tank total capacity:''' 19.8 [[US gallon]]s (75 liters) * '''Main tank usable capacity:''' 19.2 US gallons (73 liters) * '''Optional aux tank total capacity:''' 10.9 US gallons (41 liters) * '''Optional aux tank usable capacity:''' 10.5 US gallons (40 liters) |engine (prop)=[[Lycoming O-320]]-A2B or -A2C |type of prop=flat 4 piston engine |number of props=1 |power main= 124 hp |power alt= 93 kW |power original= |max speed main= |max speed alt= 117 mph, 189 km/h, 102 kts |cruise speed main= 110 mph, 177 km/h, 96 kts |cruise speed alt= |never exceed speed main=117 mph, 189 km/h, 102 kts |never exceed speed alt= |range main= 240 mi |range alt= 386 km |ceiling main= 14,000 ft |ceiling alt= 4,267 m |climb rate main= 1,200 ft/min |climb rate alt= 6.1 m/s |loading main= 2.61 lb/ft² |loading alt= 13.7 kg/m² |thrust/weight=<!-- a unitless ratio --> |power/mass main= 0.095 hp/lb |power/mass alt= 0.147 kW/kg |more performance= * '''Endurance:''' approx. 2 hours, with 30-minute reserve |armament= |avionics=

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Thomas Russell Crampton | honorific_suffix = [[Institution of Civil Engineers|MICE]], [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers|MIMechE]] | image = Thomas Russell Crampton.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1816|08|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = Broadstairs, Thanet, Kent | death_date = {{Death date and age|1888|04|19|1816|08|06|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Westminster]] | other_names = | occupation = Railway Engineer | known_for = }} '''Thomas Russell Crampton''', [[Institution of Civil Engineers|MICE]], [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers|MIMechE]] (6 August 1816 – 19 April 1888) was an English engineer born at [[Broadstairs]], [[Kent]], and trained on [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel|Brunel's]] [[Great Western Railway]].
He is best known for designing the [[Crampton locomotive]] but had many engineering interests including the [[electric telegraph]] and the [[Channel Tunnel]] for which he designed a boring machine. His locomotives had much better success in France, Germany and Italy than they did in the UK.
==Personal life== Born to John and Mary Crampton of Prospect Cottage (in what is now Dickens Walk), Broadstairs, on 6 August 1816, Crampton was the son of a plumber and architect.<ref name=Life/> He was educated privately. Crampton married Louisa Martha Hall, who was a singer and a friend of [[Jenny Lind]], on 25 February 1841.<ref name=Tree>{{cite web | url = http://www.chapelhill.homeip.net/FamilyHistory/OurFamilyData/d0005/g0000593.htm#I07523| publisher = David Horton & Kerry Raymond| title = Louisa Martha HALL| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> They had 8 children, six boys and two girls. The eldest girl, Ada Sarah, died aged 4 on 16 February 1857.<ref name=Twig>{{cite web | url = http://www.chapelhill.homeip.net/FamilyHistory/OurFamilyData/d0003/g0000318.htm#I07530| publisher = David Horton & Kerry Raymond| title = Ada Sarah CRAMPTON| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and Crampton gifted a stained glass window in St. Peter's church, Broadstairs in her memory. Their youngest daughter, Louisa, was to marry [[Sir Horace Rumbold, 8th Baronet|Sir Horace Rumbold]], the Ambassador to the Netherlands.<ref name=Life/>
He died at his home, 19 Ashley Place, [[Westminster]] on 19 April 1888 and was buried in [[Kensal Green Cemetery]].<ref name=Life/>
==Career== Crampton entered a career in engineering, initially with [[Marc Brunel]] at the [[Great Western Railway]] (GWR) in [[Swindon]].<ref name=Life>{{cite web | url = http://web.archive.org/web/20121120211033/http://www.cramptontower.co.uk/broadstairs.htm | publisher = Crampton Tower Museum via archive.org| title = PRIVATE LIFE AND BROADSTAIRS| accessdate = 2013-07-09}}</ref><ref name=Index>{{cite web | url = http://www.steamindex.com/people/crampton.htm| publisher = Steam Index| title = Thomas Russell Crampton | accessdate = 2008-03-22}}</ref>
===Great Western Railway 1839-43=== On joining the GWR in 1839,<ref name=Tower>{{cite web | url = http://www.cramptontower.co.uk/about.htm| publisher = Crampton Tower Museum| title = LOCOMOTIVES| accessdate = 2008-03-22}}</ref> Crampton worked as assistant to Marc Brunel and then [[Daniel Gooch]]. Crampton was involved in the design of the [[GWR Firefly Class|"Firefly" class]] of locomotives.<ref name=Tower/> Gooch's aim was to produce [[broad gauge]] locomotives that were better than those on the [[standard gauge]] lines, thus proving the broad gauge system was the better technically. Crampton, unbeknown to the GWR, had the idea of improving standard gauge locomotives so that they could match those of the broad gauge. Crampton soon left the GWR.<ref name=Index/> In 1843, he left the GWR.<ref name=Tower/>
===Development 1844-51=== [[File:1846Cramptonloco.jpg|thumb|1846 Crampton locomotive]]Crampton realised that the locomotives of the GWR were better than the standard gauge locomotives for a number of reasons. The broad gauge allowed a larger [[boiler]] diameter and higher [[centre of gravity]] for the same stability. Broad gauge also allowed a bigger [[Firebox (steam engine)|firebox]] and heating area. Larger [[driving wheel]]s gave a lower piston speed, which allowed a higher speed for the locomotive before exhaust problems occurred.<ref name=Index/>
In 1843, Crampton took out a [[patent]] for a new design of [[Crampton locomotive|locomotive]]. It is for the physical appearance of his locomotives that Crampton is remembered for today, with the driving wheel placed behind the firebox. But there were technical improvements that he made, which laid the foundations for future locomotive design. The three most important improvements were:- wide steam passages, large heating surfaces and generous bearing surfaces on the wheels.<ref name=Index/>
From 1844 to 1848, Crampton was working for [[John Rennie the Younger|John]] and [[George Rennie (engineer)|George]] Rennie.
In 1845, Crampton received his first order for a locomotive built to his patent. The [[Namur (city)|Namur]] and [[Liège (city)|Liege]] Railway in Belgium ordered three locomotives with {{convert|7|ft|m|2}} diameter driving wheels and a {{convert|14.5|sqft|m2}} grate. They were built by the firm of [[Tulk and Ley]] of Whitehaven. One of the locomotives was tested in 1847 on the [[London and North Western Railway]], who then built a "Crampton Patent" locomotive at [[Crewe]]. Another two locomotives were bought by the LNWR, including a [[6-2-0]] ''Liverpool'' built by [[Bury, Curtis, and Kennedy]] in 1848 with {{convert|8|ft|m|2}} diameter driving wheels. A claim of {{convert|79|mph|km/h}} being achieved was made, with an average of {{convert|53|mph|km/h}} over {{convert|30|mi|km}} with a 60 ton load.<ref name=Index/> Another claim was for a speed of hauling eight carriages over {{convert|16|mi|km}} at an average speed of {{convert|74|mph|km/h}}.<ref name=Italy>{{cite web | url = http://www.webalice.it/alberto.pezzoli81/treni/Storia/CramptonEngerth.htm| publisher = webalice.it| title = La locomotiva dell'impresa: la Crampton| accessdate = 2008-03-22}}{{it}}</ref>
One locomotive Crampton designed had an indirect drive arrangement, with a crankshaft between the driving wheels. This locomotive had a [[2-2+2-2]] wheel arrangement.<ref name=Index/> In 1847, Crampton became a founder member of the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]], and in 1848, Crampton set up in business as a Civil Engineer in London.<ref name=Tower/> In 1850, a Crampton locomotive was exhibited at [[Birmingham]] which had balance weights on the driving wheels. This feature was commented upon by [[William Stroudley]].<ref name=Index/> In 1851, Crampton started the Broadstairs Gasworks, overseeing the construction and financing much of the works.<ref name=Life/>
===South Eastern Railway 1851-88=== [[File:Great Exhibition, No 136 Folkstone by HF Talbot, 1851.jpg|thumb|right|No. 136 ''Folkstone'' at [[The Great Exhibition]], 1851]] [[File:Crampton tower.jpg|thumb|Crampton's water tower, Broadstairs]]By 1851, Crampton was working for the [[South Eastern Railway (UK)|South Eastern Railway]] (SER). In that year, ten new [[Crampton locomotive]]s were built, and one of these, No.136 ''Folkstone'' was exhibited at [[The Great Exhibition]].<ref name=Percy>{{cite web | url = http://www.percywhitlock.org.uk/trains.htm| publisher = The Percy Whitlock Trust| title = The South Eastern and Chatham Railway and the London, Chatham and Dover Railway Amalgamated 1899 LOCOMOTIVES: Their Description, History, distinctive features and interest| accessdate = 2008-03-22}}</ref> In 1854, Crampton became a member of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] and in 1855 he was responsible for the building of the Berlin waterworks.<ref name=Science>{{cite web | url = http://www.scienceandsociety.co.uk/results.asp?image=10322977| publisher = The Science Museum| title = Thomas Russell Crampton, English engineer, c 1860s.| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} (a photo of Crampton is here)</ref> In 1856, Crampton was appointed to the [[Prussia]]n [[Order of the Red Eagle]].<ref name=Tower/> In 1859, Crampton formed the Broadstairs Water Company, building a water tower {{convert|80|ft|m|2}} high which now forms the Crampton Tower Museum. The water tower could hold {{convert|83000|impgal|l}} of water. Broadstairs Water Company was taken over by Broadstairs Urban District Council in 1901. In 1860, Crampton designed a tower for Holy Trinity church, Broadstairs, which [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]] had described as a "hideous temple of flint, a petrified haystack". Crampton donated a clock as a personal gift to the church. he also donated a [[wrought iron]] bridge which was built across Goodson Steps. This is the Louisa Gap bridge, named after his youngest daughter.<ref name=Life/> Crampton was elected Vice-President of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers in 1883.<ref name=Tower/>
===Peto, Betts and Crampton=== Crampton entered a partnersip with [[Peto and Betts|Sir Morton Peto and Edward Betts]] to undertake part of the construction of the [[London Chatham and Dover Railway]]. When the partnership became insolvent in 1867, Crampton was made personally bankrupt,<ref>''The Morning Post'', 23 July 1868.</ref> but, unlike Peto and Betts, managed to retain his good reputation and continue in business.
===Railway lines constructed=== Crampton was, wholly or partly, responsible for the railway lines built between [[Smyrna]] and [[Aidin]]; [[Varna]] and [[Rustchuk]]; [[Chatham Main Line|Strood and Dover]]; [[Maidstone East Line|Sevenoaks and Swanley]]; and [[Chatham Main Line|Herne Bay and Faversham]]. The latter three lines being built by the [[London, Chatham and Dover Railway]] (LCDR).<ref name=Tower/> Crampton was also the contractor, and later chairman of the [[East and West Junction Railway]]. A Crampton locomotive was used to haul the first train from [[Kineton]] to [[Fenny Compton]].<ref name=EWJR>{{cite web | url = http://www.andythompson.net/history.htm| publisher = Andy Thompson| title = History of the line| accessdate = 2008-03-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080607170113/http://www.andythompson.net/history.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-06-07}}</ref> Crampton was a partner in the [[Mont Cenis Pass Railway]]<ref name=Ransom>P. J. G. Ransom (1999), ''The Mont Cenis Fell Railway'', pp 30-32, [[Truro]]: [[Twelveheads Press]]</ref>
===Electric telegraph=== Crampton was responsible for the laying of the first international submarine cable in the world. This was laid in the [[Strait of Dover]] in 1851.<ref name=Index/> The first messages were carried on 13 November 1851 and the cable was in use until 1859.<ref name=Tower/>
The company behind the project was an Anglo-French undertaking, known as ''la Compagnie du télégraphe sous-marin'' in France and the ''Submarine Telegraph Company between France and England'' in Great Britain. Crampton was the engineer, and [[Charlton Wollaston]] was the electrician involved in laying the cable across the Channel. The [[South Eastern Railway (UK)|SER]] were another early user of the electric telegraph, and it was by use of the SERs wires that messages were able to be transmitted between Paris and London, being relayed from [[Dover]].<ref name=wire>{{cite web | url = http://distantwriting.co.uk/competitorsallies.aspx| publisher = Distant Writing| title = COMPETITORS AND ALLIES| accessdate = 2008-03-22}}</ref>
===Channel Tunnel=== Crampton designed an automatic hydraulic [[tunnel boring machine]], which was intended to be used in the construction of the [[Channel Tunnel]]. Modern drilling techniques were made possible by this invention.<ref name=Tower/>
==Family== Crampton's first wife died on 16 March 1875<ref name=Tree/> and he married Elizabeth Werge on 25 August 1881.<ref name=Trunk>{{cite web | url = http://www.chapelhill.homeip.net/FamilyHistory/OurFamilyData/d0003/g0000343.htm#I07518| publisher = David Horton & Kerry Raymond| title = Thomas Russell CRAMPTON| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> He left six sons and one daughter, who married [[Sir Horace Rumbold, 8th Baronet|Sir Horace Rumbold]], ambassador at Vienna.{{sfn|Seccombe|1901}}
==References== {{reflist}} ;Attribution {{cite DNB|wstitle=Crampton, Thomas Russell|supplement=1|first=Thomas|last= Seccombe}} ==Further reading== * ''On the advantages of constructing, ventilating and working, long railway tunnels with three separate openings''. T. R. Crampton, Clowes, 1883. 8 pp. * ''The Crampton locomotive in England''. P.C. Dewhurst. * ''British locomotive design,1825-1960''. Glover, G., London: Allen & Unwin, 1967 * ''Narrow gauge steam: its origins and world-wide development''. Ransom, P.J.G., Sparkford: OPC * ''Locomotives of the LNWR Southern Division: London & Birmingham Railway, London & North Western Railway and Wolverton Locomotive Works''. Jack, Harry, 2001 * ''Four main lines''. London: Allen & Unwin, Hamilton-Ellis, Cuthbert, 1950. 225pp.

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox political party | name_english = '''United Progressive Alliance''' | name_native = | colorcode = | party_logo = | leader = | foundation = 2004 | headquarters = | colors = | position = Centre-left | seats1_title = Seats in the [[Lok Sabha]] | seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|226|545|hex=#00FFFF}} | seats2_title = Seats in the [[Rajya Sabha]] | seats2 = {{Infobox political party/seats|86|245|hex=#00FFFF}} | Official color = | website = | country = India }} [[Image:Gandhisonia05052007.jpg|thumb|UPA chairperson [[Sonia Gandhi]].]] The '''United Progressive Alliance''' ('''UPA''') is a [[Coalition government|coalition]] of left political parties in India formed after the [[Indian general election, 2004|2004 general election]].[http://electionaffairs.com/parties/UPA.html United Progressive Alliance, UPA, UPA Performance General Election 2009, UPA Tally, UPA in Lok Sabha Elections 2009, India Elections 2009, General Elections, Election Manifest...] In the UPA is [[Indian National Congress]], whose president [[Sonia Gandhi]] is also the chairperson of the UPA. Subsequently the [[Prime Minister of India]], [[Manmohan Singh]], and the [[Council of Ministers of the Republic of India|Council of Ministers]] are drawn from members of the UPA. ==History== The UPA was formed soon after the [[Indian general election, 2004|2004 general elections]] when it had become clear that no party had won an absolute majority. The hitherto ruling [[Bharatiya Janata Party]]-led [[National Democratic Alliance (India)|National Democratic Alliance]] (NDA) had won 169 seats[http://www.hindu.com/2008/07/12/stories/2008071260391200.htm Small parties, independents in great demand]. in the 543-member [[14th Lok Sabha]], as opposed the UPA's tally of 222 seats. The [[Left Front (India)|Left Front]] with 59 MPs (excluding the [[speaker of the Lok Sabha]]), the [[Samajwadi Party]] with 39 MPs and the [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] with 19 MPs were other significant blocks that opted to support UPA at various phases of its rule.Originally the SP had [http://164.100.47.134/newls/membershomepage.aspx 39 MPs]{{dead link|date=May 2013}}. [http://www.rediff.com/news/2008/jul/25upavote1.htm 6 MPs defied party whip] and have been expelled from the party.[http://164.100.47.134/newls/membershomepage.aspx Lok Sabha members]{{dead link|date=May 2013}} The UPA did not enjoy a simple majority on its own in the parliament, rather it has relied on the external support to ensure that it enjoys the confidence of the Indian parliament similar to the formula adopted by the previous minority governments of the [[United Front (India)|United Front]], the NDA, the Congress government of [[P. V. Narasimha Rao]], and earlier governments of [[V. P. Singh]] and [[Chandra Shekhar]]. An informal alliance had existed prior to the elections as several of the current constituent parties had developed seat-sharing agreements in many states. However, it was only after the election that the results of negotiations between parties were announced. The UPA government's policies were initially guided by a [[common minimum programme]] that the alliance hammered out with fruitful consultations with [[Jyoti Basu]] and [[Harkishan Singh Surjeet]] of the 59-member Left Front.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/India/Congress_pins_hopes_on_Jyoti_Basu/articleshow/3228282.cms | work=The Times of India | title=Congress pins hopes on Jyoti Basu | deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=February 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Hence, government policies were generally perceived as centre-left, reflecting the [[Centrism|centrist]] policies of the INC. The congress party is today more closely aligned with the [[neoliberalism]], strongly advocates [[social democracy]] and [[social liberalism]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} During the tenure of [[Jharkhand]] Chief Minister [[Madhu Koda]], the constituents of the UPA were, by mutual consent, supporting his government.[http://www.rediff.com/news/2006/sep/14jhar5.htm Madhu Koda to be next Jharkhand CM]. Retrieved on 26 March 2007. UPA survived a vote of confidence in the parliament on 22 July 2008 after left parties withdrew their support. Support from the Samajwadi Party was significant in this.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}} In the Indian General Election in 2009, the UPA won 262 seats, of which the INC accounted for 206. Inclusive and populist policies along with a younger leadership has been credited for this.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/05/22/zakaria.indiaelections/ | work=CNN | title=Zakaria: Elections could mark India's debut as great power | accessdate=26 May 2010 | date=16 May 2009}} ==Past and present members of UPA== ===Current members=== * [[Indian National Congress]] | [[India]](206 MPs) * [[Nationalist Congress Party]] | [[Maharashtra]](9 MPs) * [[Rashtriya Lok Dal]] | [[Uttar Pradesh]] (5 MPs) * [[National Conference]] | [[Jammu & Kashmir]] (3 MPs) * [[Indian Union Muslim League]] | [[Kerala]] (3 MPs) * [[Kerala Congress (Mani)]] | [[Kerala]] (1 MP) * [[Sikkim Democratic Front]] | [[Sikkim]] (1 MP) * [[All India United Democratic Front]] (1 MP) * [[Jharkhand Mukti Morcha]] | [[Jharkhand]] (Alliance in Jharkhand State with Congress, but has not formally joined UPA) ===Outside support=== * [[Samajwadi Party]] | [[Uttar Pradesh]]: (22 MPs) * [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] | [[Uttar Pradesh]]: (21 MPs) * [[Rashtriya Janata Dal]] | [[Bihar]]: (3 MPs) The total is 276 MPs which is above the requisite 272 MPs to stay in power.[http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/how-numbers-stack-up-for-upa-with-and-without-mamata-banerjee-268950 How numbers stack up for UPA with and without Mamata Banerjee]. Retrieved on 18 September 2012. ===Former members=== * [[Telangana Rashtra Samithi]] * [[Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (Withdrew support on 19 March 2013) * [[Marumalarchi Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (joined the [[United National Progressive Alliance|Third Front, in March 2014 joined NDA]]) * [[Pattali Makkal Katchi]] (joined the [[United National Progressive Alliance|Third Front, in March 2014 joined NDA]]) * [[People's Democratic Party (India)|People's Democratic Party]] * [[Samajwadi Party]] gave outside support to UPA before 2009 General Elections, later (joined Fourth Front) * [[Rashtriya Janata Dal]] (joined the Fourth Front) * [[Lok Janshakti Party]] (joined the Fourth Front and in February 2014 joined NDA) * [[Republican Party of India (Athvale)]] (joined the [[National Democratic Alliance (India)|NDA]]) * [[Jharkhand Mukti Morcha]] (joined NDA and again moved to Congress.) * [[All India Trinamool Congress]] * [[Jharkhand Vikas Morcha]] * [[All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen]] ==Current members for Lok-Sabha 2009{{cite news|title=Manmohan gets presidential invite to form govt|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/manmohan-gets-presidential-invite-to-form-govt-3521|accessdate=9 May 2013|newspaper=NDTV|date=21 May 2009}}[http://ibnlive.in.com/news/smooth-sailing-for-upa-parties-scramble-to-support/92967-37.htm]{{dead link|date=May 2013}}== * [[Indian National Congress]] - 206 Seats * [[Nationalist Congress Party]] - 9 Seats * [[Rashtriya Lok Dal]] - 5 Seats{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2709331.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Ajit Singh's RLD joins UPA | date=12 December 2011}} * [[Jammu & Kashmir National Conference]] - 3 Seats * [[Indian Union Muslim League]] - 2 Seats * [[Kerala Congress (Mani)]] - 1 Seat ===Supporting parties for Lok-Sabha 2009=== * [[Samajwadi Party]] - 22 Seat * [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] - 21 Seats * [[Rashtriya Janata Dal]] - 2 Seats * [[Janata Dal (Secular)]] - 3 Seats * [[Bodoland People's Front]] - 1 Seats * [[Bahujan Vikas Aaghadi]] - 1 Seats * [[All India United Democratic Front]] - 1 Seats * [[Sikkim Democratic Front]] - 1 Seats ==Initial support== Initially, UPA was given external support from the Left Front which totalled 59 MPs. Similar external support was also promised by several smaller parties that were not a member of any coalition, including the Samajwadi Party with 39 MPs, the [[All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] party with 4 MPs, the [[Janata Dal (Secular)]] with 3 MPs, and [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] with 19 MPs, who promised to support the government if it faced a [[vote of confidence]]. Nevertheless, these parties were not a part of the government. The UPA thus [[2004 election#May 13: India|had at least 335 MPs]] out of 543 supporting it at the time of its formation. The Left parties, despite ideological differences with the Congress, supported the UPA to ensure a [[Secularism in India|secular government]]."[http://www.rediff.com/election/2004/may/13basu.htm Secular govt a priority: Basu]." Rediff Election Bureau 13 May 2004. Outside support is currently being offered by the [[All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] Party (9 MPs), the [[Bharatiya Navshakti Party]] (1 MP), the [[Jammu & Kashmir National Conference|National Conference]] (2 MPs)[http://www.ndtv.com/convergence/ndtv/story.aspx?id=NEWEN20080058175 Inching closer to vote, govt safe@272] NDTV and by the [[National Loktantrik Party]] (1 MP). In addition, rebel MPs from [[Biju Janata Dal]], the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]], the [[Janata Dal (United)]], and the independent MPs take the tally of UPA supporting MPs to 275.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/FullcoverageStoryPage.aspx?sectionName=&id=a78363f3-9f54-4f46-9da5-9fa0e4577ae8SinghisKing_Special&MatchID1=4735&TeamID1=8&TeamID2=6&MatchType1=1&SeriesID1=1194&PrimaryID=4735&Headline=Abstentions+and+cross-voting... Abstentions and cross-voting...]{{dead link|date=May 2013}}. Retrieved on 25 July 2008. ===Withdrawals=== ====Telangana Rashtra Samithi==== The [[Telangana Rashtra Samithi]] (TRS) was the first party to quit the alliance, first when its ministers quit the Andhra Pradesh government, and finally when an official withdrawal was done at the national level by its president [[K. Chandrashekar Rao]], who resigned his Lok Sabha seat.[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2006-09-23/india/27808570_1_upa-government-trs-telengana-rashtra-samithi TRS withdraws support to the UPA]. Retrieved on 26 March 2007. ====Marumalarchi Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam==== [[Marumalarchi Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (MDMK), began its drift when it tied up with the UPA's rival [[All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (AIADMK) during the Tamil Nadu elections, and on 16 March 2007 officially withdrew support from the government.[http://www.ndtv.com/morenews/showmorestory.asp?category=National&id=102231 Vaiko withdraws support]. Retrieved on 26 March 2007. ====Bahujan Samaj Party==== On 21 June 2008, the Bahujan Samaj Party, or the BSP, with 18 seats, announced withdrawal of its support after the Congress starting opposing the UP government where the BSP was the ruling party. Their leader Mayawati said that she wouldn' ====Left Front==== On 8 July 2008, [[Prakash Karat]], the general secretary of the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] (CPI (M)), announced that the Left Front would be withdrawing support over the decision by the government to go ahead with the [[Indo-US nuclear deal|Indo-U.S. nuclear deal]], a [[Section 123 Agreement]] with the United States.[http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/Left-pulls-out-will-meet-President-Patil-on-Wednesday/332876/ Left pulls out, will meet President Patil on Wednesday] ====People's Democratic Party==== On 4 January 2009, Mehbooba Mufti, president of the [[Jammu and Kashmir People's Democratic Party|People's Democratic Party]] announced the withdrawal of the PDP from the UPA given that the Congress had decided to support the [[Omar Abdullah]]-led [[Jammu & Kashmir National Conference|National Conference]] Government in [[Jammu & Kashmir]] after the [[Jammu and Kashmir state assembly elections, 2008|2008 state elections]].[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/pdp-withdraws-from-upa-unfortunate-says.../406523/ PDP withdraws from UPA], [[The Indian Express]]. 5 January 2009 ====Pattali Makkal Katchi==== On 26 March 2009,PMK declared that it would join the AIADMK led front and withdrew from the UPA and the party president declared that two union ministers of his party will resign shortly. ====All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen==== On 12 November 2012, Barrister [[Asaduddin Owaisi]], leader of the [[All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen|AIMIM]] announced the decision of the party's executive and declared that his party would now go after the state government for its "communal" and "anti-people" policies. Addressing a news conference, Owaisi said his party was compelled to take the decision due to "the communal behaviour of [[Kiran Kumar Reddy]]'s government in [[Andhra Pradesh]]". Giving a detailed account of communal riots in the state and Hyderabad since 2010, he alleged that the Congress government not only turned a blind eye to MIM's demands to withdraw cases against innocent Muslims and take action against the guilty but pandered to the [[Sangh Parivar]]. The MIM's decision came after the government allegedly allowed construction of a canopy over a temple abutting the historic [[Charminar]] in alleged violation of court orders to maintain status quo. Owaisi criticised the chief minister for ignoring the high court order to maintain status quo.[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/majlis-e-ittehadul-muslimeen-withdraws-support-to-andhra-pradesh-government-and-upa/articleshow/17201214.cms Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen withdraws support to Andhra Pradesh government and UPA - Economic Times][http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_mim-withdraws-support-to-upa-congress-in-andhra-pradesh_1763647 MIM withdraws support to UPA, Congress in Andhra Pradesh - India - DNA] ====Trinamool Congress==== On 18 September 2012, [[All India Trinamool Congress|TMC]] Chief, [[Mamata Banerjee]], announced her decision to withdraw support to the UPA after the TMC's demands of rollback of reforms including [[Foreign direct investment|FDI]] in retail, increase in the price of diesel and limiting the number of subsidised cooking gas cylinders for households, were not met.{{cite web|title=Rupee falls after TMC pulls out from government|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/wire-news/rupee-falls-after-tmc-pulls-outgovernment_759751.html|publisher=Monetcontrol.com|accessdate=20 September 2012}}{{cite web|title=Mamata's party ready to meet President tomorrow to officially quit UPA|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/24-hours-for-mamata-banerjee-s-ministers-to-resign-will-upa-really-be-didi-less-269851|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=20 September 2012}} ====Jharkhand Vikas Morcha==== On 1 October 2012 the Jharkhand Vikas Morcha, led by Babulal Marandi, withdrew the support of its two MPs to the UPA government. The JVM was part of the UPA. Though this did not impact the stability of the government, the JVM's withdrawal of support came two weeks after a major UPA ally, the Trinamool Congress, pulled out of the alliance. The reason for JVM's withdrawal was the same as the Trinamool's; against the decision to implement 51% FDI in Retail Businesses and the Hike in Diesel Prices.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} ====Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam==== On 17 October 2012 14 DMK MPs, including central ministers [[T.R. Baalu]] and [[A. Raja]] were forced to hand in their post-dated resignation letters to the head of the party, due to Spectrum corruption Scandal. The party leader M. K. Karunanithi's daughter Kanimozhi executed the 2G scandal with then Information Technology minister Andimuthu Raja and caused billions of rupees of loss to Government of India. During the investigation, they found a huge sum of money has been exchanged to DMK party leader Karunanithi's wives' TV channel. The UPA alliance, particularly Congress, has lost its confidence among the people of India due to several corruption charges.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} The DMK pulled out of the UPA government on 19 March 2013 over the issue of a draft resolution at the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] of the alleged human rights' violations of Sri Lankan Tamils.[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-19/india/37843259_1_dmk-chief-karunanidhi-sri-lankan-tamils-humanitarian-law-and-crime DMK pulls out of UPA govt over Sri Lanka Tamils issue - Times Of India] ==Past general election alliances of Congress (before 2004)== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Election Year ! Prime Minister Candidate ! Parties |- |[[Indian general election, 1977|1977]] |[[Indira Gandhi]] |[[Indian National Congress (Indira)]]

Narasimha Rao]] |[[Indian National Congress|INC]] |- |[[Indian general election, 1998|1998]] |None |[[Indian National Congress]]
[[Kerala Congress (Mani)]] |- |[[Indian general election, 1999|1999]] |None |[[Indian National Congress (Indira)]]

[[United Democratic Front (India)|United Democratic Front]]
|- |} ==Controversies== During the discussion for the vote of confidence,{{Which|date=January 2013}}{{When|date=January 2013}} BJP MPs produced cash in the parliament, as viewed on [[Lok Sabha TV]], alleging a bribe by the Samajwadi Party to vote for the government. The BJP claimed to have documentary evidence in a "cash for vote" scam and submitted a report before the parliamentary committee probing the matter.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} The BJP also wrote a 17-page letter to the Parliamentary committee headed by Congress member V Kishore Chandradeo in this regard. [[Arun Jaitley]] said Samajwadi MP [[Reoti Raman Singh]] had offered his party's MPs the cash on the night of 21 July.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} He also alleged that SP leader [[Amar Singh (politician)|Amar Singh]] was behind the entire episode. Jaitley said: "The investigating agencies did not do their job. So we inquired into the matter and gathered documentary evidence in the case." He alleged the 'cash for vote' scam reflected the subversion of the Indian Parliament, as well as a section of the media.[http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/We-have-documentary-proof-of-cash-for-vote-scam-BJP/344093/ We have documentary proof of 'cash for vote' scam: BJP - Express India] The winter session of parliament in October 2008 came under intense criticism from the Left parties and the BJP to demand a full fledged winter session instead of what was seen as the UPA to having "scuttled the voice of Parliament" by bringing down the sittings to a record low of 30 days in the year. The tensions between the UPA and the opposition parties became evident at an all-party meeting convened by [[Lok sabha speaker|Lok Sabha speaker]] [[Somnath Chatterjee]] when the leader of opposition, [[LK Advani]] questioned the status, timing and schedule of the current session of parliament.[http://www.financialexpress.com/news/Left-joins-BJP-to-sing-chorus-against-UPA/374896/ Left joins BJP to sing chorus against UPA] Karunanidhi had said he felt "let down" by the "lukewarm" response of the Centre and had demanded amendments in the resolution on Sri Lanka. One of the amendments was to "declare that [[genocide]] and [[war crime]]s had been committed and inflicted on the [[Eelam Tamils]] by the [[Sri Lankan Army]] and the administrators". The second one was "establishment of a credible and independent international commission of investigation in a time-bound manner into the allegations of war crimes, [[crimes against humanity]], violations of international [[human rights law]], violations of [[international humanitarian law]] and crime of genocide against the Tamils". Karunanidhi said Parliament should adopt the resolution incorporating these two amendments. The UPA has also been criticised for its alleged involvement in a number of scams such as the [[CWG scam|Commonwealth Games Scam]] of 2010, the [[2G scam]], and the [[Coalgate scam]]. ==See also== * [[National Democratic Alliance (India)]] * [[Coalition government]] * [[National Advisory Council]] * [[Third Front (India)]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://pmindia.nic.in/cmp.pdf Common Minimum Programme of the UPA.] *Arora, Balveer and Tawa Lama Rewal, Stéphanie. [http://samaj.revues.org/index2845.html ''"Introduction: Contextualizing and Interpreting the 15th Lok Sabha Elections"'']. ''South Asia Multidisciplinary Academic Journal'', 3, 2009 {{Indian political parties}} [[Category:Political parties in India]] [[Category:Coalition governments of India]] [[Category:Coalitions of parties in India]] [[Category:Manmohan Singh administration]]

'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=17 officers, 134 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors=BQQ-5 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Oklahoma City'' (SSN-723)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, is the second ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]. The contract to build it was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 13 August 1981 and its keel was laid down on 4 January 1984. It was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 2 November 1985 sponsored by Mrs. Linda M. Nickles, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 9 July 1988, with [[Commander]] Kevin John Reardon in command. In 1991, ''Oklahoma City'' won the [[Marjorie Sterrett Battleship Fund Award]] for the Atlantic Fleet. On 13 November 2002, ''Oklahoma City'' collided with the [[Leif Hoegh]] [[liquified natural gas]] tanker ''Norman Lady'', east of the [[Strait of Gibraltar]]. No one on either vessel was hurt, and there were no leaks of oil from fuel tanks and no threat to the environment, but the submarine sustained damage to its [[periscope]] and sail area, and put into [[La Maddalena]], Sardinia, for repairs. Its commanding officer, Commander Richard Voter, was relieved of his command on 30 November. One other officer and two enlisted crew members also were disciplined for alleged dereliction of duty. On 20 January 2005 ''Oklahoma City'' returned to [[Norfolk, Virginia]], after a six-month deployment in support of national security interests and the [[War on Terrorism]]. ''OKC'' transited to its patrol area in the Pacific Ocean via the Arctic Ocean, the first such transit for a first-flight {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}. After the patrol, it then completed a circumnavigation of North America by transiting back to the Atlantic Ocean through the [[Panama Canal]] and returning to its homeport in Norfolk. In early 2007, ''Oklahoma City'' became the first submarine certified to exclusively use [[Digital Nautical Chart]]s (DNCs), using the [[Voyage Management System]] (VMS). VMS is part of the [[Electronic Chart Display and Information System-Navy]] (ECDIS-N) system, which has been under development since 1990. The shift from traditional paper navigation to an all-electronic navigation suite marked the first significant shift in U.S. Navy navigation practices since the introduction of the [[Global Positioning System]] (GPS) in the 1990s. From May to November 2007, ''Oklahoma City'' completed a deployment to the [[Persian Gulf]] in support of the [[War on Terror]]. It spent May to July 2008 in the Eastern Pacific in support of the [[War on Drugs]], and was responsible for seizing more than 11 [[metric ton]]s of [[cocaine]] valued at more than $1.5 billion (USD). ''Oklahoma City'' was awarded the 2008 Squadron Eight Battle "E". On 22 November 2008, Commander Aaron M. Thieme relieved Commander Louis Edward Mayer IV as [[Commanding Officer]]. After a 26-month overhaul, in March 2011 the sub was forward deployed to Guam.Matthews, Laura, "[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2011/03/gannett-navy-oklahoma-city-arrives-at-guam-030311/ Sub Oklahoma City arrives at Navy Base Guam]", ''[[Military Times]]'', 3 March 2011, retrieved 4 March 2011. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{DANFSNVR}} {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oklahoma City (SSN-723)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States submarine accidents]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 2002]] [[Category:United States Navy Oklahoma-related ships]] [[Category:1985 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]]

{{Other ships|USS Chicago}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Chicago (SSN-721) returns from Desert Storm.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=USS ''Chicago'' returning from Desert Storm }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag}} |Ship name=''Chicago'' |Ship namesake= The City of [[Chicago, Illinois]] |Ship ordered=13 August 1981 |Ship builder=[[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]], [[Newport News, Virginia]] |Ship laid down=5 January 1983 |Ship launched=13 October 1984 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=27 September 1986[http://www.csp.navy.mil/css3/721.htm USS Chicago (SSN 721)] |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship homeport=[[Joint Region Marianas|Apra Harbor, Guam]] |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honors= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship badge=[[File:USS Chicago SSN-721 Crest.png|150px]] |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement=5759 tons light,
6162 tons full,
403 tons dead |Ship length={{convert|362|ft|0|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|33|ft|0|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|31|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=one [[S6G reactor]] |Ship speed='''Surfaced:'''{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}}
'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship sensors=BQQ-5 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 12x [[Vertical Launching System]] tubes, 27 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= |Ship motto=''We Will''http://www.dodmedia.osd.mil/Assets/Still/1986/Army/DA-SC-86-04657.JPEG }} |} '''USS ''Chicago'' (SSN-721)''' is a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class]] [[submarine]], the fourth ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for the city of [[Chicago, Illinois]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 13 August 1981 and her keel was laid down on 5 January 1983. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 13 October 1984 sponsored by Mrs. Vicki Ann Paisley, wife of [[Melvyn R. Paisley]] assistant [[United States Secretary of the Navy|Secretary of the Navy]], and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 27 September 1986, with Commander Robert Avery in command. ==Ship's History== Early in 1996, an [[RQ-1 Predator]] aerial reconnaissance drone was successfully controlled from ''Chicago''. The drone reached altitudes up to 6000 meters (20,000 ft) and ranged up to 185 kilometers (100 [[nautical mile|nmi.]]) from the submarine, which was operating at periscope depth. In the summer of 2005, ''Chicago'' tested the [[Virtual Periscope]], a system that would allow submerged submarines to observe the surface above them without having to come to a shallower depth, as is required by traditional [[periscope]]s. A small camera mounted on the sail of the submarine uses the surface of the ocean as a [[lens (optics)|lens]], collecting light from above the surface and refracting it below. High-speed signal processing software assembles an image of what is on the surface. The system's resolution does not allow ship identification, only indicating that something is on the surface. Objects 30 meters (100 feet) tall can be seen at about a distance of 1600 meters (one mile). Sufficient light is available when a camera is shallower than 30 to 60 meters (100 to 200 feet). On 15 March 2010 the sub's Captain, Commander Jeff Cima, was relieved of command after facing an [[nonjudicial punishment|Admirals's Mast]]. The mast found that Cima had been drunk and had acted in an "unbecoming" manner during a visit with NROTC midshipmen at [[Cornell University]] on 10 March 2010. Cima was temporarily replaced by Captain James Horten.{{Cite news | last = Kakesako | first = Gregg | title = Fired skipper was drinking with cadets | newspaper = Honolulu Star-Bulletin | date = 19 March 2010 | url = http://www.starbulletin.com/news/20100319_Fired_skipper_was_drinking_with_cadets.html | accessdate = }} After completing a two-year maintenance and upgrade period at [[Pearl Harbor]] Naval Shipyard in October 2011, ''Chicago'' arrived in April 2012 at her new homeport, assigned to [[Submarine Squadron 15]], based at [[Joint Region Marianas]] on the island of [[Guam]].{{cite web|title=Guam Welcomes USS Chicago|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=66766|publisher=United States Navy|accessdate=21 June 2012}} The current commanding officer of the USS Chicago is CDR Lance Thompson. ==Awards== The USS ''Chicago'' has earned multiple awards in its service life. Chicago has been awarded many unit awards, including the [[Navy Unit Commendation]], three [[Meritorious Unit Commendation]]s and four [[Navy "E" Ribbon]] Submarine Squadron Battle 'E's. Further, the ''Chicago'' has been awarded several campaign and service awards, including the [[Navy Expeditionary Medal]], [[National Defense Medal]], [[Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal]], two [[Southwest Asia Service Medal]]s, three [[Sea Service Ribbon]]s, [[Kuwait Liberation Medal (Saudi Arabia)]],and the [[Kuwait Liberation Medal (Kuwait)]] Further, one of the barracks buildings at [[Recruit Training Command]] is named after the ''Chicago''. ==In Fiction== USS ''Chicago'' plays a prominent role in [[Tom Clancy]]'s novel ''[[Red Storm Rising]]''. USS ''Chicago'' is seen deploying elements of Task Force 141 in the ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2]]'' mission "The Only Easy Day... Was Yesterday". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Chicago (Submarine (nuclear-powered) : SSN-721), and Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company. ''Chicago Launching of SSN721, October 13 1984.'' Newport News, Va: Newport News Shipbuilding, Tenneco Co, 1984. {{OCLC|690001032}} * Chicago (Submarine (nuclear-powered) : SSN-721). ''Welcome Aboard, USS Chicago SSN 721.'' United States: s.n, 1993. {{OCLC|689994981}} * Genat, Robin and Genat, Robert. Modern U.S. Naval Submarines. Osceola, WI: MBI Publishing Company, 1997. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.csp.navy.mil/ Commander Submarine Force, U.S. Pacific Fleet] * [http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN721.htm USS Chicago, Naval Vessel Register] * [http://www.chicago721club.org/ 721 Club - Civilian Support Organization for the Crew of SSN 721] {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chicago (Ssn-721)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Illinois-related ships]] [[Category:1984 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]]
