{{otherships|USS Key West}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{lead missing|date=January 2009}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Key West SSN-722.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=USS ''Key West'' (SSN-722) entering [[Pearl Harbor]] }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag|1987}} |Ship name=USS ''Key West'' |Ship namesake= The city of [[Key West, Florida]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Northrop Grumman Newport News|NGNN]] |Ship laid down=6 July 1983 |Ship launched=20 July 1985 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=12 September 1987 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship badge= [[File:USS Key West SSN-772 Crest.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement=5799 [[ton]]s light, 6206 tons full, 407 tons dead |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=1×[[S6G reactor]] |Ship speed='''Surfaced:'''{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}}
'''Submerged:''' In excess of {{convert|25|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= In excess of {{convert|800|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=16 officers, 127 enlisted |Ship sensors=BQQ-10 ARCI passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 high frequency active SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) midships torpedo tubes, 12 x bow vertical launch tubes (for BGM-109 Tomahawks), up to 25 horizontal reloads (combination of [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] or [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}), mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Key West'' (SSN-722)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Key West, Florida]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 13 August 1981 and her keel was laid down on 6 July 1983. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 20 July 1985 sponsored by Mrs. Virginia Conn, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 12 September 1987 with Commander Warren Lipscomb, Jr. in command. She is the fourth [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles'' - class submarine]] equipped with the vertical launch system (VLS) capable of carrying 12 Tomahawk land attack cruise missiles ([[TLAM]]). USS ''Key West'' was home ported at the [[Norfolk Naval Base]], [[Norfolk, VA]]. She operated out of Norfolk, VA until 1995. During her [[United States Atlantic Fleet|Atlantic Fleet]] service, she completed numerous [[Cold War]] deployments and supported operations in the Caribbean, Western Atlantic and Mediterranean. USS ''Key West'' was awarded the "Hook-em" antisubmarine warfare (ASW) excellence award following her 1990 Mediterranean Cruise. She later was awarded the Meritorious Unit Commendation Award for her superior performance in Cold War operations during the 1989 and 1990 deployments. USS ''Key West'' won the "TOP TORP" Torpedo Shooting Competition in 1992 and was later awarded the Submarine Squadron Eight [[Battle E|Battle "E"]] for that year. The USS ''Key West'' deployed with the [[USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71)|''Theodore Roosevelt'']] Carrier Battle Group in 1995. During that deployment she operated in the Mediterranean Sea and Persian Gulf and was awarded the [[Navy Unit Commendation]], [[Armed Forces Service Medal|Armed Forces Service]], and [[NATO Medal|NATO Service]] medals. Following the 1995 deployment, USS ''Key West'' underwent an availability in Norfolk, VA in preparation for her transfer to the [[United States Pacific Fleet|Pacific Fleet]] in 1996. She departed Norfolk in June 1996 and transited the [[Panama Canal]] as part of her transfer to the Pacific Fleet. She arrived in [[Pearl Harbor, Hawaii]] in July 1996 and began operations under Submarine Squadron One. The USS ''Key West'' visited her name sake city in 1987 for a week long celebration after commissioning, in 1992 and later in 1994. Since reassignment to the Pacific Fleet she has not been able to visit [[Key West, Florida]] again. [[Image:Periscope Depth.jpg|thumb|left|''' ''Key West'' ''' at periscope depth, [[RIMPAC]] 2004.]] In April 1997, USS ''Key West'' conducted her first Pacific deployment with the [[USS Constellation (CV-64)|''Constellation'']] Carrier Battle Group. During this deployment, she operated in the [[Pacific Ocean]], [[Indian Ocean]] and the [[Persian Gulf]]. Later that year, USS ''Key West'' was reassigned to Submarine Squadron Three. In the next year, she deployed to the Eastern Pacific in support of the [[USS Carl Vinson (CVN-70)|''Carl Vinson'']] and [[USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72)|''Abraham Lincoln'']] Carrier Battle Groups, and later supported the 1998 Rim of the Pacific (RIMPAC) exercise. From 1998 through 2001 she supported Pacific theater operations in both the [[United States Third Fleet|Third Fleet]] and [[United States Seventh Fleet|Seventh Fleet]] area of operations. During this time she participated in numerous bilateral and multilateral exercises with our Pacific Theater partner. Following the [[11 September attacks]], she was redirected Bahrain to the Northern Arabian Sea where she launched Tomahawk Land Attack Cruise Missiles against Afghanistan in October 2001.SSN 722 at [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/navy/ssn-722.htm Global Security] In 2003,{{cite news | last = Cole | first = William | coauthors = | title = Hawai'i submarines play key role in war with Iraq | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 3 April 2003 | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2003/Apr/01/ln/ln05a.html | accessdate = }} 2005{{cite news | last = Rush | first = David | coauthors = | title = USS Key West returns from Western Pacific deployment | publisher = COMSUBPAC Public Affairs | date = 15 November 2005 | url = http://www.csp.navy.mil/news/rel05080.html | accessdate = }} and 2007 {{cite web | last = Hight | first = Michael | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Key West Returns from Deployment | work = NNS070829-11 | publisher = USN | date = 2007-08-29 | url = http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=31556 | format = | doi = | accessdate = April 2008}} USS ''Key West'' conducted deployments to the Western Pacific in support of Seventh Fleet operations. In 2007 USS ''Key West'' was named "Battle E" for COMSUBRON THREE, given to the best submarine in its squadron, awarded the Arleigh Burke Trophy for the most improved sea command in the Pacific, and awarded the Naval Unit Commendation for its outstanding accomplishments during the deployment. In 2009 USS ''Key West'' was again awarded the "Battle E" award for COMSUBRON Three for outstanding performance during the 2009 WESTPAC deployment. In 2012 USS ''Key West'' shifted home port to Naval Base Guam to support Seventh Fleet operations as a forward deployed unit.{{cite web|last=Price|first=Jeffrey|title=USS Key West Arrives in Guam|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=70626|publisher=United States Navy|accessdate=28 January 2013}} ==Command Emblem== [[Image:722insig.png|right|150px]] The [[conch]] shell is the focal point of the submarine's emblem for the fabled horn of the Greek God [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]] and the symbol of the submarine's namesake city. The USS ''Key West'' is emerging from the shell which symbolizes the emergence of the city as the leading city of the Florida Keys. The submarine insignia symbolizes the heritage that the ship has with all past and future submarines. The motto "Liberate Clavis Tenacitas et Ingenium" translates to "The Key to Freedom is Tenacity and Resourcefulness." Specifically, the phrase "The Key to Freedom" represents the namesake city and the submarine's mission to protect the fundamental rights and liberties of the American people.Symbolism of the USS Key West Crest. [http://www.ssn722.navy.mil/sub.htm USS Key West Information] FT1/SS Glenn W. Kemmerer The phrase "Tenacity and Resourcefulness" was used by the Mayor of Key West during his speech at the ship's launching to describe the characteristics of a true Conch —a native of Key West. Additionally, "Ingenium" is a word used by the ancient Greek and Roman historians to describe the resourcefulness and ingenuity of sailors in the period. {{cite web | last = Mackail | first = J.W. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Select Epigrams from the Greek Anthology | work = fulltextarchive.com | publisher = Longmans, Green, and Co | date = [1890] | url = http://fulltextarchive.com/page/Select-Epigrams-from-the-Greek-Anthology2/#p134 | format = | doi = | accessdate = April 2008}} ==In popular fiction== In the [[Tom Clancy]] novel ''[[Red Storm Rising]]'', ''Key West'' participated in a [[cruise missile]] strike against the [[Soviet Union]]. In the novel ''Kirov III-Pacific Storm'' by John Schettler, ''Key West'' is involved in a critical action with the Russian Battlecruiser Kirov II. In the Swedish novel ''Landsförrädaren'' by [[Anders Jallai]], the ''Key West'' makes an appearance to save the [[protagonist]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{NVR}} {{USGovernment|sourceURL=www.news.navy.mil, ''United States Navy''}} {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Key West (Ssn-722)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Florida-related ships]] [[Category:1985 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{otherships|USS Newport News}} {{lead too short|date=January 2009}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Newport News SSN-750 Oct04 port.jpg|300px|USS Newport News]] |Ship caption=USS ''Newport News'', in October 2004 }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag= {{USN flag|2009}} |Ship name=USS ''Newport News'' |Ship namesake=The City of [[Newport News, Virginia]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 19 April 1982 |Ship builder=[[Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding|Newport News Shipbuilding]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 3 March 1984 |Ship launched= 15 March 1986 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 3 June 1989 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= [[Norfolk, Virginia]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= ''Magni Nominis Umbra''
([[Latin]]:"Under the shadow of a great name") |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:USS Newport News SSN-750 Crest.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement= {{convert|5700|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light

{{convert|30|kn|km/h}} submerged (actual top speed classified) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth={{convert|290|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=13 officers; 121 enlisted |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × {{convert|21|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} bow tubes
• [[Mark 48 torpedo]]
• [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon missile]]
• [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk cruise missile]] |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Newport News'' (SSN-750)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Newport News, Virginia]]. ==Construction== The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 19 April 1982 and her keel was laid down on 3 March 1984. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 15 March 1986 sponsored by [[Paul S. Trible, Jr.|Mrs. Rosemary D. Trible]], and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 3 June 1989 with Commander Mark B. Keef in command. Mayor [[Jessie M. Rattley]] presented the ship with a commemorative plaque containing the poem "Newport News," written by Newport News native Ronald W. Bell, whose poem "[[Hyman G. Rickover|Admiral Rickover]]" also appears upon a plaque aboard the ''Los Angeles'' class submarine {{USS|Hyman G. Rickover|SSN-709|2}}.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} The poem appears on this page with permission from the author:{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} ::"Newport News" :Harbor of a thousand ships :Forger of a nation's fleet :Gateway to the New World :Where ocean and river meet :Strength wrought from steel :And a people's fortitude :Such is the timeless legacy :Of a place called Newport News. ==Initial operations== ''Newport News'' returned to [[Norfolk, Virginia]], following a six-month overseas deployment that included operations in the Middle East. In support of Operation Iraqi Freedom she launched 19 UGM-109C Tomahawk Land Attack Missiles in March 2003. She deployed in August 2004, first to take part in joint operations with allied navies in the North Atlantic, then to the U.S. Central Command area of operations "in support of national security interests and the global war on terrorism."{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} ==Collision with Japanese ship== On 8 January 2007, ''Newport News'' was operating submerged in the [[Arabian Sea]] south of the [[Straits of Hormuz]] when it hit the Japanese tanker ''Mogamigawa''.[http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/01/08/japan.us.ship/index.html U.S. sub collides with Japan ship], CNN, 8 January 2007. She had been operating as part of Carrier Strike Group 8 (CSG-8),[http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=24919 Eisenhower Strike Group Completes JTFEX 06-2] organized around the [[aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Dwight D. Eisenhower|CVN-69|3}}. The Carrier Strike Group was redeploying to the Indian Ocean to support a maritime cordon during the [[War in Somalia (2006–2009)|war in Somalia]] when the incident happened.{{cite news |title=U.S. Strike in Somalia Targets Al-Qaeda Figure |publisher=Washington Post |date=8 January 2007 |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/08/AR2007010801822.html | first=Karen | last=DeYoung | accessdate=27 May 2010}} The ''Newport News'' suffered damage to her bow, but there was no damage to the sail, mast or reactor, and she made for port in [[Bahrain]] under her own power.{{cite news |title=Navy sub damaged in collision heads for port in Bahrain |url=http://hamptonroads.com/node/205541 |last=Dorsey |first=Jack |date=9 January 2007 |publisher=[[The Virginian-Pilot]] |accessdate=2007-01-11 }} Newport News was escorted from the mouth of the Straits of Hormuz to Bahrain by the [[Guided Missile Destroyer]] [[USS Benfold (DDG-65)]]. This was due to the fact that the submarine was unable to transit submerged and has no surface defense capabilities. During the transit, Iranian aircraft and warships shadowed the ships. An official of the Kawasaki Kisen Company (or [[K Line]]), which owns the tanker, announced that ''Mogamigawa''{{'}}s hull and propellers were damaged.{{cite news |title=Japan's tanker sustains hull breach, propeller damage |url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11146345&PageNum=0 |date=11 January 2007 |publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]] |accessdate=2007-01-11}} According to a Navy spokesman, the collision occurred as a result of the [[venturi effect]]. The tanker drove over the area where the submarine was submerged and this created a sucking effect that forced the submarine upward to the surface.{{cite news |title=Navy says speed of tanker sucked submarine up to surface |url=http://hamptonroads.com/node/205951 |last=Dorsey |first=Jack |date=10 July 2007 |publisher=[[The Virginian-Pilot]] |accessdate=2007-01-11}} The incident was the third collision between a U.S. nuclear-powered submarine and a Japanese civilian ship.{{cite news|author=Kiroku Hanai|title=U.S. presence vs. the public will|publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|date=23 January 2007|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/eo20070123kh.html}} On 29 January, after the boat returned to Bahrain for repairs, administrative personnel actions ([[Admiral's Mast]]) were taken against several members of her crew, which included relieving the boat's commanding officer, Commander Matthew A. Weingart, of command due to a lack of confidence in his ability to command.{{cite news |title=USS Newport News Commanding Officer Relieved of Duty |url=http://www.wtkr.com/Global/story.asp?S=6005197&nav=ZolHbyvj |date=29 January 2007 |publisher=WTKR Newschannel 3 |accessdate=2007-01-30}} On 10 April the Iranian [[Fars News Agency]] reported that the ''Newport News'' has been leaking radioactive and chemical pollution in the Persian Gulf and claimed that following this formal complaint, the ship departed the gulf for a complete overhaul.{{cite news |title=US Submarine Forced to Leave Persian Gulf |url=http://english.farsnews.ir/newstext.php?nn=8601210568 |date=10 April 2007 |publisher=FARS News Agency |accessdate=2007-04-11}} (Note that the image accompanying the FARS article is not a Los Angeles class submarine.) The [[United States Fifth Fleet|US Navy Fifth Fleet]] denied this claim restating that damage was limited to the bow and that the sail, mast and reactors were not damaged.{{cite news |title=U.S. withdraws damaged sub said by Iran to leak radiation into Gulf |url=http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/07/front2454204.01875.html |date=13 April 2007 |publisher=World Tribune |accessdate=2008-02-01}} On 2 October 2007 the U.S. Navy agreed to pay [[K Line|Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd]], the company that owns ''Mogamigawa'' an undisclosed amount in compensation for the collision.{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20071003a9.html|author=[[Kyodo News]]|title=U.S. Navy to pay for hitting tanker|publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|date=3 October 2007}} ==Gallery== Image:USS Newport News SSN-750 Oct04 depart.jpg|Departing Souda Bay, Crete, Greece Image:USS Newport News SSN-750 Oct04 aft.jpg|''Newport News'' seen in October 2004 off Crete == References == {{reflist}} {{NVR|http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN750.htm}} ==External links== {{Commons category|USS Newport News (SSN-750)}} *[http://www.csg2.navy.mil/Newport%20News/newportnews.htm US Navy Commander Submarine Group Two] {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Newport News (SSN-750)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Virginia-related ships]] [[Category:United States submarine accidents]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 2007]] [[Category:Japan–United States relations]] [[Category:Non-combat military accidents]] [[Category:International maritime incidents]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]] [[Category:1986 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]

{{otherships|USS Helena}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image= [[Image:USS Helena SSN-725.jpg|300px|USS Helena (SSN-725)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= USA |Ship flag= {{USN flag|2009}} |Ship name=USS ''Helena'' |Ship namesake=The City of [[Helena, Montana]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 19 April 1982 |Ship builder=[[General Dynamics Electric Boat]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 28 March 1985 |Ship launched= 28 June 1986 |Ship sponsor=Mrs. Jean Busey |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 11 July 1987 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= [[Naval Station Norfolk|Norfolk, Virginia]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto=''Proud and Fearless'' |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:USS Helena SSN-725 Crest.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement={{convert|5808|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6203|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|395|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power=Steam Turbine (nuclear) |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers; 98 enlisted |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[UGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Helena'' (SSN-725)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the fourth ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Helena, Montana]]. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 19 April 1982 and her keel was laid down on 28 March 1985. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 28 June 1986 sponsored by Mrs. Jean Busey, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 11 July 1987, with Commander Thomas Moore in command. ==Gallery== File:US Navy 110621-N-NK458-140 Sailors conduct maintenance on small arms in the torpedo room aboard the Los Angeles-class attack submarine USS Helena (.jpg|Maintenance on small arms in the [[torpedo]] room == References == {{DANFSNVR}} {{Commonscat}} {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} == External links == * [http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN725.htm Naval Vessel Register entry for USS ''Helena''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Helena (SSN-725)}} [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Montana-related ships]] [[Category:1986 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Obsession (''Star Trek: The Original Series'')}} {{Unreferenced|date=March 2012}}{{allplot|date=July 2013}} {{longplot|date=July 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox television episode | Title = Obsession | Series = [[Star Trek: The Original Series]] | Season = 2 | Episode = 13 | Production = 047 | Airdate = {{Start date|1967|12|15}} | Writer = [[Art Wallace]] | Director = [[Ralph Senensky]] | Music = [[Sol Kaplan]] | Photographer = [[Gerald Perry Finnerman|Jerry Finnerman]] | Guests = *[[Majel Barrett]] - Nurse [[Christine Chapel]] *[[Stephen Brooks (actor)|Stephen Brooks]] - Ensign Garrovick *[[Jerry Ayres]] - Ensign Rizzo *[[Eddie Paskey]] - Lt. Leslie *[[William Blackburn (actor)|William Blackburn]] - Lt. Hadley *[[Frank Da Vinci]] - Security Guard | Prev = [[The Deadly Years]] | Next = [[Wolf in the Fold]] | Episode list = [[List of Star Trek: The Original Series episodes|List of ''Star Trek: The Original Series'' episodes]] }}
"'''Obsession'''" is a second season episode of the original [[science fiction]] television series ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' and was broadcast on December 15, 1967. It is episode #42, production #47, written by [[Art Wallace]], and directed by [[Ralph Senensky]].
In this episode, Captain [[James T. Kirk]] becomes [[fixation (psychology)|obsessed]] with destroying a deadly entity he once encountered in his youth.
This episode deals with several human emotions: guilt, fear, obsession and, ultimately, redemption. While Captain Kirk is the primary focus, the viewer sees glimpses of these emotions in other members of the ship. At various times the "fight or flight" instinct is shown as an internal battle which one has to overcome in order to find emotional peace.
==Plot== The [[United Federation of Planets|Federation]] [[starship]] USS ''[[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701)|Enterprise]]'' has sent down a landing team to a planet to search for tritanium deposits. While surveying, Captain Kirk notices a sweet honey smell, and has his men go on alert. He tells them to scan for dikironium and immediately fire at anything that looks like a gaseous cloud. The landing party fans out to explore.
One group picks up a signal but loses it, at which point they are immediately attacked. Kirk and Science Officer [[Spock]] rush over to the scene, finding three crewmen down; two dead, the other, Ensign Rizzo, near death. All of the men have had their [[red blood cell]]s drained of [[hemoglobin]]. Kirk fears that the killer is the same entity he had encountered 11 years before while serving aboard the USS ''Farragut''. As a young lieutenant, Kirk had hesitated in firing the ship's phasers at the creature, which promptly attacked. The encounter killed half the Farragut's crew, with Kirk and the ship's first officer among the survivors. Kirk felt great guilt over what happened even though, on the subsequent official record, the XO had praised the young Kirk for his actions in battle, describing Kirk as "a fine young officer who performed with uncommon bravery."
The landing team quickly returns to the Enterprise. Once aboard, Kirk becomes obsessed with finding this entity, feeling guilty that it caused so much damage and then eluded him. He ignores his priority orders to rendezvous with the USS ''Yorktown'', to transfer urgent medical supplies destined for Theta VII, until Chief Medical Officer [[Leonard McCoy|Dr. McCoy]] can confirm the cause of the men's deaths. McCoy, however, is at a loss and complains that he doesn't even know where to begin. Kirk tells him to reference the Farragut's medical logs and start there. On the bridge, Kirk has Spock look for a gaseous entity that is able to conceal itself and pass through solid matter. Spock is intrigued about such a creature, fascinated that it can move through space and time at will. He suggests that it must be able to control its molecular structure, but Kirk cuts him off, stating he doesn't want a scientific analysis and just wants the creature found.
Kirk calls one of the security officers, Ensign Garrovick. to the bridge. The ensign's father was the commanding officer of the Farragut and lost his life to the entity. Kirk believes Garrovick's son will be as driven in finding the creature as he is and assigns him to the next landing party to hunt the entity down. As soon as they prepare to leave, Dr. McCoy reports that Rizzo has died of his injuries.
Kirk orders his landing party to fire at the entity as soon as it is spotted. He informs his men that the creature attacks quickly, so any hesitation will be deadly. The team spreads out and Ensign Garrovick soon encounters the creature. He aims his phaser but hesitates to fire, becoming frozen with fear as his partner is killed. The creature moves off just as Kirk arrives. Back on the ''Enterprise'', Garrovick admits that he hesitated before firing his [[phaser (Star Trek)|phaser]] and is confined to quarters.
McCoy has seen enough and confronts the Captain on his reckless obsession over the creature. He summons Spock to consider Kirk's fitness for command. Kirk justifies his actions by maintaining that the creature is an intelligent predator and a serious threat to inhabited worlds. He warns that if it manages to travel to a populated system, there is no telling how many it will kill. McCoy finally backs off as Ensign [[Pavel Chekov|Chekov]] reports that he is tracking the cloud creature moving away from the planet.
The landing party quickly returns to the ship and Kirk orders a pursuit of the cloud at [[Warp drive (Star Trek)|Warp 8]]. The ship gives chase, but Chief Engineer [[Montgomery Scott|Scott]] doubts the ''Enterprise'' can sustain the high speeds for long. Kirk orders a reduction of speed and, curiously, the entity slows down as well. It slows as if preparing for a confrontation and allowing them to catch up. Kirk orders battle stations as the entity cloud comes into range, and gives the order to fire their weapons. The phasers and photon torpedoes pass right through the being without incident. Not only do the weapons have no effect, but neither do the deflector shields - the creature passes right through the ship's hull and into the ventilation system. Kirk orders a shutdown of life support, limiting the crew to two hours of air. He orders Scotty to close all vents and flood the system with gas.
After a conference, Spock points out to Kirk that since the creature is immune to conventional weapons fire, he needn't blame himself for hesitating to fire in the earlier incident. Firing promptly on the creature would have made no difference, and the resulting deaths by the creature were impossible for Kirk to prevent.
Meanwhile, the creature exits the vents and kills two crewmen. It then enters the room of Ensign Garrovick and tries to attack him, but Spock was already present shortly before the it arrived. The creature gets a sample of Spock's [[Vulcan (Star Trek)|Vulcan]] blood, which repels it due to its alien composition. The creature quickly lets Spock go and flees the ship. Dr. McCoy wryly comments that Spock's green blood "must have left a bad taste."
The creature makes its way to the fourth planet in the Tycho system and the ''Enterprise'' heads there in pursuit. Kirk wonders if the planet is the creature's natural home, since that is where the ''Farragut'' originally encountered it. Kirk plans a trap for the creature while Spock comments that the creature may be feeding in order to reproduce. If the entity is not stopped they could be facing more of them.
Kirk and Ensign Garrovick beam down to the planet with a case that holds an [[antimatter]] bomb. The two lure the creature with blood from the ship's medical supply, but it quickly gobbles up the "bait" before they can lead it to the bomb.
Kirk decides to use himself as bait and remain behind to detonate the bomb. He orders Garrovick back to the ship, but the young officer refuses to abandon his Captain and a fight ensues before Kirk can explain that he does not mean to sacrifice himself. The two ready the bomb as the creature draws near. With the creature ready to envelop them, Kirk and Garrovick beam away and the antimatter bomb explodes, annihilating the entity and much of Tycho IV with it.
Once safe aboard the ship, Kirk takes Garrovick aside to thank him and tell him a few stories about his father, Captain Garrovick.

revision.comment: moved [[Wikipedia:Votes for deletion/Ghostcloud]] to [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Ghostcloud]]: Move VfD to AfD.
revision.text:
[[Ghostcloud]] was proposed for deletion. This page is an archive of the discussion about the proposed deletion. '''This page is no longer live.''' Further comments should be made on the article's talk page rather than here so that this page is preserved as an historic record. The result of the debate was DELETE
A band whose only recording so far, as poor quality as it was, sold only 20 copies to friends and relatives. [[User:RickK|Rick]][[User talk:RickK|K]] 22:34, Oct 31, 2004 (UTC) *"The band has yet to reach critical or popular acclaim." I just love it when articles justify their own '''deletion'''. --[[User:Slowking Man|Slowking Man]] 22:36, Oct 31, 2004 (UTC) *'''Delete''' --[[User:Nought|Nought]] 23:06, 31 Oct 2004 (UTC) *'''Delete''' --[[User:Yoshiah ap|Josiah]] 01:26, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) *'''Delete''' --[[User:Plato|[[User:Plato|Comrade Nick]] [[User talk: plato|</small><font color=red><small>@</small><font color=green>)---^--]]]] 01:44, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) *Delete: A couple of guys with 20 friends. Best wishes, but this ain't encyclopedic. [[User:Geogre|Geogre]] 02:00, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) * '''Comment:''' i'm a member of this band. i'm surprised to see that people care enough to want to kick it off. a lot of the stuff that was added was from others reading the entry. there's nothing i can do about that. i think it should stay in. -noah (moved by [[User:Nought|Nought]] - looked confusing on the previous position) ** Comment is by [[User:64.222.101.126]], who created the article. noah/64.222.101.126, please sign your edits by appending <nowiki>~~~~</nowiki> (four tildes). It's quick and easy to create an account if you want a more reliable user name than your IP address (just click the link at top right). [[User:Pnot|Pnot]] 03:56, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) ** Contrary to noah's assertion, all the content was added from either the IP address 64.222.101.126, or the IP address 64.223.112.87 (which is in the same Verizon dialup pool). ([[User:Mr Bound|Mr Bound]] contributed a couple of minor revisions but didn't add any content.) [[User:Pnot|Pnot]] 03:56, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) * '''Comment:''' you guys are all very nice. it seems a little weird that you care though. out of curiousity, do you work for wikipedia? -noah ** noah: please don't take offence at being VfD'd: Wikipedia isn't intended to contain ''absolutely everything'', and some things just aren't notable enough to be encyclopaedic. To answer your question, very few people (or perhaps none at all) actually "work" for Wikipedia in the sense of being officially employed. All the contributors (as far as I know) are volunteers, though perhaps a few people are paid to keep the servers running smoothly. [[User:Pnot|Pnot]] 03:56, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) * '''Delete'''. Best of luck to them, but insufficiently notable until such time as they go on to greater things :-). [[User:Pnot|Pnot]] 03:56, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) *'''Delete.''' We can have an article about this band when they become more well known, but it is not appropriate to advertise oneself or one's per project here in order to gain notability. [[User:Jni|jni]] 06:11, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. Not notable yet. --[[User:Improv|Improv]] 08:30, 1 Nov 2004 (UTC) * '''Comment:''' yeah, i put it up from my computer. i think someone went in to fix things from here. it's true, we aren't very famous. i sure got a kick out of having an entry though. -noah
This page is now preserved as an archive of the debate and, like other '/delete' pages is no longer 'live'. Subsequent comments on the issue, the deletion or on the decision-making process should be placed on the relevant 'live' pages. '''Please do not edit this page'''.

revision.text:
{{Infobox Senator | name = George S. Nixon | image name = George Stuart Nixon.jpg | jr/sr =United States Senator | state=[[Nevada]] | party =[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | term_start = March 4, 1905 | term_end = June 5, 1912 | alongside = | preceded = [[William M. Stewart]] | succeeded = [[William A. Massey]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1860|4|2}} | birth_place = [[Newcastle, California|Newcastle]], [[California]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1912|6|5|1860|4|2}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]] | residence= [[Winnemucca, Nevada|Winnemucca]] | spouse = | profession=[[Banker]] | religion= }} '''George Stuart Nixon''' (April 2, 1860 – June 5, 1912) was a [[United States Senator]] from [[Nevada]].
He was born in [[Placer County, California]]. He went to work for a railroad company and studied telegraphy. Later, he was transferred in 1881 to Nevada and organized and became cashier of a bank at [[Winnemucca, Nevada]]. He built an opera house in [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]] and a theater in Winnemucca.
He became a member of the [[Nevada Assembly]] in 1891 and was elected in 1905 as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to the U.S. Senate. He was reelected in 1911 and served until his death in 1912. He was the chairman of the Committee on Coast Defenses.
On February 9, 1905, he joined the San Francisco [[Bohemian Club]]. He died in 1912 and was replaced by [[William A. Massey]]. He was buried in the [[Masonic]] Cemetery in Reno.
== References == {{CongBio|N000114}} *The Bohemian Club: Constitution, By-Laws and Rules, Officers, Committees and Members. 1910. San Francisco.

{{for|other uses of the name "Crampton"|Crampton}} [[File:Badische IX.jpg|thumb|300px|German Crampton locomotive "Badenia"]]A '''Crampton locomotive''' is a type of [[steam locomotive]] designed by [[Thomas Russell Crampton]] and built by various firms from [[1846 in rail transport|1846]]. The main British builders were [[Tulk and Ley]] and [[Robert Stephenson and Company]]. Notable features were a low [[boiler]] and large [[driving wheels]]. The crux of the Crampton patent was that the single driving axle was placed behind the firebox, so that the driving wheels could be very large. This helped to give this design a low centre of gravity, so that it did not require a very [[broad-gauge]] track to travel safely at high speeds. Its [[wheel arrangement]] was usually [[4-2-0]] or [[6-2-0]]. ==Design variations== Because the single driving axle was behind the firebox, Crampton locomotives usually had outside cylinders. However, some inside cylinder versions were built using indirect drive, then known as a ''jackshaft''. The inside cylinders drove a [[crankshaft]] located in front of the firebox and the crankshaft was connected to the driving wheels by outside rods. Some long-wheelbase [[0-4-0]] [[tank locomotive]]s were also built using this crankshaft system. The boiler feed-pump was often driven from the crankshaft as well because many Cramptons were built before the [[injector]] was invented. Another peculiarity on some Crampton locomotives was the use of a boiler of oval cross-section, to lower the centre of gravity. It would nowadays be regarded as bad engineering practice because the internal pressure would tend to push the boiler into a circular cross-section and increase the risk of [[metal fatigue]]. ==Usage== [[File:France Paris Champs Elysees Locomotive Crampton 80 01.JPG|thumb|Preserved French Crampton locomotive]] Crampton locomotives were used by some British railways and speeds of up to 120 km/h (75 mph) were achieved on the [[London and North Western Railway|LNWR]]. They were more popular in [[France]], southern [[Germany]] and the [[United States|US]]. In France the expression ''"prendre la Crampton"'' meant to catch an express. One of the French examples has been preserved in the ''[[Musée Français du Chemin de Fer|Cité du Train]]'' (the French Railway Museum) at [[Mulhouse]] and is still in working order. This is number 80 of the ''[[Chemin de Fer de l'Est]]'', the [[Paris]]-[[Strasbourg]] line, which is named ''"Le Continent"''. ==Locomotive list== Approximate numbers of Crampton-type locomotives built in Europe were: * Great Britain 51 * France 127 * Germany 135 Below is a list of British-built Crampton locomotives: '''Built by:''' [[Tulk and Ley]], all of [[4-2-0]] wheel arrangement: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date built ! Works no. ! Railway ! Name/no. ! Notes |- | 1847 | 10 | Namur and Liege Railway | ''Namur'' | (1) |- | 1847 | 11 | Namur and Liege Railway | ''Liege'' | (1) |- | 1847 | | Namur and Liege Railway | | (1) |- | 1847 | 12? | [[LNWR]] | ''London'' 200 | (2)(3) |- | 1847 | 14 | [[D&P&AJR]] | ''Kinnaird'' | (4) |- | 1847 | | Sheffield, Ashton and Manchester Railway | ''Pegasus'' 35 | |- | 1848 | | Sheffield, Ashton and Manchester Railway | ''Phlegon'' 36 | |- | 1854 | 17 | [[Maryport and Carlisle Railway]] | 12 | |- |} Notes # ''Namur'' was tested over {{convert|2300|mi|km}} on the [[LNWR]] {{cite web | url = http://www.steamindex.com/locotype/lnwr.htm#j154| publisher = Steam Index| title = London & North Western Railway locomotives: Introduction & pre-Ramsbottom| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} speeds up to {{convert|62|mph|km/h}} were recorded. Delivery of ''Namur'', ''Liege'' and the third engine ordered for Belgium was delayed, and they were purchased by the [[South Eastern Railway (UK)|South Eastern Railway]] in December 1849, becoming SER Nos 81, 83 and 85. # The LNWR obtained two other Crampton-type locomotives: ''Courier'', 4-2-0, built at [[Crewe Works]] in 1847 and [[Liverpool (1848 Crampton locomotive)|''Liverpool'']], [[6-2-0]], built by [[Bury, Curtis, and Kennedy]] in 1848. # LNWR No.200 ''London'', larger boiler and cylinders than ''Namur''. Later rebuilt as an [[0-4-2]]. # Dundee and Perth and Aberdeen Junction Railway, absorbed by the [[Scottish Central Railway]] in 1863 ----
'''Built by:''' [[Robert Stephenson and Company]]
Robert Stephenson and Company built a number of Crampton type locomotives for the [[South Eastern Railway (UK)|South Eastern Railway]] and the [[London, Chatham and Dover Railway]]. These were all of [[4-2-0]] wheel arrangement with inside cylinders and indirect drive. The inside cylinders drove a [[crankshaft]] located in front of the firebox and the crankshaft was coupled to the driving wheels by outside rods. [[File:Great Exhibition, No 136 Folkstone by HF Talbot, 1851.jpg|thumb|right|300px|No. 136 ''Folkstone'' at [[The Great Exhibition]], 1851.]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date built ! Works no. ! Railway ! No./Name ! Notes |- | 1851 | 785 | South Eastern Railway | 134 | |- | 1851 | 786 | South Eastern Railway | 135 | |- | 1851 | 787 | South Eastern Railway | ''Folkstone'' 136 | (1) |- |- | 1851 | 788 | South Eastern Railway | 137 | |- | 1851 | 789 | South Eastern Railway | 138 | |- | 1851 | 790 | South Eastern Railway | 139 | |- |- | 1851 | 791 | South Eastern Railway | 140 | |- | 1851 | 792 | South Eastern Railway | 141 | |- | 1851 | 793 | South Eastern Railway | 142 | |- |- | 1851 | 794 | South Eastern Railway | 143 | |- | 1851 | | [[Prussian Eastern Railways]] | ''England'' | |- | 1851 | | Prussian Eastern Railways | | |- | 1851 | | Prussian Eastern Railways | | |- | 1851 | | Prussian Eastern Railways | | |- | 1851 | | Prussian Eastern Railways | | |- | 1851 | | Prussian Eastern Railways | | |- | 1862 | 1381 | rowspan=5 | [[London, Chatham and Dover Railway]] | ''Coquette'' | rowspan=5 | (2) |- | 1862 | 1382 | ''Echo'' |- | 1862 | 1383 | ''Flirt'' |- | 1862 | 1384 | ''Flora'' |- | 1862 | 1385 | ''Sylph'' |- |} Notes: # The name should have read [[Folkestone]] but was misspelled on the plate. This locomotive was displayed at [[The Great Exhibition]] of 1851. [http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/eGallery/object.asp?category=EAPHOTOGRAPHS&object=2800094&row=7] Bogie wheels {{convert|3|ft|6|in|m|2}} diameter, driving wheels {{convert|6|ft|m|2}} diameter. Cylinders 15"x 22" (380mmx560mm). Weight 26¼ Tons.{{cite web | url = http://www.percywhitlock.org.uk/trains.htm| publisher = The Percy Whitlock Trust| title = The South Eastern and Chatham Railway and the London , Chatham and Dover Railway Amalgamated 1899 LOCOMOTIVES: Their Description, History, distinctive features and interest| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} # [[LCDR Echo class|LCDR ''Echo'' class]]; rebuilt as conventional 4-4-0s in 1865–1866.{{sfn|Bradley|1960|pp=15–16}} They were not given numbers until 1874. ----
'''Built by:''' [[Bury, Curtis, and Kennedy]], all 4-2-0 except ''Liverpool'' which was 6-2-0. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date built ! Works no. ! Railway ! No./Name ! Notes |- | 1848 | 355 | LNWR | ''Liverpool'' 245 | (1) |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 68 | |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 69 | |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 72 | |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 74 | |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 75 | |- | 1848 | ? | South Eastern Railway | 78 | |- |} #''Liverpool'', [[6-2-0]], built by [[Bury, Curtis, and Kennedy]] works number 355/1848. Driving wheels {{convert|8|ft|m|2}} diameter, grate area {{convert|21.5|sqft|m2}}, heating area {{convert|2290|sqft|m2}}, boiler pressure 120 lb/in2, cylinders 18"x24" (460mm x 610mm). The locomotive was awarded a Gold Medal at the Great Exhibition of 1851.{{cite web | url = http://www.steamindex.com/people/crampton.htm| publisher = Steam Index| title = Thomas Russell Crampton | accessdate = 2008-03-22}} ----
'''Built by:''' [[E. B. Wilson and Company]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date built ! Works no. ! Railway ! Name/no. ! Notes |- | 1847 | ? | [[North British Railway]] | 55 | (1) |- | 1847 | ? | [[Eastern Counties Railway]] | 108 | |- | 1847 | ? | Eastern Counties Railway | 109 | |- | 1847 | ? | Eastern Counties Railway | 110 | |- | 1847 | ? | Eastern Counties Railway | 111 | |- | 1847 | ? | Eastern Counties Railway | 112 | |- | 1847 | ? | [[Aberdeen Railway]] | 26 | |- | 1847 | ? | Aberdeen Railway | 27 | |- |} # Hauled the Royal Train in 1850, withdrawn from service in 1907.{{cite web | url = http://www.cramptontower.co.uk/about.htm| publisher = Crampton Tower Museum| title = LOCOMOTIVES| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} ----
'''Built by:''' [[R and W Hawthorn]] [[4-4-0]]ST {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date built ! Works no. ! Railway ! Name/no. ! Notes |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Lake'' 62 | (1) |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Sondes'' 59 | (1) |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Faversham'' 63 | (1) |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Chatham'' 64 | (1) |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Crampton'' 61 | (1) |- | 1858 | - | [[East Kent Railway]] | ''Sittingbourne'' 60 | (1) |- |} # Rebuilt as Kirtley F class 2-4-0T 1865{{cite book |last=Bradley |first=D. L. |year=1960 |title=The Locomotives of the London, Chatham and Dover Railway |publisher= [[Railway Correspondence and Travel Society]] |pages=19–22|ref=harv}} ----

Horlock & Co. | 1848 | | [[Padarn Railway]] | ''[[Fire Queen]]'' | (2) |- | A. Horlock & Co. | 1848 | | [[Padarn Railway]] | ''Jenny Lind'' | |- | | 1848 | | [[Chemins de fer du Nord]] | | |- | [[R. B. Longridge and Company]] | 1851 | ? | [[Great Northern Railway (Great Britain)|Great Northern Railway]] | 200 | (3) |- | | 1855 | | [[Chemins de fer de Paris à Lyon et à la Méditerranée]] | | (4) |- | | 1855 | | [[Chemin de fer du Nord]] | ''Alma'' 162 | (5) |- | Maschinenbaugesellschaft Karlsruhe | 1863 | | [[Baden state railway|Baden State Railway]] | ''Phoenix'' | (6) |- |} Notes: #Originally built as a 2-2-2, rebuilt as a Crampton 2+2-2–0 December 1848.D.L. Bradley, ''The Locomotives of the South Eastern Railway'', Railway Correspondence and Travel Society, 1963, p.43. # [[0-4-0]] locomotives, {{RailGauge|4}} gauge, ''Fire Queen'' preserved at [[Penrhyn Castle Railway Museum]]. ''[[Jenny Lind]]'' named after the opera singer, a friend of Crampton's wife Louisa. # Sources differ on how many Crampton locomotives Longridge built for the Great Northern Railway. Number 200 was later converted from a 4-2-0 to a conventional [[2-2-2]]. There were nine similar 2-2-2 locomotives numbered 91-99 and it is uncertain whether these were built as 2-2-2 or whether they were converted from 4-2-0 like number 200. # 40 locomotives built for the PLM between 1855 and 1864.{{cite web | url = http://pagesperso-orange.fr/tgveurofrance.com/traincapitale/cramptonen.htm| publisher = tgveurofrance.com| title = The Crampton steam locomotive| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} # A [[6-2-0]] locomotive, converted to the Petiet system in the 1860s, withdrawn and scrapped in 1873.{{cite web | url = http://www.aqpl43.dsl.pipex.com/MUSEUM/LOCOLOCO/petiet/frexp.htm| publisher = The Douglas Self Site| title = Petiet's French Experiments| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} # In service until 1903, length {{convert|12.90|m|ftin}}, top speed {{convert|120|km/h|mph}}, weight 28½ tonnes. Preserved in the Deutsches Bundesbahn Museum, [[Nuremberg]].{{cite web | url = https://www.db.de/site/bahn/en/db__group/db__museum/exhibitions/vehicles/phoenix.html| publisher = Deutsche Bahn Group| title = In the days when locomotives still had poetic names - the Phoenix| accessdate = 2008-03-22}} ==See also== * [[Long Boiler locomotive]] * [[6-2-0]] for Crampton locomotives in the USA ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * {{cite book |last=Bradley |first=D. L. |year=1960 |title=The Locomotives of the London, Chatham and Dover Railway |publisher= [[Railway Correspondence and Travel Society]] |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Sharman |first=M. |year=1983 |title=The Crampton Locomotive |publisher=Oakwood Press |isbn=0-9509067-0-0 }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Crampton locomotives}} *[http://www.citedutrain.com/cite_du_train/index.htm The Cité du Train museum] * [http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/eGallery/object.asp?category=EAPHOTOGRAPHS&object=2800094&row=7 Photo of Crampton locomotive] at [[The Great Exhibition]] of 1851 {{DEFAULTSORT:Crampton Locomotive}} [[Category:Steam locomotive types]] [[de:Dampflokomotive (Bauart)#Die „Crampton“]]

{{otherships|USS Pasadena}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Pasadena SSN-752.jpg|300px|USS Pasadena (SSN-752)]] |Ship caption=USS ''Pasadena'' (SSN-752) }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag}} |Ship name=USS ''Pasadena'' |Ship namesake=City of [[Pasadena, California]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded=30 November 1982 |Ship builder=[[General Dynamics Electric Boat]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=20 December 1985 |Ship launched=12 September 1987 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=11 February 1989 |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:USS Pasadena SSN-752 Crest.png|150px|''Pasedena''{{'s}} Insignia]] }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement=5,802 tons light, 6,204 tons full, 402 tons dead |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=one [[S6G reactor]] |Ship speed= '''Surfaced:'''{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}}
'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship sensors=BQQ-5 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Pasadena'' (SSN-752)''', a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Pasadena, California]]. ''Pasadena'' provides the Fleet Commander or Task Force Commander a multi-mission platform. This vessel has unlimited endurance due to the nuclear propulsion plant, advanced sonar, torpedo, cruise missile, and mine delivery systems, a combination of speed and stealth due to quieting and the capacity to fulfill numerous missions. ==History== The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 30 November 1982 and her keel was laid down on 20 December 1985. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 12 September 1987 sponsored by Mrs. Pauline Trost, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 11 February 1989 with Commander W. Fritchman in command. Originally assigned to Submarine Force, [[U.S. Atlantic Fleet]], ''Pasadena'' conducted an inter-fleet transfer in October 1990 to the Submarine Force, [[U.S. Pacific Fleet]], and was homeported in [[San Diego, California]]. In July 1991, ''Pasadena'' became the first Improved 688 Class submarine to deploy, commencing a six-month Western Pacific deployment. In June 1993, she commenced a six-month Western Pacific deployment to the Persian Gulf. While deployed, ''Pasadena'' participated in several exercises with the [[Royal Saudi Navy|Royal Saudi]], [[Royal Navy of Oman|Omani]] and [[Royal Australian Navy|Australian]] Navies, and was the first United States SSN to conduct exercises with the [[Indian Navy]] in [[Malabar 2007|MALABAR Naval Exercise]].{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2003/10/06/stories/2003100602700500.htm |title=Indo-U.S. naval exercise begins today |date=2003-10-06 | location=Chennai, India |work=The Hindu}} She also became the first nuclear-powered submarine to visit the port of [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]] on the [[Red Sea]]. In March 1995, ''Pasadena'' again deployed on a six-month Western Pacific Deployment. While deployed to the [[Persian Gulf]] she became the first nuclear-powered submarine to visit the port of [[Muscat, Oman]]; the first to operate continuously inside the Persian Gulf; and the first SSN to be assigned to Commander, U.S. [[United States Fifth Fleet|Fifth Fleet]]. In April 1996, ''Pasadena'' changed homeports to [[Pearl Harbor]], [[Hawaii]] where she is now assigned to Commander, Submarine Squadron Seven. From June 1996 to September 1996, ''Pasadena'' underwent a Selected Restricted Availability (SRA) where she was outfitted with improved offensive and defensive weapon systems. In April 1997, ''Pasadena'' deployed to the Eastern Pacific for a four-month deployment in support of UNITAS. In September 2011, the sub entered [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]] for systems upgrades and maintenance work.[[Associated Press]], "[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2011/09/ap-navy-pasadena-submarine-arrives-at-portsmouth-092111/ Submarine Pasadena arrives at Portsmouth]", ''[[Military Times]]'', 21 September 2011. On Wednesday, Sept. 21 2011 ''Pasadena'' and her crew of 18 officers and 126 enlisted personnel arrived at Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, Kittery, Maine. While at the Shipyard, Pasadena will complete various maintenance work and several system upgrades. As of December 2013, her maintenance has been completed and she has returned to her homeport in San Diego. Editor's son was assigned to the Pasadena and is stationed there. ==Awards== ''Pasadena'' was awarded the Submarine Squadron Seven Battle "E" Efficiency award for 1998, which recognizes commands that have attained the highest overall or departmental readiness to carry out their wartime tasks. She was awarded the Morale and Welfare Recreation (MWR) Fleet Recreation award for the entire Navy in 2001. ==Insignia== ''Pasadena''’s insignia is surrounded by a mooring line border with blue background, emphasizing the nautical character of the seal. The surrounding banner carries the ship's hull number and name and bracketed by the motto. The motto, in addition to enhancing the central combative caricature, states in clear terms the readiness of today’s force to fight anywhere in the world on short notice in the national interest. The red rose ties the ship to the City of Pasadena, home of the New Year’s Day [[Tournament of Roses Parade]], which dates back more than 100 years. The turtle pugilist ties SSN-752 to [[USS Pasadena (CL-65)|''Pasadena'' (CL-65)]], a [[World War II]] light cruiser that earned six battle stars. The emblem for CL-65 was created for the cruiser by [[Walt Disney]]. Interestingly, during the sub's construction at the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Groton, CT, the crew adopted a North American Snapping Turtle as a mascot. The creature actually road the boat into the Thames river during its launching. By the time construction was over, the turtle, named Frumpy, which originally fit into the palm of a hand, was over 18 inches long, forcing the crew to find a new home. Cal Poly in Pasadena proved a willing host. To get him to his new abode, two crew members: ET1(SS) Del Laughery, and ET1(SS) Don Hilliker, both pilots, flew the turtle in a private aircraft from Groton to Pasadena. == Popular culture == * ''Pasadena'' is featured in the anime, ''[[Full Metal Panic!]]''. * ''Pasadena'' is the center of the 1990 novel ''Boomer'' * ''Pasadena'' is featured in the [[Tom Clancy]] novel ''[[Executive Orders]]'' as one of several fast-attack submarines tasked to keep an eye on the hostilities growing between [[The People's Republic of China]] and [[The Republic of China]] (Taiwan); The ROC has been called Taiwan since the 1970s but is referred to as the ROC many times in the novel. Pasadena is also featured in Tom Clancy's novel Debt of Honor. == References == {{reflist}} {{DANFSNVR}} {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pasadena (SSN-752), USS}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy California-related ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:1987 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]

{{otherships|USS Columbus}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image | Ship image = [[File:980604-N-7726D-002 Submarine Emergency Surfacing Drill.jpg|300px]] | Ship caption = The Columbus performing an [[Emergency main ballast tank blow]] in 1998 }} {{Infobox Ship Career | Hide header = | Ship country = | Ship flag = {{USN flag}} | Ship name = USS ''Columbus'' | Ship namesake = The City of [[Columbus, Ohio]] | Ship ordered = | Ship awarded = 21 March 1986 | Ship builder = [[General Dynamics Electric Boat]] | Ship original cost = | Ship yard number = | Ship way number = | Ship laid down = 9 January 1991 | Ship launched = 1 August 1992 | Ship sponsor = | Ship christened = | Ship completed = | Ship acquired = | Ship commissioned = 24 July 1993 | Ship decommissioned = | Ship in service = | Ship out of service = | Ship renamed = | Ship reclassified = | Ship refit = | Ship struck = | Ship reinstated = | Ship homeport = [[Pearl Harbor]] | Ship identification = | Ship motto = | Ship nickname = | Ship honors = | Ship captured = | Ship status = {{Ship in active service}} | Ship notes = | Ship badge = [[File:762insig.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = | Ship class = {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} | Ship displacement = {{convert|6000|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] | Ship length = {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | Ship height = | Ship draft = {{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | Ship depth = | Ship decks = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = [[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] | Ship speed = '''Surfaced:'''{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}}
'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) | Ship range = | Ship endurance = | Ship test depth = | Ship complement = 12 officers, 98 men | Ship time to activate = | Ship sensors = BQQ-5 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder | Ship EW = | Ship armament = 4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines | Ship armor = | Ship notes = }} |} '''USS ''Columbus'' (SSN-762)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the fourth ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Columbus, Ohio]]. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 21 March 1986 and her keel was laid down on 9 January 1991. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 1 August 1992 sponsored by Mrs. Margaret DeMars, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 24 July 1993 with Commander Carl M. Smeigh, Jr. in command. ==Operational history== ''Columbus'' completed a Post Shipyard Availability in June 1994 in Groton, Connecticut after initial construction and shakedown operations. In September 1994, the ship conducted an interfleet transfer to [[Pearl Harbor]], [[Hawaii]] and joined the U.S. Pacific Fleet Submarine Force. ''Columbus'' deployed to the [[Pacific Ocean|Western Pacific]] in late 1995 through early 1996 and conducted a variety of operations as a unit of the [[United States Seventh Fleet|U.S. 7th Fleet]] along the way making port visits in Hong Kong, Subic Bay, Guam, and Yokosuka, Japan.[http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1996.pdf Command history. USS COLUMBUS (SSN 762)], Department of the Navy, 7 Mar 97 ''Columbus'' was the first Submarine equipped with the BYG-1 Fire Control System in December 2002.[http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2002.pdf Ship's history. USS COLUMBUS (SSN 762)], Department of the Navy, 12 Sep 2003 Two successful test launches of Tactical Tomahawk (Block IV) cruise missiles were conducted in late May 2003 from USS ''Columbus'' (SSN 762), underway in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Southern California.{{cite web|last=Schroeder |first=Sandra |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=7644 |title=Submarine USS Columbus Launches Tomahawks in West Coast Tests |publisher=Navy.mil |date= |accessdate=2010-03-26}} Columbus departed Pearl Harbor for another western Pacific deployment in late 2003 {{cite web|last=Journalist |first=Chief |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=10297 |title=USS Columbus Deploys to Western Pacific |publisher=Navy.mil |date= |accessdate=2010-03-26}} and visited Chinhae, South Korea, Singapore, and Japan while taking part in Annual-Ex 2003(exercise) with various units of the Japanese Navy Defense force.[http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2004.pdf Command history. USS COLUMBUS (SSN 762)], Department of the Navy, 1 Apr 2005 Following a modernization refit at the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard in Bremerton Washington the ''Columbus'' returned to Submarine Squadron Seven in Pearl Harbor and departed Pearl Harbor in March 2008 for a regularly scheduled six-month deployment. Deployed with the Seventh Fleet, ''Columbus'' supported national taskings and theater security cooperation efforts while making port visits in Saipan, Guam, Okinawa, Sasebo, and Yokosuka, Japan.{{cite web|last=Communication |first=Mass |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=39699 |title=USS Columbus Returns to Pearl Harbor |publisher=Navy.mil |date=13 September 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} In January 2009 ''Columbus'' won the Submarine Squadron 7 Battle Efficiency (Battle "E") award, given to the submarine crew that best demonstrates technical proficiency and continual mission readiness throughout the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.csp.navy.mil/archived_news/Jan09/release_09002.shtml |title=Commander, Submarine Force U.S. Pacific Fleet | Official Military Website |publisher=Csp.navy.mil |date=14 October 2003 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} CDR David Minyard relieved CDR Doody as Commanding Officer on 8 May 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.csp.navy.mil/releases/release_09029.shtml |title=Commander, Submarine Force U.S. Pacific Fleet | Official Military Website |publisher=Csp.navy.mil |date=14 October 2003 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} In July 2009, the Chief of Naval Operations announced that the ship was the Pacific Fleet winner of the Calendar Year 2008 Arleigh Burke Fleet Trophy.[http://www.npc.navy.mil/NR/rdonlyres/68C557A1-E67A-4210-8AAF-D13D1968DC9E/0/NAV09206.txt CALENDAR YEAR 2008 ARLEIGH BURKE FLEET TROPHY AWARD RECIPIENTS], ADMIRAL G. ROUGHEAD, CHIEF OF NAVAL OPERATIONS The Columbus returned to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii in August 2012 after completing a six-month deployment that included 7th fleet and national mission taskings along with port visits to Japan, South Korea, and Guam while under the command of Cmdr. David Youtt.[http://www.hookelenews.com/uss-columbus-completes-western-pacific-deployment/] The ''Columbus'' arrived in the South Korean southern port city of Busan March 3, 2014. Its arrival in Busan is part of its regular deployment now in the Western Pacific.http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-03/03/c_133156006.htm ==Awards== ; 1995 : Pacific Fleet Golden Anchor Award : Red Engineering "E" : Yellow Medical "M" ; 1996 : Meritorious Unit Commendation [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1997.pdf Command history. USS COLUMBUS (SSN 762)], Department of the Navy, 01 Mar 98 ; 1997 : Supply Blue "E" ; 1998 : Pacific Fleet Silver Anchor Award : Engineering "E" : Deck Seamanship [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1998.pdf Command history. USS COLUMBUS (SSN 762)], Department of the Navy, 31 Mar 99 ; 2002 : Red Green Navigational “N” ; 2003 : Navy Unit Commendation : Tactical “T" : Communications “C” ; 2004 : Medical “M” {{cite web|url=http://web.soundpublishing.com/index.php/navigator/emailtoafriend/uss_columbus_gets_a_new_boss/ |title=The Northwest Navigator > Email to a Friend |publisher=Web.soundpublishing.com |date=1 October 2004 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} ; 2008 : Department of the Navy Safety Excellence Award {{cite web|url=http://www.ctf74.navy.mil/news/2008/08/41.htm |title=2008 DON Safety Excellence Award Recipients Announced |publisher=Ctf74.navy.mil |date=22 August 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} : Battle "E", Damage Control 'DC', Navigation 'N', Communications 'C', and Supply Blue 'E' {{cite web|url=http://theycallmedependent.wordpress.com/2009/01/06/the-battle-e-winners/ |title=THE BATTLE ‘E’ WINNERS! « Anything But Dependent Blog |publisher=Theycallmedependent.wordpress.com |date=10 January 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-26}} : Arleigh Burke Fleet Trophy == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DANFSNVR}} ==External links== {{flatlist| style = border:solid 1px silver| * USS ''Columbus'' (SSN-762) command histories – [[Naval History & Heritage Command]] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1991.pdf 1991] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1992.pdf 1992] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1993.pdf 1993] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1994.pdf 1994] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1995.pdf 1995] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1996.pdf 1996] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1997.pdf 1997] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1998.pdf 1998] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/1999.pdf 1999] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2000.pdf 2000] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2001.pdf 2001] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2002.pdf 2002] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2003.pdf 2003] * [http://www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/c/ssn-762/2004.pdf 2004] }} {{commons category|USS Columbus (SSN-762)}} {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Columbus (SSN-762)}} [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Ohio-related ships]] [[Category:1992 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]

{{other ships|USS Toledo}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= [[Image:USS Toledo SSN-769.jpg|300px|USS Toledo (SSN-769)]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag= {{USN flag}} |Ship name=USS ''Toledo'' |Ship namesake= The City of [[Toledo, Ohio]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 10 June 1988 |Ship builder= [[Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding|Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 6 May 1991 |Ship launched= 28 August 1993 |Ship sponsor=Mrs. Sabra Smith |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 24 February 1995 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= [[Groton, Connecticut]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[Image:769insig.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement={{convert|6000|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=• 4 × {{convert|21|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} torpedo tubes
• 12 × vertical launch [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk]] missiles |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Toledo'' (SSN-769)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Toledo, Ohio]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 10 June 1988 and her keel was laid down on 6 May 1991. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 28 August 1993 sponsored by Mrs. Sabra Smith, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 24 February 1995, with Commander Jack Loye III in command. The submarine was a cover story of the 6 April 1998 issue ''[[US News & World Report]]''. ==Deployments== The USS ''Toledo'' returned to the [[Naval Submarine Base New London]] in mid-April 2003 after having taken part in [[Operation Iraqi Freedom]]. On 7 December 2004, ''Toledo'' returned to [[Groton, Connecticut]], after a six-month deployment in the [[Persian Gulf]] with the {{USS|John F. Kennedy|CV-67|2}} [[carrier strike group]] that included port calls in [[Crete]], [[Dubai]], and Bahrain. Her route home from Bahrain was unusual, rounding the [[Cape of Good Hope]] rather than using the [[Suez Canal]]. Once back in the North Atlantic, she was diverted for a classified drug interdiction mission with the [[Joint Interagency Task Force]]–South in the [[Caribbean Sea]]. On 31 January 2006, ''Toledo'' again departed for a six-month deployment to CENTCOM. Port calls included [[Augusta Bay, Sicily|Augusta Bay]], [[Dubai]], the British island territory of [[Diego Garcia]] and [[La Maddalena]]. The ship returned from this deployment on 31 July 2006 and a change of command ceremony took place in 2009 where Commander Reckamp relieved Commander Goldman. ''Toledo'' left for another six-month deployment on 23 July 2010. In December 2010 ''Toledo'' did a port call in [[Haifa]]. Commander Reckamp was received by the Haifa City Major [[Yona Yahav]] in the City Hall as is customary for visiting commanders of warships doing port calls in Haifa. On 20 January 2011, ''Toledo'' returned to [[Groton, Connecticut]] after a six-month deployment that included port calls in Cyprus, Bahrain, and [[Haifa]]. ==Maintenance== [[Northrop Grumman]] Corporation was awarded a contract from the U.S. Navy for maintenance work, known as a depot modernization period, on the nuclear-powered submarine USS ''Toledo'' (SSN 769). The initial planning contract was valued at approximately $34.7 million. The final value, including the actual execution, was $178.5 million. The ship arrived in December 2006 to [[Newport News, VA]] and the work was completed in March 2009. The project was delayed more than eight months because of more than 2,000 project changes. This was a competitive award under a Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA) multiple award contract. In July 2009 two hull cracks, including one in the pressure hull, were discovered during a routine inspection. The Navy has begun an investigation. Although the Navy and Northrop Grumman launched two investigations into welding practices at the yard while ''Toledo'' was under maintenance, the cracks do not appear to be related to welds.{{cite news|publisher=Newport News, Va., Daily Press|title=Cracks found in USS Toledo|author=Peter Frost|date=21 July 2009|url=http://www.dailypress.com/business/dp-biz_toledo-submarine_0722jul22,0,3033376.story}} ==Kursk-Toledo collision hypothesis== {{details|Kursk submarine disaster}} French filmmaker Jean-Michel Carré, in ''Kursk: a Submarine in Troubled Waters'',http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0vR2MIriTCY ''« Koursk » : un sous-marin en eaux troubles'' 70 mn documentary which aired on 7 January 2005 on French TV channel ''[[France 2]]'', alleged that ''Kursk'' sank because of a sequence of events triggered by a collision with the ''Toledo''. According to Carré, ''Kursk'' was performing tests with [[VA-111 Shkval|''Shkval'']] torpedoes and the tests were being observed by two US submarines on duty in the region, USS ''Toledo'' and {{USS|Memphis|SSN-691}}. == References == {{reflist}} {{NVR}} {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} {{coord missing|Arctic Ocean}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toledo (SSN-769)}} [[Category:K-141 Kursk accident]] [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Ohio-related ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Virginia]] [[Category:1993 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]
