{{convert|6927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= '''Surfaced:'''{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}}
'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors=BSY-1/BQQ-10 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Santa Fe'' (SSN-763)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the second ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[Electric Boat]] Division of [[General Dynamics]] Corporation in [[Groton, Connecticut]] on 21 March 1986 and her keel was laid down on 9 July 1991. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 12 December 1992 sponsored by Mrs. Joy Johnson, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 8 January 1994, with Commander Rodger P. Krull in command. ==Operational history== ''Santa Fe'''s maiden deployment was in 1997 to the [[Persian Gulf]] and Western Pacific. In 1998, she completed a Selected Rectricted Avialability in Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard. In 1999, she was again deployed to the Persian Gulf and Western Pacific earning a [[Meritorious Unit Commendation]] and Coast Guard [[Meritorious Unit Commendation]]. In 2001, she deployed to the Western Pacific and Persian Gulf earning two Meritorius Unit Commendations as well as earning her first coveted CSS-7 Battle E. ''Santa Fe'' deployed to the Western Pacific in September 2003 until March 2004. For this deployment she participated in ANNUALEX '03 with the [[Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force|Japanese Maritime Defense Force]]. The ship made port calls in Singapore, [[Guam]], multiple times in [[Sasebo, Japan]], and in [[Yokosuka, Japan]] in which she rode out a typhoon while in port. ''Santa Fe'' was awarded the [[Navy Unit Commendation]], the second highest award given to a submarine, for actions completed on this deployment. She underwent a three-month Interim drydocking in October 2004. After the ship completed sea trials and other various workups she then completed a two-month Eastern Pacific Deployment that started in May 2005. After returning to her homeport of Pearl Harbor in June 2005, she again deployed to the Western Pacific on 9 August 2005. During this deployment she participated in [[Malabar 2007|Exercise Malabar]] with the Indian Navy. ''Santa Fe'' was the second U.S. nuclear submarine to participate in the exercise and also to port in [[Goa|Goa, India]]. After Malabar, the ship made a brief stop in [[Phuket Province|Phuket, Thailand]]. She was the first U.S. submarine to visit Phuket since 2001. The ship returned to Pearl Harbor in February 2006. She made the transit to the East Coast in July 2006, surfacing near the North Pole on the way. USS ''Santa Fe'' completed a major repair period lasting 18 months at the [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]] in [[Kittery, Maine]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} After undergoing sea trials at [[Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay]], Georgia and transiting through the Panama Canal, she has returned to her homeport of Pearl Harbor, HI. After shipyard she completed a six-month Western Pacific deployment from May–November 2009, after stops in Singapore, [[Saipan]], [[Guam]], [[Okinawa]], JP, and [[United States Fleet Activities Yokosuka|Yokosuka]], JP. She received the Battle "E" Award in January 2010. ''Santa Fe'' returned 24 August 2011 to [[Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam]] after successfully completing a six-month deployment to the western Pacific region. During this deployment ''Santa Fe'' skillfully conducted four operations of great importance to national security by safely operating in a demanding and challenging undersea environment, directly enhancing fleet, theater and national objectives. The crew displayed exceptional tactical skill, tenacity and perseverance while operating under extremely challenging conditions to prepare the battle space for future operations. ''Santa Fe'''s tactical acumen was further displayed by their highly successful participation in [[Exercise Malabar]], a bilateral exercise with the Indian navy. Port calls included [[Sasebo, Japan]] (x3), [[Chinhae]], South Korea; [[Yokosuka, Japan]]; [[Guam]], and [[Subic Bay, Philippines]]. In recognition of their outstanding performance, ''Santa Fe'' received the COMSUBRON 7 Battle "E" Award and was awarded the [[Navy Unit Commendation]] by the [[Secretary of the Navy]]. == Awards == {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2010}} * 2000 -Arleigh Burke Fleet Trophy for most improved ship in the Fleet. * 2001 -Marjorie Sterrett Battleship Fund Award * 2001, 2004, 2009, and 2011 -COMSUBRON 7 Battle Efficiency "E" Award. * 2003, 2012 -Navy Unit Commendation by the SECNAV (2nd highest award that can be given to a Naval vessel) * 2006 -Navy Meritorious Unit Commendation ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DANFSNVR}} ==External links== {{Commons category|USS Santa Fe (SSN-763)}} * [http://www.csp.navy.mil/subssquadrons/santafe/santafe_homepage.shtml USS Santa Fe Official Website] * [http://www.csp.navy.mil/news/santafeab.htm Santa Fe Wins Arleigh Burke Trophy] * [http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=17500 Submarine Commodore Mentioned in Covey Book] * [http://www.csp.navy.mil/releases/release_12-005_2.shtml SANTA FE wins 2011 CSS-7 Battle E] * [http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=66340 SANTA FE earns Navy Unit Commendation] {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Santa Fe (Ssn-763)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy New Mexico-related ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Connecticut]] [[Category:1992 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]]

{{otherships|USS Miami}} {{Use American English|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{MOS|date=March 2013}} {{specific|date=March 2013}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:USS Miami SSN-755.jpg|300px|border|alt=The USS Miami in Port Everglades, Florida in April 2004.]] |Ship caption=The USS ''Miami'' moored to a [[Port Everglades, Florida|Port Everglades]] pier in April 2004. }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=U.S. |Ship flag={{USN flag}} |Ship name=''Miami'' |Ship namesake=[[Miami|City of Miami, Florida]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded=28 November 1983 |Ship builder=[[General Dynamics Electric Boat]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=24 October 1986 |Ship launched=12 November 1988 |Ship sponsor=Jane P. Wilkinson |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=30 June 1990 |Ship decommissioned=28 March 2014 |Ship in service= |Ship out of service=8 August 2013 |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Groton, Connecticut|Groton]], [[Connecticut]], U.S. |Ship identification= |Ship motto= "No Free Rides, Everybody Rows!" |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate={{nowrap|Removed from service, sent for scrapping{{cite web|url=http://www.kjonline.com/news/Navy-abandons-plan-to-fix-nuclear-sub.html|title=Navy abandons plan to fix nuclear sub burned in Maine|work=Kennebec Journal|accessdate=2013-08-06}}}}http://www.janes.com/article/25709/usn-to-scrap-los-angeles-class-attack-submarine-uss-miami |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:755insig.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement={{convert|5751|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6146|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|395|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= Four MK 67 Torpedo Tubes, Twelve VLS Missile Tubes |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Miami'' (SSN-755)''' was a [[United States Navy]] {{sclass|Los Angeles|attack submarine}}. She was the third vessel of the U.S. Navy to be named after [[Miami|Miami, Florida]]. Miami is the 44th Los Angeles Class (688) attack submarine and the 5th Improved Los Angeles Class (688I) to be built and commissioned. The contract to build her was awarded to the [[General Dynamics Electric Boat|Electric Boat]] division of [[General Dynamics|General Dynamics Corporation]] in [[Groton, Connecticut]], on 28 November 1983 and her keel was laid down on 24 October 1986. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 12 November 1988 and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 30 June 1990 with Commander Thomas W. Mader in command. On 1 March 2012 ''Miami'' pulled into the [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]] in [[Kittery, Maine]] for a scheduled 20-month Engineered Overhaul (EOH) and system upgrades. A civilian employee started a fire aboard the boat on 23 May 2012. It impacted the forward compartment of the submarine which includes crew living, command and control spaces and torpedo room. The revised estimate to restore the USS ''Miami'' increased to approximately $450 million with completion estimated on 30 April 2015. Due to [[Budget sequestration in 2013|budget cuts]], it was announced 6 August 2013 that the vessel would not be repaired and placed on the inactive list.http://www.kjonline.com/news/Navy-abandons-plan-to-fix-nuclear-sub.html On 28 March 2014, the USS ''Miami'' was formally decommissioned.[http://www.militarytimes.com/article/20140328/NEWS/303280014/Decommissioning-today-fire-damaged-sub-Miami Decommissioning today for fire-damaged sub Miami] - Militarytimes.com, 28 March 2014 ==History== ===1999=== USS Miami became the first submarine to conduct combat operations in two theaters since [[World War II]] ([[Operation Desert Fox]] and [[Operation Allied Force]]).{{cite web|title=USS Miami (SSN 755) History|url=*History of Miami operations and port calls[http://www.uscarriers.net/ssn755history.htm]|accessdate=21 December 2013}} ===2012 fire=== [[File:120315-N-TT535-040_USS_Miami.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The USS ''Miami'' enters dry dock at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard on 15 March 2012 to begin an engineered overhaul. She would be severely damaged by fire two months later.]] At 5:41 p.m. EDT on 23 May 2012, fire crews were called with a report of a fire on the USS ''Miami'' while being overhauled at the [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]] in [[Kittery, Maine]]. At the time the submarine was on a scheduled 20-month maintenance cycle,{{cite web|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2012/05/24/fire-put-out-on-nuclear-submarine-off-maine/ |title=Fire Extinguished On Nuclear Submarine In Maine « CBS Boston |publisher=Boston.cbslocal.com |date=24 May 2012 |accessdate=2013-02-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.necn.com/05/23/12/Fire-reported-on-nuclear-powered-submari/landing_newengland.html?blockID=713110&feedID=4206 |title=Fire reported on nuclear-powered submarine at Maine shipyard |publisher=Necn.com |date=23 May 2012 |accessdate=2013-02-16}} indicating the submarine was undergoing an extensive overhaul called "The Engineered Overhaul".{{cite web |first=John|last=Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ship/ssn-688-ero.htm |title=SSN-688 Los Angeles-class |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=29 October 2003 |accessdate=2013-02-16}} Injuries to seven firefighters had been reported by national media.ABC's ''Good Morning America'' 24 May 2012 One crewmember suffered broken ribs when he fell through a hole left by removed deck plates during the fire.{{cite web |last=Sharp | first=David | title=Nuclear Submarine Fire Sparks Two Navy Probes | work=[[Portland Press Herald]]| date=10 September 2012}} It took firefighters 12 hours to extinguish the fire.{{cite news|url=http://www.timescolonist.com/cmlink/gmg-glacier-media-group/canadian-press/news/world/navy-drops-plans-to-repair-fire-damaged-submarine-uss-miami-citing-budget-restraints-1.571590/ |last=Sharp |first=David |title=Navy drops plans to repair fire-damaged submarine USS Miami, citing budget restraints| newspaper=Times Colonist |agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=6 August 2013 |accessdate=2013-02-16}} Originally the U.S. Navy reported that the fire started when an industrial vacuum cleaner, used "to clean worksites on the sub after shipyard workers’ shifts," sucked up a heat source that ignited debris inside the vacuum. On 23 July 2012; Casey J. Fury, a civilian painter and sandblaster working on the sub, was indicted on two counts of arson after confessing to starting the fire. Fury admitted to setting the 23 May fire by igniting some rags on the top bunk of a bunk room. He claimed to have started the fire to get out of work early{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/new_hampshire/articles/2012/06/29/navy_no_update_on_uss_miami_investigation/|title=Navy: No update on USS Miami investigation|work=boston.com|accessdate=2012-07-02}}{{cite web |url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120723/NEWS/120729932/-1/NEWSMAP |title=Suspect in $400M sub blaze appears in court |work=seacoastonline.com |accessdate=2012-07-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wcvb.com/news/local/boston-north/Man-charged-in-fire-on-USS-Miami/-/11984708/15641884/-/eeu7f9z/-/index.html|title=Man charged in fire on USS Miami|work=www.wcvb.com |accessdate=2012-07-23}}{{cite news| title=Civilian worker charged with setting both fires aboard, near submarine in Maine shipyard| url=http://www.newser.com/article/da06ofmg3/civilian-worker-charged-with-setting-both-fires-aboard-near-submarine-in-maine-shipyard.html | agency=[[Associated Press]] |year=2012 | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120723172145/http://www.newser.com/article/da06ofmg3/civilian-worker-charged-with-setting-both-fires-aboard-near-submarine-in-maine-shipyard.html| archivedate=2012-07-23}} On 15 March 2013; Fury was sentenced to over 17 years in federal prison and ordered to pay $400 million in restitution.[http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/15/justice/maine-submarine-arson-sentence/index.html?iref=obnetwork Shipyard worker sentenced to 17 years for $400 million submarine fire] The U.S. Navy debated on whether to scrap the boat. Both of Maine's Senators, [[Susan Collins]] and [[Olympia Snowe]], advocated repairing her.{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/news/navy-fire-on-nuclear-sub-started-in-vacuum_2012-06-07.html |title=Navy: Fire on nuclear sub started in vacuum cleaner |publisher=Pressherald.com |date=7 June 2012 |accessdate=2013-02-16}} The U.S. Navy asked Congress to add $220 million to the operations and maintenance budget for emergent and unfunded ship repairs which would be used to help repair the Miami.{{cite web |url=http://www.theday.com/article/20120720/NWS09/307209962/-1/NWS|title=Links to USS Miami fire explored|work=theday.com|accessdate=2012-07-23}} The final outcome was a choice to repair the submarine at an estimated total cost of $450 million. The USS ''Miami'' was expected to return to service sometime in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.courant.com/business/hc-us-submarine-20120822,0,234505.story|title=USS Miami Expected Back In Service In 2015 |work=www.courant.com |accessdate=2012-08-22}} However, congressional inaction to fully resolve the [[United States fiscal cliff]] had put this in doubt.[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2013/03/ap-navy-says-submarine-miami-repairs-uncertain-031813/ "Navy: Repairs to submarine Miami now uncertain."] To keep costs down, spare parts from the recently decommissioned {{USS|Memphis|SSN-691}} were to be used to repair ''Miami''.http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/f743aa38a4b94bc99c8559232027092c/CT--Submarine-Fire{{dead link|date=February 2013}} Furthermore, integrity checks on the hull did not show changes to its metallurgy or strength; fixing the internal sections would be much cheaper than replacing hull sections. [http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/South-Beached-Fire-and-Fixes-aboard-USS-Miami-07539/ Fire and Fixes aboard USS Miami] - Defenseindustrydaily.com, 2 October 2012 At first glance, it seemed more prudent to repair the USS ''Miami'' in the same manner as the {{USS|San Francisco|SSN-711}} since such a repair would cost "only" (around) 80 million USD.{{cite web |url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2008/10/navy_sub_surgery_102108w/ |title=Transplant complete, attack sub floats again - Navy News | News from Afghanistan & Iraq |publisher=Navy Times |date=|accessdate=2013-02-16}} However, it should be noted that the hull of the USS ''Memphis'' was already 26 years old (as of 2012). ''Memphis'' is also a different version (or "flight") of 688 submarine, as it was not built with the vertical launch system that the newer ''Miami'' has,http://www.public.navy.mil/subfor/csg2/Pages/USSMemphis(SSN691).aspx thus making the Memphis' hull incompatible with that of ''Miami''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} On 6 August 2013, the U.S. Navy announced it will scrap the USS ''Miami'', concluding the cost of repairs is more than it can afford in a time of [[Budget sequestration in 2013|budget cuts]]. A "comprehensive damage assessment" found that while the ''Miami'' could have theoretically been repaired, the necessary repairs were more extensive than first anticipated. This raised the expected repair costs from $450 million to $700 million. At that cost, repairing the ''Miami'' would have required cancellation of work on dozens of other submarines and surface ships. In the end, the Navy determined that repairing the ''Miami'' was not considered worth weakening overall fleet readiness. One factor in the heightened cost estimate was the effect of "environmentally-assisted cracking" in the steel piping and fasteners used in the air, hydraulic, and cooling water systems, which required more equipment to be replaced than previously thought. The U.S. Navy will lose five deployments ''Miami'' was to make over the ten years that remained in its service life, but funds will be used to support other vital maintenance efforts to improve the wholeness and readiness of the fleet.http://navylive.dodlive.mil/2013/08/07/uss-miami-a-tangible-impact-to-readiness-from-sequestration The sub was officially decommissioned on 28 March 2014 .McDermott, Jennifer, "[http://www.stripes.com/news/us/fire-stricken-submarine-uss-miami-is-decommissioned-1.275179#.UziilcKRVZI Fire-stricken submarine USS Miami is decommissioned]", ''[[The Day]]'', 29 March 2014; reprinted in ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper|Stars and Stripes]]'' The USS ''Miami'' is the first submarine and nuclear-powered ship to be lost in a U.S. naval shipyard, and the second warship lost in a U.S. naval shipyard after the destruction of [[USS Merrimack (1855)|USS ''Merrimack'']] in 1861.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}} ==Commanding officers== USS Miami has been commanded by eleven commanding officers (COs), all with the equivalent rank of [[commander]]. Commander Rolf B. Spelker serves as Miami's eleventh and current commanding officer after assuming command from Commander Roger E. Meyer at [[Portsmouth Naval Shipyard]]. Spelker initially served as the Executive Officer of [[USS Albany (SSN-753)]] before assuming command aboard Miami from Meyer; Who will serve as deputy commander of [[Submarine Squadron 6]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. Upon the Navy's announcement of Miami's decommissioning; Meyer served as Miami's last commanding officer to have deployed with the ship itself. The ship's initial start of the original engineering overhaul (EOH) and later fire recovery overhaul were seen over by Meyer from March 2012 to November 2013. Spelker will serve and oversee the ship's defueling of the ship's [[nuclear reactor]], inactivation, and decommissioning. ===Commanding officer (Incumbent)=== * Commander Rolf B. Spelker (2013 – Present) ===Past commanding officers=== *Commander Thomas W. Mader (1988 – 1990) *Commander Houston K. Jones (1990 – 1993) *Commander Don H. Potter, Jr. (1993 – 1995) *Commander Larry B. Olsen (1995 – 1998) *Commander James P. Ransom, III (1998 – 2000) *Commander Randall G. Richards (2000 – 2003) *Commander Joseph B. Wiegand (2003 – 2005) *Commander Richard R. Bryant (2005 – 2008) *Commander Dennis R. Boyer (2008 – 2010) *Commander Roger E. Meyer (2010 – 2013) ==Previous mottos== *"Can do, will do, glad to." This motto was used prior to operation Desert Fox. *"First to fire. Twice to fire." This motto was adopted after returning to home port after the 1998-1999 deployment. ==In popular culture== [[File:SubmarineClancy.jpg|thumb|1st edition (publ. {{otherships|USS Scranton}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image= [[File:US Navy 070615-N-0780F-004 Los Angeles-class fast-attack submarine USS Scranton (SSN 756) departs Souda harbor following a routine port visit to Greece's largest island.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption= USS ''Scranton'' departing [[Souda Bay]] off of the [[Greece|Greek]] island of [[Crete]]. }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag= {{USN flag}} |Ship name=USS ''Scranton'' |Ship namesake= City of [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 26 November 1984 |Ship builder= [[Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding|Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 29 August 1986 |Ship launched= 3 July 1989 |Ship sponsor=Mrs. Sarah McDade |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 26 January 1991 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= [[Naval Station Norfolk]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[File:756insig.png|200px]] }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement={{convert|5742|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6145|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|403|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Scranton'' (SSN-756)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, is the second ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding|Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]], on 26 November 1984, and construction began on 29 August 1986. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 3 July 1989 sponsored by Mrs. Sarah McDade, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 26 January 1991, with Commander J.G. Meyer in command. ''Scranton'' was the first submarine at Newport News to be built via "modular construction". No keel was laid. In this method, the ship was almost fully built out in individual hull sections. Most of the internal structure, machinery, and piping were loaded in via open ends of the hull sections as each hull section was built out. The individual hull sections were later assembled with exact precision such that piping running between the sections was joined as the hull sections were welded together. The ship was later rolled into a floating drydock and "floated" In January 2006, ''Scranton'' successfully demonstrated homing and docking of an AN/BLQ-11 [[Long-Term Mine Reconnaissance System]] (LMRS) [[unmanned undersea vehicle]] (UUV) system during at-sea testing under the leadership of Commanding Officer Michael J. Quinn.[http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=22618] ==Operation Odyssey Dawn== On 19 March 2011, the submarine launched Tomahawk cruise missiles at [[Libya]]n air defenses as part of [[Operation Odyssey Dawn]].Burns, Robert, "[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/us_us_libya First wave of allied assault: 112 cruise missiles]", ''[[Yahoo! News]]'', 20 March 2011, retrieved 20 March 2011. == External links == {{Commons category|USS Scranton (SSN-756)}} *[http://www.csg2.navy.mil/Scranton/scranton.htm USS ''Scranton'' official website] *[http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN756.htm nvr.navy.mil: USS ''Scranton''] *[http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08756.htm navsource.org: USS ''Scranton''] *[http://united-states-navy.com/ssn/ssn756.htm united-states-navy.com: USS ''Scranton''] ==References== {{DANFSNVR}} ==External links== {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scranton (SSN-756)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Cold War submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Pennsylvania-related ships]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]] [[Category:1989 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Scranton, Pennsylvania]] {{US-submarine-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{otherships|USS Charlotte}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= [[Image:USS Charlotte SSN-766.jpg|300px|USS Charlotte (SSN-766) off the coast of Oahu]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag= {{USN flag}} |Ship name=USS ''Charlotte'' |Ship namesake= The City of [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= 6 February 1987 |Ship builder= [[Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding|Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= 17 August 1990 |Ship launched= 3 October 1992 |Ship sponsor= Mrs. Mary McCormack |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 16 September 1994 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= [[Pearl Harbor]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto=''Silent Stinger'' |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= |Ship badge=[[Image:766insig.png|150px]] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}} |Ship displacement={{convert|6000|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} light
{{convert|6927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} full
{{convert|927|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} [[Deadweight tonnage|dead]] |Ship length={{convert|110.3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|10|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft={{convert|9.4|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=• 4 × {{convert|21|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} torpedo tubes
• 10 × [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mark 48 ADCAP]] torpedoes
• [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk]] missiles
• [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon]] missiles
• Mark 67 Submarine Launched Mobile Mines
• [[CAPTOR mine|Mark 60 CAPTOR mines]] |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Charlotte'' (SSN-766)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, is the fourth ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 6 February 1987 and her keel was laid down on 17 August 1990. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 3 October 1992 sponsored by Mrs. Mary McComack, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 16 September 1994, with Commander Michael Matthews in command. The current commanding officer is Commander Andrew T. Miller.{{Cite web|url=http://www.csp.navy.mil/subssquadrons/charlotte/charlotteco_bio.shtml|title=USS Charlotte CO Biography|accessdate=2009-08-14}} ==History== [[File:Charlotte Northpole.jpg|left|thumb|''Charlotte'' at the north pole]] On 29 November 2005, ''Charlotte'' arrived in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], having taken the northern route from [[Pearl Harbor]], under the [[Arctic]] ice cap. Along the way, she surfaced at the [[North Pole]] through 61 inches of ice, a record for a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}.{{Cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=21223|title= USS Charlotte Achieves Milestone During Under-Ice Transit|accessdate=2007-10-25|author=Dave Ozeck, Commander, Submarine Force, U.S. Atlantic Fleet Public Affairs}} On 24 October 2007, ''Charlotte'' returned to Pearl Harbor from [[Norfolk Naval Shipyard]] after nearly two years in a Depot Modernization Period.{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=32796 |title=USS Charlotte Returns to Pearl Harbor |author=Cynthia Clark |date=25 October 2007}} ==''Charlotte'' in Fiction== In [[Tom Clancy]]'s book ''[[Debt of Honor]]'', USS ''Charlotte'' is sunk by the Japanese sub ''Harushio'' along with her sister ship {{USS|Asheville|SSN-758|6}}. USS ''Charlotte'' also makes an appearance in [[Dan Brown]]'s novel ''[[Deception Point]]'', where it plays an important role making covert missions in the Arctic Circle. == References == {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}} {{DANFSNVR}} {{Los_Angeles_class_submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Charlotte (SSN-766)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy North Carolina-related ships]] [[Category:1992 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]] {{US-submarine-stub}}

'''Submerged:''' +{{convert|20|kn|mph km/h}} (official) |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors=BQQ-5 passive [[SONAR]], BQS-15 detecting and ranging SONAR, WLR-8 fire control [[RADAR]] receiver, WLR-9 acoustic receiver for detection of active search SONAR and acoustic homing torpedoes, BRD-7 radio direction finder |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 21 in (533 mm) bow tubes, 10 [[Mark 48 torpedo|Mk48 ADCAP torpedo]] reloads, [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|Tomahawk land attack missile]] block 3 SLCM range {{convert|1700|nmi|km}}, [[Boeing Harpoon|Harpoon anti–surface ship missile]] range {{convert|70|nmi|km}}, mine laying Mk67 mobile Mk60 captor mines |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Jefferson City'' (SSN-759)''', a {{sclass|Los Angeles|submarine}}, was the only ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Jefferson City, Missouri]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 26 November 1984 and her keel was laid down on 21 September 1987. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 17 August 1990 sponsored by Mrs. Susan A. Skelton, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 29 February 1992, with Commander Russell Harris in command. Homeport is the [[Naval Base Point Loma|Point Loma Sub Base]] in San Diego, CA. {{reflist}} {{DANFSNVR}} {{Los Angeles class submarine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jefferson City (SSN-759)}} [[Category:Los Angeles-class submarines]] [[Category:Nuclear ships of the United States Navy]] [[Category:United States Navy Missouri-related ships]] [[Category:1990 ships]] [[Category:Active submarines of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Newport News, Virginia]] {{US-submarine-stub}}
